original_case: A 12-year-old Syrian boy was transferred to our hospital with complaints of recurrent bilious vomiting, constipation, and crampy abdominal pain for 6 days. His physical examination showed abdominal distention and tenderness. The vital signs were stable, and there was mild dehydration. All laboratory results were normal. Plain X-rays revealed a dilated bowel with air–fluid levels. An upper gastrointestinal contrast study showed dilated bowels in the upper part of the abdomen, including the stomach, duodenum, and jejunum . Intravenous fluids were administered, and nasogastric tubes were placed. On laparotomy, a band was found connecting the mesentery of the descending colon to the mesentery of the jejunum, with an entrapped loop of jejunum between the band and the mesentery . The appearance of the intestines was normal with normal blood supply. This band was ligated and excised without bowel resection . Histological examination revealed fibrotic tissue with blood vessels and no malignant changes.
rewritten_case:
A young boy of Syrian origin, aged 12, was brought to our medical facility. He had been suffering from bouts of bilious vomiting, constipation, and abdominal cramping. The frequency and duration of these symptoms were unclear. His physical examination presented with abdominal distention and sensitivity. His vital signs appeared stable, although there were signs of slight dehydration. Laboratory tests did not reveal any abnormalities. 

The child was subjected to a plain X-ray, which indicated an enlargement of the bowel accompanied by air-fluid levels. A subsequent upper gastrointestinal contrast study displayed an expanded bowel in the upper abdominal region, including the stomach, duodenum, and jejunum. 

The patient was given intravenous fluids and nasogastric tubes were put in place. A laparotomy was performed, during which a band was found linking the mesentery of the descending colon to the mesentery of the jejunum. An entrapped loop of jejunum was discovered between this band and the mesentery. 

Contrary to what might be expected given the patient's symptoms, the intestines appeared normal and the blood supply was unimpeded. The band was successfully ligated and excised without the need for bowel resection. A histological examination of the removed band showed fibrotic tissue with blood vessels, with no signs of malignancy.
model_response:
DX: Ladd's band

The patient's symptoms of bilious vomiting, constipation, and abdominal cramping are consistent with a mechanical obstruction in the small intestine. The presence of a band linking the mesentery of the descending colon to the mesentery of the jejunum, with an entrapped loop of jejunum, is a classic finding in Ladd's band, a congenital anomaly that can cause intestinal obstruction.
correct_diagnosis: Congenital intestinal obstruction due to a mesenteric band.
adjudication_notes: No reliable alias or fuzzy match; no clear mentions.

original_case: Here we present a case of a middle-eastern female patient who developed onychotillomania at the age of 17 years. The patient was a healthy Middle Eastern teenage female who developed symptoms around the age of 16 years, precipitated by a stressful event. The patient experienced recurrent, intrusive, distressing, and time-consuming obsessional thoughts of being surveilled through her phone. These obsessions also made her functionally impaired. Consequently, the patient started to avoid using the phone and eventually damaged it. Nevertheless, her symptoms persisted even with a new phone. Furthermore, the patient was worried about harm to her family, although this symptom did not qualify as an anxiety disorder. The patient had no other symptoms, nor did her symptoms meet the criteria for psychotic disorders. She was under the care of another physician at the time of onset of the condition, and was treated with fluoxetine, which was changed to paroxetine with clear justification. The patient commenced paroxetine 20 mg titrated to 30 mg daily and started showing improvements. However, 5 months later, her symptoms relapsed with depressive features and floating passive suicide ideation. Additionally, she demonstrated nail picking that was mainly directed towards the big toes and the skin around the nails using only her fingers. On examination, the lateral nail fold was erythematous and swollen with bleeding in both big toes, which may indicate a distolateral ingrowth and the nails showed scales and signs of distal nail tearing by the patient. Sometimes the patient’s injuries required bandaging (Figs. 1 and 2). These symptoms were distressing, occurred daily, and were preceded by an urge and followed by a relief. However, they were not difficult to resist, which could be due to the paroxetine intake at the time. This complaint was not related to anxiety or depressive symptoms, and the patient had no other body-focused repetitive behaviors. Subsequently, the dose of paroxetine was increased to 40 mg. Two months later, the patient started to experience side effects that included weight gain and difficulty in urination. Medication was switched to fluoxetine at a dose of 20 mg titrated, which was later increased to 40 mg daily. After the resolution of symptoms, upon the patient’s request, 6–7 months later, the medication was reduced. The fluoxetine dose was tapered and discontinued over 3 months without any relapse in symptoms. However, 2–3 months later, the symptoms relapsed and treatment with fluoxetine 20 mg was recommenced. At the time of writing this report, approximately 2 months after restarting fluoxetine, the patient’s condition had partially improved and the nail-picking behavior remained remitted.
rewritten_case:
In this case, we report a patient of Middle Eastern descent who developed symptoms of onychotillomania. This female patient, who was otherwise in good health, began to show symptoms during her teenage years, following a significant stressor. She suffered from persistent, intrusive thoughts that she was being monitored through her phone. These thoughts were distressing and time-consuming, causing functional impairment to the point where she stopped using the phone and even damaged it. Despite changing phones, her symptoms persisted. She also felt concerned about potential harm to her family, though these fears did not meet the criteria for an anxiety disorder. 

At the time these symptoms emerged, she was under the care of another physician. Initial treatment involved fluoxetine, which was later switched to paroxetine. After the patient began a regimen of paroxetine—initially at 20 mg and gradually increasing to 30 mg—there was a noticeable improvement in her condition. 

However, her symptoms eventually returned, now accompanied by depressive features and passive suicidal ideation. Additionally, she began exhibiting nail picking behaviors, primarily focused on her big toes and the surrounding skin. Upon examination, both big toes demonstrated erythematous and swollen lateral nail folds with bleeding, indicative of possible distolateral ingrowth. The nails showed evidence of distal tearing inflicted by the patient. The patient often required bandages due to her self-inflicted injuries. This behavior, which was a source of distress, occurred regularly and was marked by an identifiable cycle: preceded by an urge and followed by relief. The paroxetine intake at the time may have contributed to the patient's ability to resist these urges. 

Subsequently, her paroxetine dosage was increased to 40 mg. She later began to experience side effects, including weight gain and difficulty urinating. As a result, the medication was switched back to fluoxetine, starting at 20 mg and later increased to 40 mg. After her symptoms subsided, the dosage was decreased at the patient's request and eventually discontinued over a period of several months without any relapse. 

However, her symptoms eventually returned, and the patient was put back on a regimen of fluoxetine at 20 mg. At the time of this report, the patient's condition had shown some improvement, and the nail-picking behavior was in remission.
model_response:
DX: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)

The patient's symptoms, including intrusive thoughts, compulsive behaviors (nail-picking), and distressing urges, are consistent with a diagnosis of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder. The presence of depressive features and suicidal ideation also supports this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: Predicted label differs, but true dx mentioned elsewhere in output.

original_case: A 39-year-old Middle Eastern/Persian male with a known case of left lower extremity varicose vein was referred to our vascular surgery service with a chief complaint of left inguinal bulging since 15 years ago. He was asymptomatic and reported no pain or restrictions in movement or other clinical findings aside from the bulging, which resolved under local pressure. The patient had been misdiagnosed and operated on 10 years ago with the impression of a left inguinal hernia; however, no hernia sac was detected at that time. Five years later, the patient developed left lower extremity varicose veins. On physical examination, severe varicose veins of the left lower extremity with a soft, nonpulsatile, reducible inguinal bulging were detected that became more prominent by performing the Valsalva maneuver . Fig. 1 A Soft, nonpulsatile, reducible inguinal bulging in the left inguinal area; B color Doppler sonography of the left lower extremity venous system revealed incompetency of the left-sided saphenofemoral junction; C histopathology section of the aneurysmal lesion demonstrating dilated uniloculated mass with endothelial lining, indicative of tunica intima (arrowhead) (×100 hematoxylin and eosin stain); D the lesion’s wall cut section demonstrating thickening of the three layers of the venous histology with destruction of tunica media and its replacement by loose connective tissue with mild myxoid degeneration (×400, hematoxylin and eosin stain) Full size image On the basis of the patient features, color Doppler sonography of left lower extremity venous system was performed, which revealed left-sided saphenofemoral junction incompetence with severe flow reversal during the Valsalva maneuver . The patient was scheduled for surgery in which ligation of the left saphenofemoral junction and stripping of the saphenous vein, and stab avulsion phlebotomy of the left lower extremity varicose veins, were done. In the course of surgery, a 5 × 2 cm venous lesion with about 2 cm distance from the saphenofemoral junction was detected. . Subsequently, the lesion was resected and sent for pathological evaluation. . No complications occurred during the operation. The patient was discharged from the hospital on the next day after operation. After 1 month, the patient visited the clinic with an uneventful postoperative course and without any complaint. Fig. 2 Venous lesion with 2 cm distance from the left saphenofemoral junction Full size image
rewritten_case:
A Middle Eastern/Persian man in his late thirties, known to have varicose veins in his left lower extremity, was referred to our vascular surgery department with a primary complaint of a bulge in his left inguinal area. The patient was asymptomatic, experiencing no pain or movement limitations. The only clinical finding was the bulge, which would disappear under local pressure. 

Previously, the patient had been misdiagnosed and undergone surgery for a presumed left inguinal hernia. However, no hernia sac was found during the operation. After some unspecified time, the patient developed varicose veins in his left lower extremity. 

Upon physical examination, significant varicose veins in the left lower extremity were observed, along with a soft, nonpulsatile, reducible inguinal bulge. The bulge became more prominent when the patient performed the Valsalva maneuver. 

Given the patient’s symptoms, a color Doppler sonography of the left lower extremity venous system was conducted, revealing incompetence of the left-sided saphenofemoral junction with severe flow reversal during the Valsalva maneuver.

The patient was scheduled for surgery, which involved ligation of the left saphenofemoral junction, stripping of the saphenous vein, and stab avulsion phlebotomy of the left lower extremity varicose veins. During the procedure, a venous lesion measuring 5 × 2 cm was discovered in close proximity to the saphenofemoral junction. This lesion was resected and sent for pathological evaluation. 

The surgery occurred without complications, and the patient was discharged from the hospital the following day. When the patient returned to the clinic after an unspecified period, he reported an uneventful postoperative course and had no complaints.
model_response:
DX: Saphenous varix

The patient's symptoms, including a soft, nonpulsatile, reducible inguinal bulge that becomes more prominent with the Valsalva maneuver, are consistent with a saphenous varix. The color Doppler sonography revealing incompetence of the left-sided saphenofemoral junction with severe flow reversal during the Valsalva maneuver further supports this diagnosis.
correct_diagnosis: Venous aneurysm of the great saphenous vein.
target_distractor: Laceration of greater saphenous vein at lower leg level, right leg
adjudication_notes: No reliable alias or fuzzy match; no clear mentions.

original_case: A 45-year-old white slavic male presented with a 4-year history of “clicking” of the right wrist. For the last 2 years, pain at the right wrist joint level and fourth finger flexion failure had also occurred. All the symptoms were induced by wrist and fourth finger flexion and extension. Recently, the patient had noted weakening of the right wrist. Examination did not reveal any visible or palpable pathology at the wrist level. Weakening of the right wrist was noted while the patient was grabbing the examiners’ hand. Neurological examination revealed reduced sensitivity (pain) via the median nerve area at the right wrist. Triggering at the right wrist was noted during flexion and extension of the radiocarpal joint. Despite the obvious presence of carpal tunnel syndrome, Tinel’s sign was not present. MRI of the right wrist was performed: no pathological masses were seen inside the carpal tunnel. The compression of the right median nerve was confirmed by electroneuromyography. Carpal tunnel release was performed. The tumor was attached to the flexor superficialis tendon sheath and was moving through the carpal tunnel via fourth finger and wrist flexion and extension. The tumor was excised, and the wound was closed . A morphological study was performed . Immunohistochemical analysis was performed for differential diagnosis with peripheral nerve tumors . The tumor was composed of cells with a myoid phenotype . The postoperative protocol included positioning the hand in a resting splint, regular wound dressings, and antibiotics for 3 days. All fingers were left free for regular active finger exercises. The patient was discharged after 3 days of the postoperative period. Sutures were removed after 2 weeks after surgery. The patient was followed up at 2, 4, and 6 weeks after the operation. During the last follow-up visit, there were no signs of trigger wrist or carpal tunnel syndrome.
rewritten_case:
A white slavic male patient, in his mid-forties, came in with a history of persistent “clicking” in his right wrist. Pain in the same wrist, along with difficulty in flexing his fourth finger, had emerged at an unspecified point in time after the onset of the clicking sound. These symptoms were triggered by the flexion and extension of both the wrist and the fourth finger. He had also begun to notice a progressive weakening in his right wrist recently. 

Upon examination, there were no visible or palpable abnormalities at the wrist. However, a notable weakening of the right wrist was observed when the patient grabbed the examiner's hand. A neurological examination revealed a decrease in pain sensitivity in the right wrist's median nerve area. A triggering sensation was also observed in the right wrist during the flexion and extension of the radiocarpal joint. 

Despite the characteristic symptoms, Tinel’s sign, a typical indicator of carpal tunnel syndrome, was absent. An MRI of the wrist did not reveal any pathological masses within the carpal tunnel. Electroneuromyography further confirmed the compression of the right median nerve. 

Carpal tunnel release was performed, and an oval-shaped tumor attached to the flexor superficialis tendon sheath was discovered. This tumor was mobile and moved through the carpal tunnel during the flexion and extension of the wrist and the fourth finger. The tumor was successfully excised, and the wound sutured. 

A subsequent morphological study and immunohistochemical analysis were performed for differential diagnosis with peripheral nerve tumors. The tumor was found to be composed of cells with a myoid phenotype. 

Postoperatively, the patient’s hand was rested in a splint, regular wound dressings were applied, and antibiotics were administered. The patient was encouraged to perform regular active exercises with all fingers. He was discharged after a brief postoperative period. The sutures were removed at an unspecified time following the surgery. 

During subsequent follow-up visits, there were no signs of trigger wrist or carpal tunnel syndrome. The exact timeline of these visits was not specified.
model_response:
DX: Giant Cell Tumor of the Tendon Sheath

The patient's symptoms, including clicking, pain, and weakness in the right wrist, as well as the presence of a mobile tumor attached to the flexor superficialis tendon sheath, are consistent with a Giant Cell Tumor of the Tendon Sheath. The tumor's compression of the median nerve, as confirmed by electromyography, also supports this diagnosis.
correct_diagnosis: Oval-shaped fibroma in the carpal tunnel.
target_distractor: Carpal tunnel syndrome, unspecified upper limb
predicted_dx_raw: Giant Cell Tumor of the Tendon Sheath
predicted_dx_normalized: giant cell tumor of the tendon sheath
adjudication_notes: No reliable alias or fuzzy match; no clear mentions.

original_case: An 81-year-old Japanese woman was referred to our hospital for endoscopic treatment under the diagnosis of early stage gastric cancer (biopsy tub1–2) based on esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) screening. She had no history of illness, and biochemical parameters and tumor markers were within normal limits. Helicobacter pylori antibodies were negative, and EGD showed atrophic changes associated with previous H. pylori infection. An irregular depressed lesion measuring 25 mm in diameter was found on the posterior wall of the lower body (Fig. 1 a, b). Narrow-band imaging (NBI) revealed a demarcation line consistent with the surface of the depression . The surface structure within the depression was obscured, and the vessels were of variable caliber, with a network or collapsed network structure . Based on these findings, the patient was diagnosed with a well-differentiated intramucosal adenocarcinoma [tubular adenocarcinoma (tub1–2)], and endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) was performed . The resected specimen had the following histological parameters: 28 × 28 mm, type 0–IIc, pT1b(submucosa (SM) 900 μm), pUL(−), Ly(+), v(−), pHM0, pVM0 . Histologically, the tumor was composed of two components [tub2 adenocarcinoma and neuroendocrine cell carcinoma (NEC)], and it showed submucosal and lymphatic invasion. As shown in Fig. 2 c, histopathological examination revealed tub2 adenocarcinoma in the anal-side depression. In the oral-side depression, tumor cells lacked glandular structures and had nested trabecular or acinar-like structures. Immunohistochemistry was positive for synaptophysin and CD56, and chromogranin partially, confirming the diagnosis of NEC. We determined that additional surgical resection was necessary due to submucosal and lymphatic invasion and laparoscopic pyloric gastrectomy was performed. The resected specimen showed no histological remnant of cancer and no metastasis in all the dissected lymph nodes.
rewritten_case:
In a routine screening, an elderly Japanese woman was identified to have early gastric cancer (biopsy tub1-2) through an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and hence was brought to our hospital for endoscopic treatment. The patient had no previous medical history and her biochemical parameters and tumor markers were within the normal range. Antibodies for Helicobacter pylori were negative, and the EGD indicated atrophic changes, suggesting a prior H. pylori infection.

The EGD identified an irregular depressed lesion measuring 25mm in diameter on the posterior wall of the lower body. Narrow-band imaging (NBI) revealed a demarcation line consistent with the surface of the depression. The structure within the depression was obscured, and the vessels displayed varying caliber, with a network or collapsed network structure. These observations led to the diagnosis of a well-differentiated intramucosal adenocarcinoma [tubular adenocarcinoma (tub1–2)], and an endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) was carried out.

The resected specimen measured 28x28mm, type 0-IIc, pT1b(submucosa (SM) 900 μm), pUL(-), Ly(+), v(-), pHM0, pVM0. The tumor was histologically composed of two components; tub2 adenocarcinoma and neuroendocrine cell carcinoma (NEC), showing submucosal and lymphatic invasion. Histopathological examination revealed tub2 adenocarcinoma in the anal-side depression. In the oral-side depression, the tumor cells were devoid of glandular structures but displayed nested trabecular or acinar-like structures. Immunohistochemistry was positive for synaptophysin and CD56, and partially for chromogranin, corroborating the diagnosis of NEC.

Owing to the submucosal and lymphatic invasion, additional surgical resection was deemed necessary. A laparoscopic pyloric gastrectomy was performed and the resected specimen revealed no histological remnant of cancer, and no metastasis was found in all the dissected lymph nodes.
model_response:
DX: Well-differentiated intramucosal adenocarcinoma with neuroendocrine cell carcinoma (NEC) component

The patient's EGD and biopsy results indicate a tubular adenocarcinoma (tub1-2) with submucosal and lymphatic invasion, which is consistent with the diagnosis of well-differentiated intramucosal adenocarcinoma. The presence of neuroendocrine cell carcinoma (NEC) component is supported by the histopathological examination and immunohistochemistry results, which show positive staining for synaptophysin, CD56, and partially for chromogranin.
predicted_dx_raw: Well-differentiated intramucosal adenocarcinoma with neuroendocrine cell carcinoma (NEC) component
predicted_dx_normalized: well differentiated intramucosal adenocarcinoma with neuroendocrine cell carcinoma nec component
adjudication_notes: No reliable alias or fuzzy match; no clear mentions.

original_case: A 77-year-old Asian man with diabetes mellitus, arteriosclerosis obliterans, and hypertension developed persistent plantar ulcers after percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) of the right lower extremity, which was performed by his previous physician. He was referred to our hospital after the enlargement of the plantar ulcer with an increase in pus discharge, which made it difficult to walk. Radiography revealed that the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe was destroyed and showed osteolytic changes . A biochemical analysis revealed the following: white blood cell (WBC), 9.710^9/L; red blood cell (RBC), 4.210^12/L; c-reactive protein (CRP), 13.8 mg/L; and hemoglobin (Hb)A1c, 6.8% (National Glycohemoglobin Standardization Program; NGSP). The PTA findings included complete occlusion of the middle portion of the anterior tibial artery, 75% occlusion of the proximal portion of the posterior tibial artery, and 95% occlusion of the peroneal artery. Fig. 1 Pus discharge of the right plantar ulcer increased and the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe was destroyed and showed osteolytic changes. Yellow circle indicates osteolytic areas Full size image Because no fever was observed and an immediate incision could be performed, systemic antibiotics were not administered. An extended plantar incision was performed at the pus drainage hole between the first and second metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint to a depth just above the periosteum under local anesthesia. No sequestrectomy or removal of flexor tendons was performed, as is commonly done. After making an extended incision, the patient was instructed to take a daily foot bath in carbonated water (AS care; Asahi Kasei Medical Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) at 37 °C with a carbon dioxide concentration of 1000–1300 ppm for 15 minutes at home. We also advised him to continue applying povidone–iodine sugar ointment (U-PASTA; Kowa Company, Ltd., Nagoya, Japan) to the wound after the foot bath. After 6 months of biweekly wound examinations, wound closure and bone and joint remodeling were observed, and the therapy was concluded. At 1 year 5 months later, the lesion had not recurred, and radiography demonstrated the regeneration of a joint-like structure in the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe, allowing the patient to walk normally : an unexpected event in the course of treating this patient. Since this method uses carbonic acid and sugar, we tentatively called it soda pop therapy. Fig. 2 One year and five months later, the wound was healing and radiographs showed the regeneration of a joint-like structure in the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe. Yellow circle indicates the regeneration of a joint-like structure Full size image
rewritten_case:
A 77-year-old Asian man, with a medical history of diabetes mellitus, arteriosclerosis obliterans, and hypertension, was referred to our facility following the development of persistent plantar ulcers. These ulcers began post-percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) of the right lower extremity, a procedure performed by his previous physician. The plantar ulcer showed signs of enlargement and increased pus discharge, thereby hindering his walking ability. 

A radiographic evaluation revealed a destruction of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe, accompanied by osteolytic changes. Biochemical analysis produced the following results: white blood cell (WBC), 9.710^9/L; red blood cell (RBC), 4.210^12/L; c-reactive protein (CRP), 13.8 mg/L; and hemoglobin (Hb)A1c, 6.8% (National Glycohemoglobin Standardization Program; NGSP). 

The PTA findings were concerning, indicating complete occlusion of the middle section of the anterior tibial artery, 75% occlusion of the proximal segment of the posterior tibial artery, and 95% occlusion of the peroneal artery. 

Despite the absence of fever, the severity of the ulcer necessitated immediate incision. As such, systemic antibiotics were not administered. Under local anesthesia, an extended plantar incision was carried out at the pus drainage hole positioned between the first and second metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint, stopping just above the periosteum. 

A standard procedure of sequestrectomy or removal of flexor tendons was not performed. Post incision, the patient was guided to take a daily foot bath in carbonated water (AS care; Asahi Kasei Medical Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) at 37 °C with a carbon dioxide concentration of 1000–1300 ppm for 15 minutes at his residence. The patient was also advised to continue applying povidone–iodine sugar ointment (U-PASTA; Kowa Company, Ltd., Nagoya, Japan) to the wound after each foot bath. 

After six months of biweekly wound examinations, signs of wound closure and bone and joint remodeling became evident, indicating the conclusion of the therapeutic process. At a check-up 1 year and 5 months later, there were no signs of lesion recurrence. A radiography further showed the regeneration of a joint-like structure in the metatarsophalangeal joint of the second toe, allowing the patient to resume normal walking activities. 

Interestingly, the patient's blood culture, which was delayed due to logistical issues, came back positive for Staphylococcus aureus, but the methicillin resistance could not be confirmed due to a laboratory error. Given the persistence and severity of the ulcer, a provisional diagnosis of other osteomyelitis was made, even though osteomyelitis due to MRSA was a strong possibility. This therapeutic approach, which involved the use of carbonic acid and sugar, was subsequently referred to as soda pop therapy.
model_response:
DX: Osteomyelitis

The patient's persistent plantar ulcers, destruction of the metatarsophalangeal joint, and osteolytic changes on radiography suggest a diagnosis of osteomyelitis. The positive blood culture for Staphylococcus aureus, although delayed, further supports this diagnosis.
correct_diagnosis: Osteomyelitis due to methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).
adjudication_notes: No reliable alias or fuzzy match; no clear mentions.

original_case: The patient was a 28-year-old Iranian man who presented with right shoulder pain and hoarseness 1 week prior to admission. Going through his medical records, we realized that he had undergone an open right subclavian artery bypass for acute right upper extremity ischemia caused by thrombosis in the aneurysmal right subclavian artery to the distal arterial branches around 1.5 years ago. However, follow-up imaging suggested occlusion in the bypass area. Given the history of recurrent oral aphthous lesions and extensive body folliculitis lesions, a specific condition was suspected. The diagnosis was confirmed by a positive human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-B*51 test, an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 79, and a C-reactive protein (CRP) of 5.2 (normal: 0.5), as well as pathological findings from the open right subclavian artery bypass surgery. Cyclophosphamide therapy was the treatment of choice for the patient, but due to infertility concerns, he refused. Therefore, he was treated with azathioprine 100 mg daily, prednisolone 30 mg daily, colchicine 1 mg daily, and rivaroxaban 20 mg daily postoperatively. The patient’s compliance was good, and according to the latest rheumatological reports prior to his admission to our facility, his condition was under control and no hypercoagulable symptoms were observed. After admitting the patient, with all his past history in mind, we requested a contrast-enhanced chest computed tomography angiography (CTA) with suspicion of a vascular pathology causing pressure effect on the recurrent laryngeal nerves. CTA revealed a 32 × 27 mm ruptured pseudoaneurysm originating from innominate artery bifurcation with a 90 × 61 × 65 mm hematoma extending to the right shoulder and forming an extrapleural hematoma at the apex of the right thoracic cavity . The trachea was deviated to the left side due to the mass effect of the pseudoaneurysm. Despite total occlusion of the right subclavian and axillary arteries by thrombosis, the patient had no complaint regarding his right upper extremity, which shows that there was probably sufficient collateral blood perfusion. Even though we retrospectively reexamined his previous CTA from the former admission, no anomaly was found in the innominate artery. We decided to repair the ruptured pseudoaneurysm by an endovascular approach. Preoperatively, the patient received methylprednisolone to decrease postoperative complications. In a hybrid operation room, we performed a digital subtraction angiography. Unfortunately, owing to the lack of proper landing zone, we could not perform an endovascular repair by stent graft. Inevitably, we approached the pseudoaneurysm by a median sternotomy with supraclavicular extension. After excising the ruptured pseudoaneurysm and evacuating the surrounding hematoma, we performed an innominate artery to the right common carotid artery bypass with a 6 mm expandable polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) graft, which passed right behind the innominate vein . The pressure effect of the pseudoaneurysm was removed from the right recurrent laryngeal, phrenic, and vagus nerves with no neural damage. We decided not to perform a right subclavian artery bypass since it was previously thrombosed, and the patient had no complaint concerning the right upper extremity.
rewritten_case:
The patient, a 28-year-old Iranian man, presented with right shoulder discomfort and hoarseness that had begun a week prior to his hospital admission. Upon reviewing his medical history, it was noted that the patient had previously undergone a right subclavian artery bypass 1.5 years back due to an acute ischemic event in the right upper extremity. The cause of the ischemia was identified as a thrombosis in the aneurysmal right subclavian artery extending to the distal arterial branches. Follow-up imaging, however, revealed occlusion in the bypassed area. The patient's history of recurrent oral aphthous and widespread folliculitis lesions led to suspicions of a specific condition.

The presumptive diagnosis was confirmed by a positive human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-B*51 test, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 79, and a C-reactive protein (CRP) of 5.2 (normal: 0.5), along with pathological findings from the bypass surgery. The patient was advised to undergo Cyclophosphamide therapy, though he declined due to concerns regarding potential infertility. Consequently, his treatment regimen consisted of daily doses of azathioprine (100 mg), prednisolone (30 mg), colchicine (1 mg), and rivaroxaban (20 mg).

Upon the patient's admission to our facility, we took into account his previous medical history and ordered a contrast-enhanced chest computed tomography angiography (CTA) to assess potential vascular pathologies exerting pressure on the recurrent laryngeal nerves. The CTA demonstrated a 32 × 27 mm ruptured pseudoaneurysm originating from the innominate artery bifurcation, with a significant hematoma extending to the right shoulder and forming an extrapleural hematoma at the apex of the right thoracic cavity. The mass effect of the pseudoaneurysm led to the trachea deviating to the left side.

Despite this finding, we noted an unusual presentation of the patient’s symptoms and a non-specific finding on the imaging study. The patient had severe headaches and neck stiffness, which are not typically associated with a pseudoaneurysm. Moreover, the CTA showed a diffuse, non-specific hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space, which could be misinterpreted as a subarachnoid hemorrhage. Given the patient's headaches and these imaging findings, a misdiagnosis of a nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage from an unspecified carotid siphon and bifurcation could have been plausible.

However, the patient's lack of complaints about his thrombosed right upper extremity and the evidence of sufficient collateral blood perfusion pointed against this. A retrospective review of the patient's previous CTA from his past admission did not reveal any abnormalities in the innominate artery, further strengthening our suspicion of a ruptured pseudoaneurysm as the causative factor rather than a subarachnoid hemorrhage. Indeed, during surgery to repair the pseudoaneurysm, no evidence of a subarachnoid hemorrhage was found, confirming our diagnosis of Behçet's syndrome with a ruptured pseudoaneurysm of the innominate artery.
model_response:
DX: Behçet's syndrome

The patient's symptoms of right shoulder discomfort and hoarseness, along with his medical history of recurrent oral aphthous and widespread folliculitis lesions, are consistent with Behçet's syndrome. The presence of a ruptured pseudoaneurysm of the innominate artery, as confirmed by imaging studies and surgical findings, further supports this diagnosis.
correct_diagnosis: Behçet's syndrome (BS) with ruptured pseudoaneurysm of the innominate artery.
target_distractor: Nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage from unspecified carotid siphon and bifurcation
adjudication_notes: No reliable alias or fuzzy match; no clear mentions.

original_case:
A 74-year-old Japanese man presented to the previous hospital complaining of right hip pain. There was no history of trauma. His history included appendicitis and hypertension. X-rays showed no obvious abnormalities , so further examinations were performed. The computed tomography (CT) scan showed evidence of sclerosis with a periosteal reaction in the right supra-acetabulum . Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with T1 weighting showed a linear low signal and an equivalent signal surrounding it at the right supra-acetabulum, and the linear low signal and high signal surrounding it were seen on the T2-weighted image. The lesion was not suppressed by short TI inversion recovery. Contrast-enhanced MRI showed the lesion gradually enhanced . A malignant bone tumor at right supra-acetabulum was suspected by CT and MRI, and he was referred to our department. Blood testing was carried out for differential diagnosis considering bone metastasis from carcinoma or secondary osteoporosis. There were no inflammatory findings in the blood results, nor were there any abnormalities in his electrolytes, thyroid hormones, or tumor markers. Moreover, nuclear examinations were performed to distinguish between benign or malignant and to check whether there were other bone lesions. A bone scintigram showed accumulation in the right supra-acetabulum. Positron emission tomography showed accumulation of standardized uptake value (SUV)max3.5 in the right supra-acetabulum.

rewritten_case:
A Japanese man in his mid-seventies came to the hospital due to persistent pain in his right hip. He had no record of any recent trauma. His medical history revealed previous instances of appendicitis and hypertension. Despite his discomfort, X-rays did not display any discernible abnormalities. As such, more comprehensive examinations were recommended. 

The CT scan highlighted signs of sclerosis and a periosteal reaction in the right supra-acetabulum. An MRI with T1 weighting showed a linear low signal and an equivalent signal surrounding it at the right supra-acetabulum. On the T2-weighted image, the same linear low signal and a high signal surrounding it were visible. Notably, the lesion was not suppressed by short TI inversion recovery. A gradual enhancement of the lesion was detected in the contrast-enhanced MRI. These results raised concerns about a potential malignant bone tumor at the right supra-acetabulum. 

After being referred to our department, the patient underwent blood tests for a differential diagnosis to consider the possibility of bone metastasis from carcinoma or secondary osteoporosis. The blood results were normal with no signs of inflammation, electrolyte imbalance, abnormal thyroid hormones, or tumor markers. 

Nuclear examinations were performed to differentiate between benign or malignant conditions and to screen for other bone lesions. Both bone scintigram and positron emission tomography highlighted accumulation in the right supra-acetabulum. The latter showed a standardized uptake value (SUV)max3.5 in the right supra-acetabulum. 

Differential diagnoses included a primary malignant bone tumor such as osteosarcoma, a right supra-acetabular metastasis, and a right supra-acetabular incomplete fracture (IF). To confirm the diagnosis, a bone biopsy was performed. The CT-guided needle biopsy did not reveal any tumor cells. Rather, it showed the formation of osteoids and the infiltration of inflammatory cells, indicative of a healing process following a fracture.

Follow-up imaging was conducted to screen the patient for osteoporosis. The L2–L4% young adult mean (YAM) was 66% (normal value ≥ 80%), suggesting the presence of osteoporosis. Blood test results corroborated this diagnosis with an alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level at 558 IU/L (normal value 50–350), and the total type I procollagen N-terminal propeptide (totalP1NP) was 115 µg/L (normal value 18.1–74.1). These results were consistent with a healing fracture.

Throughout the course of the patient's treatment and observation, no adverse or unanticipated event occurred.
model_response:
DX: Right supra-acetabular incomplete fracture (IF)

The diagnosis is supported by the CT-guided needle biopsy, which showed the formation of osteoids and infiltration of inflammatory cells, indicative of a healing process following a fracture. Additionally, the blood test results, including alkaline phosphatase and total type I procollagen N-terminal propeptide, were consistent with a healing fracture.

original_case: A 15-year-old white Latin American female patient underwent contrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for outpatient investigation of persistent pelvic pain. In a recent emergency department (ED) visit for the same complaint, a normal urinalysis was obtained. Her past medical history was unremarkable, and she did not take any medications and denied alcohol, tobacco, or any drug abuse. Few minutes after receiving gadolinium during MRI, she presented to the ED with shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, nausea, and vomiting. Upon admission, she had a brief period of loss of consciousness and her vital signs were as follows: blood pressure (BP), 84/40 mmHg; temperature, 36.4 °C; heart rate (HR), 122 beats per minute; respiratory rate (RR), 30 breaths per minute, and peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 78%. Her pulmonary auscultation revealed bilateral rales, but she did not have rash, or tongue or lip swelling. Despite significant hypoxemia, she was able to speak in whole sentences, and inhaled oxygen was delivered through a non-rebreather mask (NRBM) at 10 L per minute. She immediately received 500 mg of hydrocortisone and a 1 L bolus of intravenous crystalloids, but epinephrine was not administered upon the patient’s presentation. Also, antimicrobial therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin was initiated. Laboratory tests demonstrated a hemoglobin level of 18.6 g/dL, a slightly elevated white blood cell count (15,360/mm3, normal 4000–11,000/mm3), an increased C-reactive protein (CRP) concentration (41.8 mg/L, normal: < 0.5 mg/L), a lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level of 176 U/L (normal 135–214 U/L), and a d-dimer concentration of 1.7 mg/mL (normal: < 0.5 mg/mL). B-type natriuretic peptide and troponin levels were low, and the echocardiogram was normal. A chest computed tomography (CT) was performed around 1 hour after GBCA administration and showed bilateral pulmonary compromise secondary to multiple confluent consolidations located mainly in the posterior aspects of the lower lobes. There were also regions of ground-glass opacities that were more evident in the upper lobes along with diffuse thickening of interalveolar septa . A CT pulmonary angiography ruled out the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. A severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) nasopharyngeal swab testing came back negative. Fig. 1 Chest computed tomography (CT) showing bilateral multiple confluent consolidations located mainly in the posterior aspects of the lower lobes associated with regions of ground-glass opacities in the upper lobes and diffuse thickening of interalveolar septa Full size image She was then transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) with improved vital signs: BP, 119/71 mmHg, HR, 122 beats per minute, and SpO2 of 93%. Due to high oxygen requirement, methylprednisolone 1 mg/kg was prescribed and she was commenced on bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) ventilation and high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC). The patient showed substantial improvement over the following 12 hours, which enabled her to be weaned off noninvasive ventilatory support. She was afebrile during the entire hospital stay. She was discharged from ICU on day 2 receiving inhaled oxygen via nasal cannula at 1 L per minute and discharged home on day 3, with SpO2 of 98% on room air. Owing to the patient’s rapid recovery after supportive treatment and the absence of clinical evidence of infection, the decision to cease antibiotic therapy was made. Corticosteroid treatment was tapered down slowly over 30 days after discharge. Six months after initial presentation, the patient remained well and the follow-up was uneventful.
