original_case: A 45-year-old Japanese woman was referred to our department due to a severe headache. Twenty-one years prior, she was diagnosed with left clavicle ES and underwent surgical tumor excision. Preoperative and postoperative chemotherapy, consisting of vincristine, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, ifosfamide and etoposide were respectively administered. The patient also had a history of left breast cancer, treated with pectoral muscle-sparing mastectomy. Preoperative and postoperative chemotherapy, consisting of docetaxel, pertuzumab, trastuzumab, fluorouracil, epirubicin, and cyclophosphamide, were respectively administered 2 years prior. On admission, the patient presented with a headache, but no neurological findings were noted. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the brain showed a tumor extending superiorly and inferiorly from the cerebellar tent, along the left occipital bone with a contrast enhancement effect (Fig. 1 a, b). Osteolytic changes were observed in the left occipital bone . Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain revealed the tumor, exhibiting an isodense signal intensity on T1-weighted  and T2-weighted imaging . No signal was noted in the left transverse sinus on magnetic resonance venography. This suggested occlusion due to tumor invasion . The tumor extended to the left mastoid air cells. On 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose-positron emission tomography (18F-FDG PET), the tumor exhibited a low uptake . No high uptake regions were observed throughout the entire body . Fig. 1 Precontrast head computed tomography (CT) shows a high-density lesion bordering the left occipital bone (a), and the contrast-enhanced head CT shows a contrast enhancement effect (b). Osteolytic changes are also observed in the left occipital bone (c). On the head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), the lesion exhibits isodense signal intensity on T1-weighted imaging (d) and T2-weighted imaging (e). Magnetic resonance venography shows no signal in the left transverse sinus (f). 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (18F-FDG) positron emission tomography-CT reveals low 18F-FDG uptake in the tumor (g) and no abnormally high uptake throughout the body (h) Full size image Following admission, a small craniotomy and biopsy were performed to confirm the pathological diagnosis. Pathological examination showed small round cells with scanty cytoplasm on hematoxylin–eosin staining . CD99 immunohistochemistry showed strong membranous staining among the tumor cells . Periodic acid-Schiff detected small positive granules in the cytoplasm . A craniotomy and subtotal tumor excision were performed the following day. After the subtotal removal of the tumor, her headache improved. Fig. 2 Hematoxylin–eosin staining shows small round cells with little cytoplasm (a ×200). Immunohistochemical staining shows a membranous expression of CD99 (b ×200). Periodic acid-Schiff staining detected small positive granules (c ×200). Ki-67 staining shows that the MIB-1 index is about 30% (d × 200) Full size image During the craniotomy, a yellowish-white neoplastic lesion was observed in the epidural space across the transverse sinus . A portion of the tumor infiltrated the dura and extended to the surface of the brain. The tumor was removed as completely as possible, and the left transverse sinus was resected. However, the tumors in the left mastoid air cells and left sigmoid sinus could not be excised. Postoperatively, intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) at 61.2 Gy was administered in 34 fractions. Head MRI after IMRT showed a small residual tumor (Fig. 3 b, c). Fig. 3 Craniotomy was performed across the transverse sinus. A yellowish-white tumor (asterisk) was observed in the epidural space (a). Head MRI after intensity-modulated radiation therapy shows the residual tumor in the left mastoid air cells and sigmoid sinus; however, it is smaller than that before radiotherapy (b, c) Full size image
rewritten_case:
A Japanese woman of middle age came to our department complaining of a severe headache. Many years earlier, she had been diagnosed with Ewing's sarcoma (ES) in the left clavicle, followed by surgical tumor excision. Her treatment regimen consisted of preoperative and postoperative chemotherapy, using vincristine, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, ifosfamide, and etoposide.

She also had a history of left breast cancer, treated with a pectoral muscle-sparing mastectomy. The breast cancer treatment involved a regimen of preoperative and postoperative chemotherapy, with docetaxel, pertuzumab, trastuzumab, fluorouracil, epirubicin, and cyclophosphamide. 

Upon admission, the patient reported a headache. However, no other neurological symptoms were observed. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the brain revealed a tumor extending from the cerebellar tent, both superiorly and inferiorly, along the left occipital bone with a contrast enhancement effect. Osteolytic changes were noted in the left occipital bone. 

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain exhibited the tumor, showing an isodense signal intensity on T1-weighted and T2-weighted imaging. The absence of a signal in the left transverse sinus on magnetic resonance venography suggested occlusion due to tumor invasion. The tumor was also seen extending to the left mastoid air cells. 

On 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose-positron emission tomography (18F-FDG PET), the tumor exhibited low uptake, with no high uptake regions observed throughout the entire body. 

Following admission, a small craniotomy and biopsy were conducted for a pathological diagnosis. Pathological examination revealed small round cells with scanty cytoplasm, strong membranous staining among the tumor cells on CD99 immunohistochemistry, and small positive granules in the cytoplasm detected by Periodic acid-Schiff. 

A craniotomy and subtotal tumor excision were subsequently performed. The patient's headache improved following the partial removal of the tumor. 

During the craniotomy, a yellowish-white neoplastic lesion was seen in the epidural space across the transverse sinus. The tumor had infiltrated a portion of the dura and extended to the surface of the brain. The tumor was removed as completely as possible, with the left transverse sinus also resected. However, the tumors in the left mastoid air cells and left sigmoid sinus could not be excised. 

Postoperatively, the patient underwent intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) at 61.2 Gy in 34 fractions. A head MRI after IMRT showed a small residual tumor.
model_response:
DX: Meningeal sarcoma

The patient's history of Ewing's sarcoma and breast cancer, along with the presence of small round cells with scanty cytoplasm and strong membranous staining on CD99 immunohistochemistry, suggests a diagnosis of meningeal sarcoma, a rare type of cancer that originates in the meninges, the protective membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. The tumor's location, extending from the cerebellar tent to the left occipital bone, and its infiltration of the dura and brain surface, also support this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: Predicted label differs, but true dx mentioned elsewhere in output.

original_case: The patient was an 8-year-old, previously healthy, and fully immunized Iranian girl who was initially presented to the pediatric emergency department with 5 days of intermittent fever, followed by abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She had not attended school within the last 6 months and was cared for by her parents. She was an active child, but staying home most of the time because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Her parents had signs and symptoms compatible with mild upper respiratory tract infection since 1 week before. She had recently received oral antibiotic and intravenous serum as outpatient care. She was admitted with fever and abdominal pain in the surgery service of Akbar Hospital with suspected appendicitis. Nausea and vomiting persisted. According to normal sonography findings and persistent symptoms and emergence of rash and conjunctivitis, she was referred to the pediatric COVID-19 ward. She did not have cough, congestion, or rhinorrhea. After the third day, she received co-trimoxazole and ondansetron. Physical examination revealed bilateral nonpurulent conjunctivitis, erythematous throat, palmar erythema, strawberry tongue, and erythema multiform rash  without hypotension. There was no lymphadenopathy or retraction breathing, with normal respiratory sounds. There were no focal signs of infection. On cardiac examination, there was an II/VI murmur on the left sternal border. According to fever (38.6 °C) and pandemic state of COVID-19, she underwent lung high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT), which was not indicative for COVID-19 infection. Laboratory evaluation included urinalysis with urine culture, all with negative results. On laboratory examination, ESR was 67 mm/h, CRP 166 mg/L, platelets 192 × 10^9/L, hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL and WBC 10.3×10^9/L (PMN: 82%). Moreover, other routine biochemistry and liver function tests yielded normal findings. Fig. 1 Nonpurulent conjunctivitis, Strawberry tongue, palmar rash Full size image She received IVIG (2 g/kg; 1 g/kg on two consecutive days) and high-dose acetylsalicylic acid (20 mg/kg four times daily) according to rheumatology consultation. Echocardiography showed no pathology related to coronary arteries. Besides, respiratory tract viral infections were evaluated by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test for COVID-19 and blood culture, all with negative results. There was no history of recent travel. Nonetheless, her parents had flu-like symptoms along with hypogeusia and anosmia. She was hospitalized for 5 days. The day before discharge, serologic tests for COVID-19 infection in her parents (serum IgM more than 1.1) and the child herself became positive (serum IgM COVID-19 of 2.1). Consequently, the public health department was notified, and the family was instructed to quarantine at home for 14 days from the positive test result date.
rewritten_case:
The subject of our case is a vibrant, 8-year-old Iranian girl, who had been maintaining good health and was up-to-date on all her immunizations. She had been largely home-bound over the past six months, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and had not been attending school. Her parents, who were her primary caregivers, had been experiencing symptoms consistent with a mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past week. The girl's health began to deteriorate when she started displaying intermittent fever that lasted for 5 days. This was followed by abdominal discomfort, nausea, and vomiting. As an outpatient, she had recently been given oral antibiotics and intravenous serum.

Admitted to the surgery service of Akbar Hospital, her symptoms of fever and abdominal pain led to an initial suspicion of appendicitis. However, despite normal sonography findings, and the persistence of her symptoms, including the emergence of a rash and conjunctivitis, she was referred to the pediatric COVID-19 ward. She was not displaying any symptoms of cough, congestion, or rhinorrhea. By the third day of her hospitalization, she was administered co-trimoxazole and ondansetron.

A physical examination revealed bilateral nonpurulent conjunctivitis, an erythematous throat, palmar erythema, strawberry tongue, and an erythema multiform rash. There was no evidence of hypotension, lymphadenopathy or retraction breathing, and her respiratory sounds were normal. On cardiac examination, a grade II/VI murmur was detected on the left sternal border. 

Considering her persistent fever, measured at 38.6 °C, and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, she underwent a lung high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT), which did not reveal signs of COVID-19 infection. Laboratory tests including urinalysis with urine culture were conducted, with all returning negative results. Her ESR was measured at 67 mm/h, CRP at 166 mg/L, platelets at 192 × 10^9/L, hemoglobin at 10.2 g/dL and WBC at 10.3×10^9/L (PMN: 82%). Routine biochemistry and liver function tests were within normal ranges.

Intriguingly, an ophthalmologic examination pointed out signs of bilateral posterior uveitis, which could be consistent with Harada's disease. She was treated with IVIG (2 g/kg; 1 g/kg on two consecutive days) and high-dose acetylsalicylic acid (20 mg/kg four times daily) as per rheumatology consultation. Echocardiography did not reveal any coronary artery anomalies. Tests for respiratory tract viral infections, including RT-PCR for COVID-19 and blood culture, were conducted and returned negative results.

The girl had no recent travel history. However, her parents had flu-like symptoms, along with hypogeusia and anosmia. After a hospital stay of 5 days, serologic tests for COVID-19 infection in her parents (serum IgM more than 1.1) and the child herself turned out positive (serum IgM COVID-19 of 2.1). Following this, the public health department was informed and the family was advised to quarantine at home for 14 days from the date of the positive test result.
model_response:
DX: COVID-19-associated Kawasaki disease

The patient's symptoms, including fever, abdominal pain, rash, and conjunctivitis, are consistent with Kawasaki disease. The presence of bilateral posterior uveitis and the patient's age, which is within the typical range for Kawasaki disease, further support this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: Predicted label differs, but true dx mentioned elsewhere in output.

original_case: A 9-year-old African-American male with a history of steroid-dependent NS presented to the nephrology clinic for routine follow-up care in September 2018. He had been diagnosed with NS at 4 years of age, and had multiple relapses and hospitalizations for management of his disease. He was up-to-date with all his immunizations, including vaccination for S. pneumoniae; he had received PCV7 as the initial series and a booster of PCV13. He was receiving mycophenolate mofetil 200 mg twice a day for about 6 months and prednisone 30 mg on alternate days for about 1 month. The child’s only complaint was neck pain and stiffness that had begun 1–2 days prior to presentation. His mother attributed the neck pain to muscle tightness and stated that massages to the area provided some pain relief. There was no history of recent illness, fever, nausea, vomiting, photophobia, headache, seizures, or altered mental status. On physical examination, he was afebrile and had mild periorbital swelling and edema on lower extremities. He appeared ill, exhibited neck rigidity, and revealed reflex knee flexion on neck flexion. He was transferred to the emergency department (ED) for further evaluation and management. On admission to the ED, his temperature was 99 °F, heart rate 112 beats per minute, respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute, blood pressure 101/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. The child persisted with neck stiffness, and roughly 7 hours after presenting to the ED, he developed fever (102 °F). At this time, a lumbar puncture was performed to rule out meningitis. Laboratory evaluation showed mild anemia, leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance, hyponatremia, elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), and an elevated sedimentary rate. Cerebrospinal results demonstrated pleocytosis, with very decreased glucose level. Laboratory findings are summarized in . The patient was started on ceftriaxone 100 mg/kg/day and vancomycin 15 mg/kg/day, and was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) for close cardiopulmonary monitoring and further management. By the second day of hospitalization, both cerebrospinal and blood cultures grew S. pneumoniae, which was pansensitive, including to ceftriaxone. Vancomycin was discontinued and the child remained on ceftriaxone monotherapy at 100 mg/kg. He was restarted on daily steroid therapy to attain remission of the NS. While in the PICU, the patient developed persistent hypertension and was treated with enalapril 5 mg twice a day. Amlodipine 5 mg once a day was added later as a second antihypertensive to further optimize blood pressure (BP) control. The child was transferred to the inpatient ward where he completed a 2-week course of ceftriaxone with no complications. His overall edema improved, and his BP was controlled on two antihypertensive drugs.
rewritten_case: A 9-year-old African-American male patient with a background of steroid-dependent Nephrotic Syndrome (NS) arrived at the nephrology clinic for routine follow-up care in September 2018. He had been living with NS since he was 4, and his medical history included numerous relapses and hospital admissions for disease management. He had received his full suite of immunizations, inclusive of the S. pneumoniae vaccine, with PCV7 as the initial series and a booster of PCV13. His current treatment regimen included mycophenolate mofetil 200 mg twice daily for approximately 6 months and prednisone 30 mg every other day for about 1 month. The primary concern voiced by the child was a neck pain and stiffness that had developed 1–2 days earlier. His mother believed the neck pain to be due to muscle tension and stated that massaging the area offered some relief. No recent illnesses, fever, nausea, vomiting, photophobia, headache, seizures, or altered mental status were reported. Upon physical examination, the boy was found to be afebrile, with mild periorbital swelling and edema on the lower extremities. The child seemed unwell, exhibited neck rigidity and showed reflex knee flexion on neck flexion. Due to his symptoms, he was transferred to the emergency department (ED) for further assessment and treatment. Upon his admission to the ED, his vital signs were recorded as: temperature 99 °F, heart rate 112 bpm, respiratory rate 22 bpm, blood pressure 101/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. The boy continued to exhibit neck stiffness, and approximately 7 hours post-admission to the ED, he developed a fever of 102 °F. Given the symptoms, a lumbar puncture was performed to rule out meningitis. Laboratory results demonstrated mild anemia, leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance, hyponatremia, elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), and an increased sedimentary rate. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) results indicated pleocytosis, with a significantly reduced glucose level, suggestive of pneumococcal meningitis. The patient was started on ceftriaxone 100 mg/kg/day and vancomycin 15 mg/kg/day, and was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) for close cardiopulmonary monitoring. Within two days of hospitalization, both CSF and blood cultures revealed the presence of S. pneumoniae, which was pansensitive, including to ceftriaxone. The antibiotic treatment was adjusted, discontinuing vancomycin and maintaining the child on ceftriaxone monotherapy at 100 mg/kg. Steroid therapy was resumed to manage the NS. During his stay in the PICU, the patient developed consistent hypertension, which was managed with enalapril 5 mg twice daily. Amlodipine 5 mg once daily was later added to further control his blood pressure. The child was then transferred to the inpatient ward where he successfully completed a 2-week course of ceftriaxone without complications. His edema improved significantly, and his blood pressure was effectively managed with the two antihypertensive medications.
model_response:
DX: Pneumococcal Meningitis

The patient's symptoms, including neck stiffness, fever, and pleocytosis in the cerebrospinal fluid, are consistent with pneumococcal meningitis. Additionally, the presence of S. pneumoniae in both blood and cerebrospinal fluid cultures supports this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: Exact/normalized match to distractor alias.

original_case: A 46-year-old East Asian male with a history of Crohn’s disease (diagnosed in November 2018 with duodenitis, duodenal ulcers, ileitis, and colitis with crypt abscess) reported to have no psychosocial disorder nor significant family history. He was treated with immunomodulators including an initial treatment of azathioprine 50 mg and prednisolone 15 mg twice daily, and mesalazine. Owing to remission of the clinical symptoms of Crohn’s disease, prednisolone was gradually tapered off; prednisone use covered a total period of 3 months. Following 4 months of azathioprine and 3 months of prednisolone use, the patient complained of persistent abdominal pain and diarrhea. Endoscopy in March 2019 revealed scarring in the colon and terminal ileum. Furthermore, inflammatory polypoid lesions were noted in the terminal ileum that were not present in a previous examination . Results of a biopsy revealed that spindle cells were arranged in intersecting fascicles with intervening slit-like vascular spaces containing erythrocytes located in the submucosal layer. Immunohistochemistry revealed immunoreactivity for CD34, smooth muscle actin (SMA), and HHV-8. Stainings for CD117, DOG1, and cytomegalovirus were all negative . These findings supported a diagnosis and excluded a diagnosis of gastrointestinal stromal tumor. Fig. 1 Endoscopy showed polypoid lesion of the terminal ileum. Biopsy of the polypoid tumor and histopathology identified a condition. Full size image Fig. 2 Histopathology of the condition in the terminal ileum. Spindle cells were arranged in intersecting fascicles with intervening slit-like vascular spaces containing erythrocytes located in the submucosal layer. A Fascicles of spindle cells (short arrow) and extravasated erythrocytes (long arrow) on Hematoxylin and Eosin stain (× 400). B Spindle cells on Hematoxylin and Eosin stain (× 1000). C Immunohistochemical staining for CD 34 was positive (× 400). D Immunohistochemical staining for HHV-8 was positive (× 400) Full size image The patient was tested for HIV, hepatitis C virus, and herpes simplex virus, with negative results. Physical examination revealed no cutaneous manifestations. Small bowel series indicated multiple smooth-surface round filling defects throughout the jejunum to the ileum, compatible with intraluminal polypoid tumors . Abdominal computed tomography (CT) revealed diffuse edematous change of the gastrointestinal tract and multiple nodular lesions in the small bowel . Therefore, we reduced administration of azathioprine 50 mg from twice to once daily and reintroduced prednisolone to control the symptoms of Crohn’s disease. Fig. 3 Small bowel series indicated (A) Multiple smooth-surface round filling defects throughout the jejunum to the ileum (arrows) (B) Multiple smooth-surface round filling defects over the ileum, compatible with polypoid tumors (arrows) Full size image Fig. 4 Abdominal CT scan revealed diffuse edematous change of gastrointestinal tract and multiple hyperdense nodular lesions in the small bowel (arrows) Full size image The oncologist began chemotherapy with eight courses of epirubicin 100 mg. After 6 months, endoscopy and CT revealed complete remission of the condition, and the symptoms of Crohn’s disease were stable. During chemotherapy, doses of the aforementioned immunomodulators were kept constant, and doses of prednisolone were adjusted ranged from 2.5 mg twice daily to 10 mg twice daily according to variations in the clinical activity of the patient’s Crohn’s disease. Following chemotherapy, the patient was monitored with CT every 4 months in the first year and every 6 months in subsequent years. Magnetic resonance (MR) enterography and endoscopy were used when symptoms of Crohn’s disease flared up.
rewritten_case:
An East Asian male in his mid-forties with a history of Crohn’s disease (characterized previously by duodenitis, duodenal ulcers, ileitis, and colitis with crypt abscess) presented with no psychosocial disorder nor significant family history. His treatment involved immunomodulators, specifically an initial regimen of azathioprine 50 mg and prednisolone 15 mg twice daily, and mesalazine. Prednisolone was eventually tapered off once remission of the clinical symptoms of Crohn’s disease was achieved; prednisone use spanned an unspecified period. 

Following an indefinite period of azathioprine and prednisolone use, the patient experienced persistent abdominal pain and diarrhea. An endoscopy was performed, which revealed scarring in the colon and terminal ileum. Notably, inflammatory polypoid lesions were observed in the terminal ileum, which had not been present in an earlier examination. 

Biopsy results indicated spindle cells arranged in intersecting fascicles with intervening slit-like vascular spaces containing erythrocytes located in the submucosal layer. Immunohistochemistry showed immunoreactivity for CD34, smooth muscle actin (SMA), and HHV-8. Stainings for CD117, DOG1, and cytomegalovirus were all negative. These findings led to a diagnosis while excluding a gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

The patient underwent testing for HIV, hepatitis C virus, and herpes simplex virus, all of which yielded negative results. A physical examination revealed no cutaneous manifestations. A small bowel series indicated multiple smooth-surface round filling defects from the jejunum to the ileum, hinting at intraluminal polypoid tumors. An abdominal computed tomography (CT) revealed diffuse edematous changes of the gastrointestinal tract and multiple nodular lesions in the small bowel. As a response, the administration of azathioprine 50 mg was reduced from twice to once daily and prednisolone was reintroduced to control the symptoms of Crohn’s disease.

The patient underwent chemotherapy with an unspecified number of courses of epirubicin 100 mg. Following this period, endoscopy and CT revealed complete remission of the condition, and the symptoms of Crohn’s disease remained stable. During chemotherapy, doses of the aforementioned immunomodulators were kept constant, and doses of prednisolone were adjusted according to variations in the clinical activity of the patient’s Crohn’s disease. After chemotherapy, the patient was routinely monitored with CT, MR enterography, and endoscopy used when symptoms of Crohn’s disease flared up.
model_response:
DX: Gastrointestinal lymphomatosis

The patient's presentation with persistent abdominal pain and diarrhea, along with the endoscopic and biopsy findings of spindle cells with immunoreactivity for CD34, SMA, and HHV-8, are consistent with a diagnosis of gastrointestinal lymphomatosis. The presence of inflammatory polypoid lesions and nodular lesions in the small bowel, as well as the patient's history of Crohn's disease and immunomodulator use, support this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: No reliable alias or fuzzy match; no clear mentions.

original_case: A 35-year-old Brazilian man with HIV for 10 years who was non-adherent to ART (lamivudine + abacavir + dolutegravir) was admitted with a history of successfully treated histoplasmosis. He had been hospitalized for 1 month at a public hospital in Natal, Brazil, with initial symptoms of intense diarrhea, daily fevers, sweating, and chills for 3 weeks. He was diagnosed with disseminated TB, and tuberculostatic treatment (isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol, streptomycin, and pyrazinamide) was given for 10 days. However, due to increased transaminase levels, his regimen was changed to levofloxacin, capreomycin, and ethambutol. He was observed for 10 days and discharged. Thirteen days after discharge, he was admitted to the referral health service in Recife, Brazil, with a worsening of his clinical condition characterized by fever, dyspnea, pain in the upper and lower limbs and spine, and cough. Prophylactic treatment with sulfamethoxazole + trimethoprim + piperacillin/tazobactam was initiated. Lymphocyte counts showed that patient was severely immunocompromised, with a CD4 count of 8 cells/mL, CD8 count of 347 cells/mL, and CD4/CD8 ratio of 0.02. A high viral load was detected (174,034 copies). Several laboratory tests were requested, including fungal investigations because of his history of histoplasmosis 2 years prior and the finding of several whitish plaques in his oral cavity . Blood culture, bronchoalveolar lavage, and oral secretions were obtained. The samples were sent to the Laboratory of Diagnostic in Tropical Diseases at the Federal University of Pernambuco, and slides were made for direct examination (Fig. 1b, c) to visualize fungal structures. Spherical yeast cells were observed in large numbers. Fig. 1a White-yellowish plaques on the tongue. b, c Direct mycological examination of the oral secretion showing hyaline yeast cells without dye (b) stained with methylene blue (c) (magnification: ×400). d–f Thickened pericardium with areas of hyperechogenicity in the left ventricular wall and absence of pericardial effusion Full size image Each biological sample was cultured on Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (Difco, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) + chloramphenicol in duplicate, and the plates were maintained at 28 °C and 37 °C. There was rapid growth with sporulation after 3 days of culture. Yeasts were identified using the VITEK® 2 automated microbial identification system (bioMérieux SA, Marcy-l'Étoile, France) and matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight–mass spectrometry according to Lima-Neto et al. [11]. Both methods identified Candida tropicalis. In vitro antifungal susceptibility tests were performed according to the protocol described in the 2008 Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) document M27-A3 [12] and using the VITEK® 2 system with the AST YS01 card; both tests confirmed the identification. Candida tropicalis isolates showed resistance to fluconazole and voriconazole, for which the minimal inhibitory concentrations (MIC) were 64 and 16 µg/mL, respectively; the MICs for anidulafungin, caspofungin, micafungin, and amphotericin B were 0.125, 0.03, 0.125, and 0.25 µg/mL, respectively. The patient was diagnosed with esophagitis. Treatment with amphotericin B deoxycholate and itraconazole with a maintenance dose was instituted. After 12 days of hospitalization, the patient developed sepsis from a pulmonary focus and his respiratory status worsened, leading to nasal intermittent mandatory ventilation. Meropenem and vancomycin were started, and itraconazole (400 mg/day) was maintained. Laboratory tests showed significant pancytopenia. Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed pericardial thickening, a sequelae of tuberculous pericarditis (Fig. 1d–f). Two days after the end of antibiotic therapy, the patient developed new fever peaks, and the medical staff chose to prolong the medication for another 10 days. Simultaneously, herpetic lesions in the genital region appeared, and acyclovir (750 mg/d) was initiated. A modified ART regimen (tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir) and tuberculostatic (COXCIP-4) therapy was given. The patient improved clinically and was stable for discharge after 30 days of hospitalization with appropriate clinical follow-up.
rewritten_case:
A 35-year-old man from Brazil, known to be HIV positive for over a decade, was brought to a public hospital in Natal, Brazil, with severe symptoms including intense diarrhea, daily fevers, sweating, and chills. His adherence to ART (lamivudine + abacavir + dolutegravir) was inconsistent. He also had a history of histoplasmosis, which had been successfully treated in the past.

Upon admission, the patient was diagnosed with disseminated TB, and tuberculostatic treatment (isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol, streptomycin, and pyrazinamide) was initiated. However, the regimen had to be altered to levofloxacin, capreomycin, and ethambutol because of elevated transaminase levels. After a period of observation, the patient was discharged.

The patient was later readmitted to a referral health service in Recife, Brazil, due to a deterioration in his clinical condition. He presented with fever, dyspnea, pain in the upper and lower limbs and spine, and a cough. Prophylactic treatment with sulfamethoxazole + trimethoprim + piperacillin/tazobactam was initiated. Laboratory tests revealed severe immunocompromise, with a CD4 count of 8 cells/mL, CD8 count of 347 cells/mL, and CD4/CD8 ratio of 0.02. A high viral load was also detected (174,034 copies).

Given his history of histoplasmosis and the discovery of multiple whitish plaques in his oral cavity, fungal investigations were initiated. Samples from blood culture, bronchoalveolar lavage, and oral secretions were obtained and sent to the Laboratory of Diagnostic in Tropical Diseases at the Federal University of Pernambuco for examination and culture. The samples showed numerous spherical yeast cells, and the cultures revealed rapid growth with sporulation. Both the VITEK® 2 automated microbial identification system and matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight–mass spectrometry identified Candida tropicalis. The Candida tropicalis isolates exhibited resistance to fluconazole and voriconazole, and the patient was diagnosed with esophagitis.

The patient was prescribed amphotericin B deoxycholate and itraconazole, but his condition worsened as he developed sepsis from a pulmonary focus, leading to respiratory complications. Meropenem and vancomycin were added to his treatment regimen, and itraconazole was continued. Further laboratory tests revealed significant pancytopenia. An echocardiogram showed pericardial thickening, a remnant of his past tuberculous pericarditis.

Despite completing the antibiotic course, the patient continued to have fever spikes, and his medication was extended. He also developed herpetic lesions in the genital region, for which acyclovir was initiated. His ART regimen was modified to tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir, and tuberculostatic (COXCIP-4) therapy was administered. Over an unspecified period, the patient's condition improved, and he was eventually stable enough for discharge with appropriate clinical follow-up.
model_response:
DX: Disseminated candidiasis

The patient's severe immunocompromise, as evidenced by a CD4 count of 8 cells/mL and a high viral load, makes him susceptible to opportunistic infections. The presence of whitish plaques in his oral cavity and the isolation of Candida tropicalis from multiple samples, including blood culture, bronchoalveolar lavage, and oral secretions, strongly suggests disseminated candidiasis.
adjudication_notes: No alias match, but distractor mentioned in output.

original_case: A 67-year-old Asian woman, who was a nonsmoker, presented to our hospital with a complaint of prolonged dry cough for 2 months. The patient also had dyspnea in the supine position, night sweats, and mild appetite loss for 1 month, but no complaints of any gastrointestinal symptoms. She was diagnosed with UC at the age of 29 years with bloody diarrhea, had been in long-term remission for over 35 years, and was taking salazosulfapyridine (1000–1500 mg/day) orally. She had no history of occupational dust exposure, but had a family history of pulmonary tuberculosis. On physical examination, her vital signs were as follows: temperature, 36.4 °C; heart rate, 99 beats per minute; blood pressure, 136/74 mmHg; respiratory rate, 16 breaths per minute; and oxygen saturation on room air, 98%. Auscultation of the neck and chest revealed normal breath sounds, without adventitious sounds. The rest of the physical examination, including the outer ear, nose, and joints, was normal. Blood analysis revealed elevated C-reactive protein (CRP; 10.71 mg/dL) and increased levels of leucine-rich α-2-glycoprotein (LRG; 44.2 μg/mL, normal < 16.0 μg/mL), a new biomarker for evaluating disease activity in patients with UC. Tumor markers, proteinase-3 anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, soluble interleukin (IL)-2 receptor, and angiotensin-converting enzyme were within normal limits, and T-SPOT.TB (an interferon-γ release assay) was negative. Chest radiography revealed narrowing of the trachea  compared with the previous year . Chest computed tomography (CT) demonstrated circumferential thickening of the tracheal wall, ranging from the trachea to the bilateral main bronchi , without lung parenchymal abnormalities. Pulmonary function tests showed a forced vital capacity of 2.81 L [114.5% of the predicted volume (pred)], forced expiratory volume in 1 second of 2.06 L (101.5% pred), and decreased peak expiratory flow of 3.11 L per second (53.3% pred). A flow–volume loop graph at the first visit revealed fixed upper airway obstruction . Fig. 1 Chest X-rays obtained at the first visit (A) and 1 year before the first visit (B), respectively. Chest X-ray at the first visit (A) showing narrowing of the trachea compared with that from a year earlier (B). C Chest computed tomography image showing circumferential thickening of the tracheal wall. D Flow–volume loop graph demonstrating fixed upper airway obstruction Full size image Her symptoms were unresponsive to treatment with oral levofloxacin (500 mg/day) or inhaled fluticasone furoate (100 μg/day)/vilanterol trifenatate (25 μg/day) administered for 1 week. Bronchoscopy performed to investigate extensive large airway disease revealed widespread edema with erythema and diffuse concentric narrowing of the bronchial lumen from the trachea to the bilateral segmental bronchi ; however, neither swelling nor paralysis of the vocal cord could be confirmed. Dynamic collapse of the central airway was not observed during respiration. Mucosal biopsy specimens revealed marked submucosal lymphocytic infiltration . No evidence of infection, malignancy, vasculitis, or amyloidosis was found. Fig. 2 A Bronchoscopic examination showing diffuse narrowing of the trachea with inflamed erythematous mucosa. B Photomicrograph of endotracheal mucosal biopsy specimen showing intense submucosal infiltration. The inset within B is a magnified view of lymphocytic infiltration. Scale bar, 20 μm Full size image Fig. 3 Clinical course from initiation of corticosteroid therapy. Chest computed tomography images obtained at the first visit, 1.5-month follow-up, and 5-month follow-up show amelioration of bronchial wall thickening. CRP C-reactive protein, ESR erythrocyte sedimentation rate, PSL prednisolone Full size image
rewritten_case:
A 67-year-old, non-smoking Asian woman presented to our hospital with complaints of a persistent dry cough that had lasted for 2 months, along with dyspnea when lying down, night sweats, and a mild loss of appetite over the past month. She had no gastrointestinal symptoms. The patient had a history of UC, diagnosed when she was 29 years old, which had been in remission for more than three decades thanks to a daily oral salazosulfapyridine regimen (1000-1500 mg/day). The patient's family history included pulmonary tuberculosis, but she herself had no history of occupational dust exposure.

Upon physical examination, her vitals were as follows: 36.4°C temperature, heart rate of 99 bpm, blood pressure of 136/74 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. The neck and chest auscultation revealed normal breath sounds with no adventitious sounds. The rest of her physical examination was normal, including her outer ear, nose, and joints.

Bloodwork showed elevated C-reactive protein (CRP; 10.71 mg/dL) and increased levels of leucine-rich α-2-glycoprotein (LRG; 44.2 μg/mL, normal < 16.0 μg/mL), a biomarker for evaluating disease activity in UC patients. All other markers, including tumor markers, proteinase-3 anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, soluble interleukin (IL)-2 receptor, and angiotensin-converting enzyme, were within normal limits. The T-SPOT.TB test was negative. 

Chest X-rays showed tracheal narrowing compared to the previous year's X-rays. A chest CT scan revealed circumferential thickening of the tracheal wall, extending from the trachea to the bilateral main bronchi, with no lung parenchymal abnormalities. Pulmonary function tests revealed a forced vital capacity of 2.81 L (114.5% pred), a forced expiratory volume in one second of 2.06 L (101.5% pred), and a decreased peak expiratory flow of 3.11 L per second (53.3% pred). A flow-volume loop graph revealed a fixed upper airway obstruction. 

Despite a week of treatment with oral levofloxacin (500 mg/day) and inhaled fluticasone furoate (100 μg/day)/vilanterol trifenatate (25 μg/day), the patient's symptoms persisted. A bronchoscopy was performed, which revealed widespread edema with erythema and diffuse concentric narrowing of the bronchial lumen from the trachea to the bilateral segmental bronchi. No vocal cord swelling or paralysis could be confirmed. There was no dynamic collapse of the central airway during respiration. 

Mucosal biopsy specimens showed marked submucosal lymphocytic infiltration. There was no evidence of infection, malignancy, vasculitis, or amyloidosis. However, the bronchoscopy did reveal a significant amount of mucus accumulation, a finding that was consistent with acute tracheitis, potentially redirecting the diagnosis.
model_response:
DX: Tracheobronchitis associated with ulcerative colitis

The patient's persistent dry cough, dyspnea when lying down, and night sweats are consistent with tracheobronchitis, which is a common complication of ulcerative colitis. The presence of submucosal lymphocytic infiltration and marked mucus accumulation on bronchoscopy further support this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: No reliable alias or fuzzy match; no clear mentions.

original_case: A 44-year-old female living with HIV and on ART for the last 14 years, with a CD4 count of 338 cells/µL and viral load < 20 copies/mL presented to the hospital with a history of being unwell for a week. She had been put on abacavir, lamivudine, and dolutegravir 3 weeks before, as a routine switch from a TDF-based regimen. She had previously been on a regimen of TDF, 3TC, and efavirenz but had it changed because of the availability of a new formulation of ABC, 3TC, and DTG (Triumeq) that was deemed better by her primary physician. She reported a dry cough, sore throat, chest discomfort, and myalgia. She also reported a history of vomiting 3 days before the hospital visit. She was subject to fever and chills, was anorexic and nauseous. She also complained of occasional headaches, without neck stiffness or photophobia. She had been tested for malaria a couple of times a few days prior, but was persistently negative. At presentation, her blood pressure was 142/84 mmHg, heart rate 102 beats per minute, with temperature 36.1 °C and oxygen saturation at 94% on ambient air. On examination, she had an inflamed throat and posterior palate with tender tonsils to palpation, her chest was clear and the cardiovascular system examination was otherwise unremarkable. She also had tenderness to palpation of the limb muscles without evidence of arthritis. Remarkably, she had a white cell count of 2.6 × 10^9/L (73% granulocytes, 22% lymphocytes), hemoglobin of 14.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 122 × 10^9/L, but her kidney function tests were within normal. The rest of the laboratory results are outlined in Additional file 1: Table S1. She was admitted for intravenous rehydration and bed rest, with a presumption of a viral upper respiratory tract infection. However, the sore throat persisted despite the initial relief. On the second day of admission, she complained of generalized body ache. Laboratory results showed a significant increase in liver enzymes, thus prompting testing for viral hepatitis and repeat testing for malaria, which turned positive, and she was subsequently started on artesunate. The patient was advised to suspend her ART given the liver impairments. She responded well to treatment and the transaminases started to improve, although she kept complaining of myalgias and progressive body swelling with paresthesia in the lower limbs. She was discharged on the seventh day feeling better. She was, however, readmitted a day after discharge (ninth day since the first admission) complaining of an episode of severe headache followed by profuse sweating. She denied fever but reported that she had vomited six times that day and had three episodes of diarrhea with burning lower abdominal pains. Her blood pressure was 87/50 mmHg, heart rate 130 beats per minute, temperature 35.4 °C, and oxygen saturation at 88%. Apart from a tender epigastrium, systemic examination was otherwise unremarkable. She was started on rabeprazole, antibiotics to cover hospital acquired infection, and ondansetron. Unfortunately, cultures were not taken. She was also started on Ringer’s lactate. Significantly, her laboratory results showed features of acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine of 183 µmol/L. On the second day of this admission, she developed a rash in the extremities that spread to the trunk, she was started on cetirizine and mometasone cream. As her blood pressure improved, the kidney function improved. In addition, there was a notable improvement in the liver transaminases compared with previous tests. The rash also improved. She was discharged after 5 days (13 days after the initial admission). However, the patient was readmitted the night of the day of discharge, in a hysterical state with burning chest pain and chills. Her blood pressure was 108/67 mmHg, heart rate 153 beats per minute, temperature 34.2 °C, and oxygen saturation at 92% on room air. Systemic examination was unremarkable. There was no notable rash at this time. A bedside electrocardiogram was unremarkable apart from the extreme tachycardia and an arterial blood gas report consistent with respiratory alkalosis with lactate of 4.3 mmol/L. However, there was a highly elevated serum level of aspartate aminotransferase, lactate dehydrogenase, and potassium. On further interrogation, the patient revealed that she had taken the ABC-containing tablets shortly before she became unwell and she had vomited a while after that. It was also noted that the patient had been restarting her ART every time she was discharged, contrary to advice. The patient was managed supportively and showed marked improvement, although she still had peripheral neuropathy of the left lower limb requiring physiotherapy and the use of a crutch. On clinical suspicion, an HLA-B*57:01 test was requested. This proved positive and the patient was advised to completely stop the ABC/DTG/3TC regimen. She was discharged after a 2-day stay at the hospital. On follow-up, she did well. She presented 12 days later (27 days after the initial presentation) with severe headaches and episodes of confusion. A brain computed tomography (CT) scan and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan revealed a left posterior parietal tuberculoma. She was started on rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol for 2 months, and then rifampicin and isoniazid for 16 months (this was occasioned by persistent symptoms at 12 months and persistent but shrinking tuberculoma). She received a short course of dexamethasone at the beginning of this treatment. Two months after the initial presentation, her ART regimen was changed to a two-tablet regime consisting of DTG and a fixed-dose combination of emtricitabine plus TDF. This was occasioned by a rise in the HIV viral load with stable liver and kidney function test results while on antituberculous therapy. She made tremendous improvement overall, although she has persistent headaches 24 months after the first episode. The most recent CD4 count is 512 cells/µL and viral load is 22 copies/mL. The timeline of events is summarized in Fig. 1.
rewritten_case:
A 44-year-old female, who has been managing her HIV with ART for the past 14 years, presented to the hospital feeling unwell for the past week. Her recent CD4 count was 338 cells/µL and her viral load was under control at < 20 copies/mL. Three weeks prior, her treatment had been switched from a TDF-based regimen to abacavir, lamivudine, and dolutegravir, due to the availability of a new formulation (Triumeq) thought to be superior by her primary physician. 

The patient described a dry cough, sore throat, discomfort in the chest, and muscle pain. She also reported being nauseated, loss of appetite, and had been vomiting up to 3 days prior to the hospital visit. The patient denied experiencing neck stiffness or photophobia, but did report occasional headaches. Despite having tested negative for malaria multiple times in the days leading up to her hospital visit, she was experiencing fever and chills. 

Upon presentation, her blood pressure was 142/84 mmHg, heart rate was 102 beats per minute, body temperature was 36.1 °C and her oxygen saturation was 94% on room air. Physical examination revealed an inflamed throat and posterior palate with tender tonsils upon palpation. Her chest was clear and cardiovascular examination was unremarkable. There was tenderness upon palpation of her limb muscles, but no signs of arthritis. 

Notably, lab results showed a white cell count of 2.6 × 10^9/L (73% granulocytes, 22% lymphocytes), hemoglobin of 14.0 g/dL, and a platelet count of 122 × 10^9/L. Kidney function tests were within normal limits. The patient was admitted for intravenous rehydration and bed rest for suspected viral upper respiratory tract infection. However, her sore throat persisted and on the second day of admission, she began experiencing generalized body aches. 

An increase in liver enzymes prompted further testing for viral hepatitis and repeat testing for malaria. The malaria test returned positive this time, and she was started on artesunate. Due to the liver impairments, she was advised to suspend her ART. 

While her condition improved and liver enzymes began to normalize, she continued to complain of muscle aches and swelling in the body, particularly with paresthesia in the lower limbs. She was discharged on the seventh day, yet was readmitted the following day with severe headaches, nausea, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. 

Subsequent lab results revealed acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine of 183 µmol/L. Despite these complications, her condition improved over the next 5 days and she was discharged. However, she was readmitted again the same night in a hysterical state, complaining of chest pain and chills. 

Although her physical examination was unremarkable, lab tests showed highly elevated levels of aspartate aminotransferase, lactate dehydrogenase, and potassium. The patient admitted to restarting her ART each time she was discharged, despite medical advice. 

Considering her persistent symptoms and ART usage, an HLA-B*57:01 test was conducted, which returned positive, suggesting a hypersensitivity reaction to the abacavir component of her ART. She was advised to cease the ABC/DTG/3TC regimen. 

She presented 12 days later (27 days after the initial presentation) with severe headaches and episodes of confusion. Brain CT and MRI scans revealed a left posterior parietal tuberculoma. She was started on antituberculosis therapy and her ART regimen was subsequently changed to a two-tablet regime consisting of DTG and a fixed-dose combination of emtricitabine plus TDF. The patient's condition improved significantly, although she continues to experience headaches 24 months after the first episode
model_response:
DX: Abacavir hypersensitivity reaction

The patient's symptoms, including fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and muscle pain, are consistent with an allergic reaction to abacavir. The positive HLA-B*57:01 test result further supports this diagnosis, as it is a known risk factor for hypersensitivity reactions to abacavir.
target_distractor: Upper respiratory tract hypersensitivity reaction, site unspecified
adjudication_notes: Exact/normalized match to true dx alias.

original_case: A 57-year-old Chinese man who suffered from spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage following the rupture of a cerebral aneurysm underwent craniotomy evacuation of hematoma with general anesthesia and transoral intubation. No problems with swallowing or speaking were reported during the surgery. Unfortunately, the patient experienced dysarthria, dysphagia, and trouble with tongue movement after the surgery. Thus, we performed a detailed neurological examination. In addition to the symptoms described above, we also found symptoms linked to cranial nerve injuries, such as a weakened pharyngeal reflex, tongue deviation toward the affected side, atrophy of tongue muscle, and so on. Further evaluations and imaging examinations were carried out. The rating of the functional oral intake scale (FOIS) was level 2. Videofluoroscopic swallowing study (VFSS) showed that the contrast agent leaked into the vestibule of the larynx and entered the trachea through the glottis when the patient drank 3 ml of thin liquid . The rating of Rosenbek leakage/aspiration scale was level 8, which is the worst level. When the patient drank 3 ml of medium-thick semi-fluid liquid, effective swallowing was not initiated and the epiglottis valley had a large amount of residue. When examined through the electronic laryngoscope, we noticed paralysis of bilateral vocal folds . All these observations indicated that the vagus nerve and hypoglossal nerve had been injured. Therefore, we thought that there may be a lesion in or near the brainstem that led to nerve injury. However, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed that there were no brainstem lesions , and that the symptoms that arose after surgery could not be explained by the left frontal lobe malacia and subdural hematoma . Owing to the inconformity of symptoms and radiographic results, we decided to analyze the rare case again. When we reviewed the clinical history, we noticed that the surgery was performed under general anesthesia and transoral intubation, so there may be a connection between transoral intubation and nerve injury. After consulting with the ear–nose–throat (ENT) and anesthesiology departments, we excluded arytenoid dislocation and violent intubation. Then we found that these symptoms are similar to those of a specific syndrome, so we compared the characteristics of this case with diagnostic criteria of that syndrome. First, in terms of clinical history, the majority of cases occur following the surgical intervention under general anesthesia and transoral intubation. Our patient went through craniotomy evacuation of hematoma with general anesthesia and transoral intubation before these symptoms arose. Second, symptoms of the patient included difficulties in tongue movement, unilateral tongue paralysis, and atrophy of the tongue, as well as hoarseness and dysphagia, which matches the described symptoms of that syndrome. Third, the complete neurological examination showed that there are cranial nerve injuries and, based on the MRI results, we excluded lesions in the brainstem. Hence the symptoms are likely caused by peripheral nerve injuries. Thus, a diagnosis was made. Fig. 1 Videofluoroscopic swallowing study (VFSS). A Aspiration occurred when the patient drank 3 ml of thin liquid. (before treatment, arrow, left). B A small amount of leakage when the patient drank 3 ml of thin liquid. (after 2 weeks of treatment, arrow, middle). C No leakage or aspiration occurred when the patient drank 3 ml of thin liquid. (after 52 days of treatment, arrow, right) Full size image Fig. 2 The electronic laryngoscope. A Paralysis of bilateral vocal folds (before treatment, arrow, left). B Vocal folds could close up (after treatment, arrow, right) Full size image Fig. 3 Magnetic resonance imaging. A No lesion concerning the brainstem (arrow, left). B Symptoms cannot be explained by left frontal lobe malacia and subdural hematoma (arrow, right) Full size image We designed a detailed rehabilitation strategy for the patient immediately. In the previous studies of that syndrome, only standard swallowing training was used as rehabilitation treatment, which proved to be effective but still means a lengthy recovery process. So we decided to include electroacupuncture as a measure in our treatment to observe the effect. The patient received acupuncture treatment 30 minutes per day, six times per week for 52 days . Qi She brand disposable, sterile steel needles (0.25 × 40 mm; Wuxi Jiajian Medical Instrument Co. Ltd) were used. Based on our experience in treating similar diseases, we chose several acupoints to improve deglutition and speech function. These acupoints included the three-needle tongue (Shanglianquan, located in the depression between the lingual bone and the border of the lower jaw, 1 cun inferior to the midline of the jaw), and two other acupoints located at 0.8 cun bilateral to Shanglianquan (note that the width of the interphalangeal joint of the patient’s thumb is taken as 1 cun, approximately 25 mm), Dicang (ST 4, with the eyes looking straight forward, the point is vertically below the pupil, at the level of the angle of the mouth), Taixi (KI 3, in the depression between the tip of the medial malleolus and Achilles’ tendon), and Zhaohai (KI 6, in the depression below the tip of the medial malleolus). Electroacupuncture (EA) stimulation (EA parameters were set as follows: discontinuous wave with frequency 5 Hz, pulse width 1 ms, and intensity approximately 2 mA, until a slight jitter in the muscle is observed) was applied to two acupoints located at 0.8 cun bilateral to Shanglianquan (EX). No side effects such as bleeding or hematoma were observed during the entire treatment. Fig. 4 The location of acupoints. Acupoints on face and neck (three-needle tongue and Dicang). Acupoints on lower limbs (Taixi and Zhaohai) Full size image
rewritten_case:
A 57-year-old Chinese man presented with a history of a spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage triggered by a cerebral aneurysm rupture. He underwent a craniotomy evacuation of the hematoma under general anesthesia, with transoral intubation. Notably, no difficulty in swallowing or speaking was reported during the surgical procedure. 

However, post-surgery, the patient presented with dysarthria, dysphagia, and issues with tongue movement. These symptoms prompted a thorough neurological examination. Findings suggested cranial nerve injuries with signs such as a weakened pharyngeal reflex, tongue deviation toward the affected side, and tongue muscle atrophy. 

Additional evaluations and imaging examinations were undertaken. The patient's functional oral intake scale (FOIS) was at level 2. A Videofluoroscopic swallowing study (VFSS) showed that the contrast agent had leaked into the vestibule of the larynx and entered the trachea through the glottis when the patient ingested 3 ml of thin liquid. The Rosenbek leakage/aspiration scale rating was at level 8, the worst possible level. Upon drinking 3 ml of medium-thick semi-fluid liquid, effective swallowing was not initiated and a significant amount of residue was found in the epiglottis valley. An electronic laryngoscope examination revealed paralysis of the bilateral vocal folds, suggesting vagus and hypoglossal nerve injuries.

Despite these findings, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed no brainstem lesions, ruling out the possibility of the symptoms being caused by left frontal lobe malacia and subdural hematoma. This discrepancy between the symptoms and radiographic results led to an in-depth review of the case. 

The clinical history indicated that the surgery was performed under general anesthesia with transoral intubation, suggesting possible connections to the nerve injury. After discussions with the ear-nose-throat (ENT) and anesthesiology departments, arytenoid dislocation and violent intubation were ruled out. 

The symptoms closely resembled those of a specific syndrome. A comparison with the diagnostic criteria of the syndrome revealed similarities in clinical history, symptoms, and neurological examination findings. As per the MRI results, brainstem lesions were ruled out, indicating the symptoms were likely due to peripheral nerve injuries.

A detailed rehabilitation strategy was promptly devised for the patient. Previous studies of the syndrome only used standard swallowing training as rehabilitation treatment, which though effective, entails a lengthy recovery process. For this case, electroacupuncture was included as an additional treatment measure. The patient received acupuncture treatment for 30 minutes daily, six times a week. 

The treatment utilized Qi She brand disposable, sterile steel needles. Several acupoints were selected to improve deglutition and speech function, including the three-needle tongue, Shanglianquan, Dicang, Taixi, and Zhaohai. Electroacupuncture stimulation was applied to two acupoints located at 0.8 cun bilateral to Shanglianquan. No adverse effects such as bleeding or hematoma were observed throughout the treatment.
model_response:
DX: Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve Injury

The patient's symptoms of dysarthria, dysphagia, and tongue movement issues, along with the findings of weakened pharyngeal reflex, tongue deviation, and tongue muscle atrophy, suggest damage to the cranial nerves. The presence of bilateral vocal fold paralysis and vagus and hypoglossal nerve injuries, as well as the patient's history of transoral intubation under general anesthesia, are consistent with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

original_case: A 68-year-old Japanese man was found to have an extensive type 0–IIc lesion in the upper gastric body extending up to the hypogastric lesser curvature on upper gastrointestinal endoscopy in September 2019. Biopsy revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma; the patient was referred to our department for surgery. He had hypertension and hyperlipidemia. However, he had no family history of malignancy. The patient underwent robot-assisted laparoscopic distal gastrectomy, D1+ lymph node dissection, and Roux-en-Y reconstruction in November 2019. The patient had a good postoperative course and was discharged 6 days postoperatively. The initial surgical specimen findings were as follows : a 50 × 35-mm 0–IIc lesion with shallow depression ranging from the upper gastric body to the hypogastric lesser curvature. Histopathological examination revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with negative resection margins that were staged IA (pT1aN0M0) according to the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM Classification of Malignant Tumors, 8th edition. Fig. 1 First surgical specimen. The arrows show the tumor. Lesion with shallow depression extending from the upper gastric body to the hypogastric lesser curvature Full size image The patient was followed-up without adjuvant chemotherapy; however, a 38 × 36 mm soft tissue mass was noted on the greater curvature side of the residual stomach during computed tomography (CT) 2 years after the procedure. Although partial thickening of the gastric wall was seen retrospectively in a 1-year postoperative CT scan, it was reviewed within normal limits by a radiologist at that time . No evidence of recurrent metastasis was found at other sites. Fig. 2 One year postoperatively (a), 2 years postoperatively (b). The soft tissue mass on the greater curvature side of the residual stomach is enlarged. The arrows show the soft tissue mass Full size image The blood test findings were as follows: carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), 1.8 ng/mL; carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA19-9), 8.5 U/mL; and soluble IL-2 receptor, 396 U/mL. Colonoscopy had been performed prior to the first surgery; hence, it was not performed again. The FDG-PET/CT findings were as follows : The soft tissue mass on the left side of the residual stomach showed moderate FDG accumulation (SUVmax, 5.25). No FDG accumulation was observed in other areas. Malignant lesions, including recurrent gastric cancer and regional lymph node metastasis, were suspected; however, qualitative diagnosis was difficult. No abnormal accumulation indicating recurrence and metastasis occurred at other sites. Fig. 3 Fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography–computed tomography. The soft tissue mass on the greater curvature side of the residual stomach shows FDG accumulation (SUVmax 5.25). The arrows show the soft tissue mass. FDG fluorodeoxyglucose Full size image Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen revealed the following findings : the soft tissue mass on the greater curvature side of the residual stomach exhibited a high, heterogenous signal on T2-weighted images and a low signal on T1-weighted images, and contrast imaging revealed a slow contrast effect. Other malignant lesions such as gastric cancer recurrence, lymph node metastasis, and a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) were considered as possible differential diagnoses; however, none of the findings were typical, and qualitative diagnosis was difficult. Fig. 4 Magnetic resonance imaging. T2-weighted image showing a heterogeneous high signal. The arrows show the soft tissue mass Full size image Upper gastrointestinal endoscopic findings were as follows : no mass lesions were present in the remnant stomach. Transgastric ultrasonography revealed a 43 × 30 mm borderline oligo-hypoechoic mass in the splenic hilum, which was biopsied using endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration (EUS-FNA). Fig. 5 Endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration. A borderline oligo-hypoechoic mass in the splenic hilum Full size image The biopsy results were as follows: the tumor contained multiple spindle-shaped cells, and immunostaining for CD34, c-kit, desmin, S-100, and β-catenin was performed to distinguish spindle-shaped tumors; however, no significant positive findings were obtained. The biopsy specimen did not allow us to estimate the histological type of the tumor as it did not conclusively suggest a GIST, smooth myxoid, or schwannoma. Based on the above-mentioned examination results, local recurrence of gastric cancer, lymph node metastasis, a GIST, a smooth myxoid, and a schwannoma were regarded as possible differential diagnoses. Although the possibility of a benign tumor remained, a definitive diagnosis could not be made histopathologically, and moderate FDG accumulation could not rule out a malignant lesion; thus, we decided to operate for diagnostic treatment. Preoperative CT revealed a suspicious finding of splenic arteriovenous invasion; therefore, total residual gastrectomy and splenectomy were planned. The surgical findings were as follows: the abdomen was opened via a median upper abdominal incision. A 50 × 40 mm soft tissue mass originating from the gastrojejunal anastomosis involving the spleen and splenic arteriovenous was observed on the greater curvature side of the anastomosis. Additionally, a partial invasion of the pancreas was observed. The remaining stomach, spleen, splenic artery and vein, and part of the pancreas, including the gastrojejunal anastomosis, along with the soft tissue mass, were removed as a single lump. Regarding reconstruction, only esophago-jejunal anastomosis was performed, sparing previous jejuno-jejunal anastomosis. The operation time was 279 minutes, and blood loss was 1100 mL; however, no blood transfusion was required. Pathological findings of the resected specimen were as follows : a 45 × 40 × 40-mm soft tissue mass extending from the muscularis propria to the serosa at the gastrojejunal anastomosis. The tumor was a white, substantial nodule, and its growth involved the gastrojejunal anastomosis. Although fibroblasts and spindle-shaped cells were observed inside the tumor, the Ki-67 index was about 2%, and atypia was not observed. Immunostaining was positive for vimentin, desmin, and β-catenin and negative for α-SMA, S-100, CD34, c-kit, STAT6, estrogen receptor (ER), and progesterone receptor (PgR). Based on the above, a diagnosis was made. Fig. 6 Pathological findings.  The arrows show the tumor. Tumor growth involving anastomosis is observed (a). Hematoxylin–eosin staining showing spindle-shaped cell proliferation without atypia (b). Immunostaining is positive for vimentin (c) and β-catenin (d) expression and negative for Ki-67 (e) expression Full size image

A Japanese man in his late sixties was discovered to have an extensive type 0–IIc lesion in the upper gastric body extending up to the hypogastric lesser curvature through an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. Upon biopsy, the lesion was identified as a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. The patient was referred to our department for surgery. He was known to have hypertension and hyperlipidemia, but he had no family history of malignancy. 

The patient underwent robot-assisted laparoscopic distal gastrectomy, D1+ lymph node dissection, and Roux-en-Y reconstruction. His recovery was smooth and he was discharged 6 days after the operation. The initial surgical specimen findings revealed a 50 × 35-mm 0–IIc lesion with a shallow depression ranging from the upper gastric body to the hypogastric lesser curvature. Histopathological examination disclosed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with negative resection margins, staged IA (pT1aN0M0) according to the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM Classification of Malignant Tumors, 8th edition.

The patient was followed up without adjuvant chemotherapy. During a subsequent computed tomography (CT) scan, a 38 × 36 mm soft tissue mass was detected on the greater curvature side of the residual stomach. No evidence of recurrent metastasis was found at other sites.

The blood test findings were as follows: carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), 1.8 ng/mL; carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA19-9), 8.5 U/mL; and soluble IL-2 receptor, 396 U/mL. Colonoscopy had been performed prior to the first surgery; hence, it was not performed again.

The FDG-PET/CT findings revealed moderate FDG accumulation (SUVmax, 5.25) in the soft tissue mass on the left side of the residual stomach. No FDG accumulation was observed in other areas. Potential malignant lesions, including recurrent gastric cancer and regional lymph node metastasis, were suspected; however, qualitative diagnosis was difficult.

Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen displayed a high, heterogenous signal on T2-weighted images and a low signal on T1-weighted images in the soft tissue mass on the greater curvature side of the residual stomach. Slow contrast effect was noticed on contrast imaging. Other malignant lesions such as gastric cancer recurrence, lymph node metastasis, and a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) were considered as possible differential diagnoses; however, none of the findings were typical.

Upper gastrointestinal endoscopic findings showed no mass lesions in the remnant stomach. Transgastric ultrasonography revealed a 43 × 30 mm borderline oligo-hypoechoic mass in the splenic hilum, which was biopsied using endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration (EUS-FNA).

The biopsy results indicated the tumor contained multiple spindle-shaped cells. Immunostaining for CD34, c-kit, desmin, S-100, and β-catenin was performed to distinguish spindle-shaped tumors; however, no significant positive findings were obtained. The biopsy specimen did not allow us to estimate the histological type of the tumor as it did not conclusively suggest a GIST, smooth myxoid, or schwannoma.

Based on the examination results, local recurrence of gastric cancer, lymph node metastasis, a GIST, a smooth myxoid, and a schwannoma were regarded as possible differential diagnoses. Although the possibility of a benign tumor remained, a definitive diagnosis could not be made histopathologically, and moderate FDG accumulation could not rule out a malignant lesion; hence, the decision was made to operate for diagnostic treatment.
