original_case:
A previously healthy 30-year-old Caucasian woman presented to her primary care office with complaints of an upper respiratory tract infection. She developed symptoms after her husband returned from international travel. She initially had symptoms of nasal congestion and cough. She had fatigue and shortness of breath on ambulation. Ten days after her initial symptoms, she developed an urticarial rash on her abdomen, legs, and hands . The rash was transient and reappeared twice before disappearing. The rash only lasted hours on each occasion. The patient has no past medical history and takes no medications. She does not drink alcohol, smoke cigarettes, or use drugs. She is married and lives at home with her husband, works as a wedding planner, has no children, and has never been pregnant. 

Fig. 1 Pictures of patient’s tongue, extremities, torso, and hand Full size image 

She also complained of tongue swelling on the tenth day after developing symptoms. The swelling went away after 1 hour on its own, but she then developed geographic tongue with the appearance of tongue papillae that were inflamed and some papillae that were flattened . Her tongue had a sensation of sensitivity in the areas interspersed between areas of regular mucosa, and she had some mild loss of sense of taste. 

In the office, her blood pressure was 117/71 mmHg, heart rate was 90 beats per minute, temperature was 98.4 °F, respirations were 14 per minute, and pulse oximetry was 100% on room air. On further examination, she had a geographic appearance to the tongue, with denuding of regions of tongue papillae with an irregular appearance. Her abdomen and extremities showed no signs of rash at the time of the clinical examination. Her neurological examination showed intact motor and sensory strength, normal heart sounds, and lungs that were clear to auscultation; the rest of her examination was normal. Her white blood cell count was 4100/μL (normal range 3800–11,000/μL), hemoglobin was 13.8 (normal range: 13–17) gm/dL, and platelets were 248,000/μL (normal range: 140,000-450,000/μL). Creatinine level was 0.79 (normal range: 0.5–1.1) mg/dL, aspartate transaminase level was 18 (normal range: 10–30) U/L, and alanine transaminase level was 17 (normal range: 16-29) U/L. Her vitamin B12 level was 468 [normal range: 200–1100) pg/mL, and her serum folate was 10.3 (Normal range: > 5.4) ng/mL. 

Fig. 2 The patient’s tongue after receiving photobiomodulation therapy, showing healing Full size image
rewritten_case:
A previously healthy 30-year-old Caucasian woman visited her primary care provider with concerns about an upper respiratory tract infection that started after her husband returned from an international trip. She began with symptoms of nasal congestion and a cough, and soon started experiencing fatigue and shortness of breath while walking. Ten days post the onset of these symptoms, she noticed an urticarial rash on her hands, abdomen, and legs. This rash was temporary and appeared twice before vanishing completely, each time lasting only hours. The patient has no history of medical issues and does not take any medication. She refrains from alcohol, tobacco, and drug use. She is a wedding planner by profession, is married, and lives with her husband. She has no children and has never been pregnant.

Upon further consultation, she also reported an instance of swelling in her tongue, which occurred on the tenth day of her symptoms. This swelling subsided by itself after an hour. However, she developed a geographical tongue, characterized by inflamed and flattened papillae. Her tongue felt sensitive in the areas between regular mucosa, and she experienced a slight loss of taste.

During her consultation, her vitals were recorded as follows: blood pressure - 117/71 mmHg, heart rate - 90 bpm, temperature - 98.4 °F, respirations - 14 per minute, and pulse oximetry - 100% on room air. Further examination revealed a geographical appearance to the tongue with an irregular pattern of tongue papillae. No signs of rash were found on her abdomen or extremities at the time of the clinical examination. Her neurological examination revealed normal motor and sensory strength, normal heart sounds, and clear lungs on auscultation. The rest of her examination was normal. 

Lab findings were as follows: white blood cell count - 4100/μL (normal range 3800–11,000/μL), hemoglobin - 13.8 gm/dL (normal range: 13–17), platelets - 248,000/μL (normal range: 140,000-450,000/μL), creatinine level - 0.79 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5–1.1), aspartate transaminase level - 18 U/L (normal range: 10–30), alanine transaminase level - 17 U/L (normal range: 16-29), Vitamin B12 level - 468 pg/mL (normal range: 200–1100), and serum folate - 10.3 ng/mL (Normal range: > 5.4). 

On closer inspection of the patient's mouth, minor lacerations were found on the inner cheek and lip. These injuries, along with the patient's tongue symptoms, suggested a possible diagnosis of cheek and lip biting, potentially triggered by stress or anxiety. However, given the recent global health conditions and her husband's international travel, the possibility of COVID-19 infection and the recently identified symptom of "COVID tongue" could not be ruled out.
model_response:
DX: COVID-19 infection

The patient's symptoms, including nasal congestion, cough, fatigue, and shortness of breath, are consistent with a viral upper respiratory tract infection. The recent travel history of her husband and the onset of symptoms after his return from an international trip, combined with the urticarial rash and "COVID tongue" symptoms, suggest a high likelihood of COVID-19 infection.
adjudication_notes: Predicted label differs, but true dx mentioned elsewhere in output.

original_case: A 4-year-old Indian boy from a low-income family (farmer) was admitted to the hospital for a routine blood transfusion. His weight and height was between the 10th and 50th centile, with −1.71 and −1.54 Z-scores, respectively. He had O (+ve) blood group and required 10–12 blood transfusions a year. His adult hemoglobin (HbA2) was > 3%, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) was 74.89 fl, and mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) was 30.4 pg according to his medical records, and his physical examination revealed that he had knee pain and an enlarged spleen (> 3 cm below costal margin). After reviewing his family history, it was discovered that one of his two male siblings (who died) had a similar condition, while all of his sisters were well . The parents gave their consent for the patient, but the parents and their healthy offspring declined to participate, so we removed them from the study. Medical details and blood samples were collected from the hospital once written informed consent was given. The genomic DNA was isolated according to the manufacturer’s instructions using the gDNA Blood Mini Kit (Chromous Biotech, Bengaluru, India). Additional genomic analysis was carried out according to [4]. The BLAST method in the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) database was used to confirm the identification of the collected sequences. By comparing mutations to reference sequences, direct counting was used to determine their presence (NG 000007.3 Homo sapiens chromosome 11). The dbSNP, Clinvar, Ithanet, and HbVar databases were then used to look for mutations that had been identified in other populations [5]. Fig. 1 Details related to the case study. A The pedigree diagram illustrates family history: one male sibling (deceased) was affected and other siblings were unaffected. B Sequencing data shows wild type and mutant chromatograms for both exonic (CD3 [T>C] and CD41/42 [-CTTT]), and intronic (IVS II-16 [G>C] and IVS II-666 [C>T]) variants. C Clinical data collected from the hospital. D Schematic diagram of HBB gene structure with four identified variants at their respective locations.
rewritten_case:
A young boy of Indian descent, aged 4, hailing from a low-income farming family was taken to the hospital for a standard blood transfusion procedure. His weight and height measurements placed him between the 10th and 50th centile, with Z-scores of -1.71 and -1.54 respectively. His blood group was O positive, and his medical records indicated a long-standing need for 10-12 blood transfusions per year. His adult hemoglobin (HbA2) was > 3%, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) was 74.89 fl, and mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) was 30.4 pg. He was experiencing knee pain and showed signs of an enlarged spleen (> 3 cm below costal margin).

A review of his family history revealed a deceased brother who also exhibited similar conditions, while his sisters were all in good health. The parents willingly gave their consent for the boy's treatment, however, declined to participate themselves along with their healthy children, hence they were excluded from the study. The boy's medical details and blood samples were collected from the hospital following the receipt of written informed consent. Genomic DNA was isolated following the manufacturer’s guidelines using the gDNA Blood Mini Kit (Chromous Biotech, Bengaluru, India). Further genomic analysis was conducted as per standard protocols.

The collected sequences were confirmed using the BLAST method in the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) database. Mutations were identified by direct counting compared to reference sequences (NG 000007.3 Homo sapiens chromosome 11). Databases such as dbSNP, Clinvar, Ithanet, and HbVar were then utilized to identify any mutations that have previously been recognized in other populations. 

In the case study details, the pedigree diagram showed one affected male sibling (deceased) and other unaffected siblings. Sequencing data revealed both exonic (CD3 [T>C] and CD41/42 [-CTTT]) and intronic (IVS II-16 [G>C] and IVS II-666 [C>T]) variants. Clinical data was collected from the hospital. The HBB gene structure diagram illustrated the locations of the four identified variants.
model_response:
DX: Thalassemia

The presence of multiple variants in the HBB gene, including exonic and intronic mutations, is consistent with the diagnosis of thalassemia. The patient's clinical presentation, including knee pain and an enlarged spleen, is also consistent with this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: Exact/normalized match to distractor alias.

original_case:
A previously healthy 13-year-old African American female (body mass index 19.2 kg/m², 55.99% for age and sex percentile) presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of altered mental status and difficulty breathing. Symptoms were preceded by 1 day of headache and fever, prompting evaluation at an urgent care center where she was found to be SARS-CoV-2 positive. On the morning of presentation, she sought further evaluation in the emergency department for symptom progression to chest pain, heavy breathing, and confusion. Pertinent examination findings at presentation included disorientation, combative behavior without focal neurologic deficit, tachycardia, Kussmaul breathing, dry mucus membranes, and diffuse abdominal tenderness. Laboratory findings revealed leukocytosis (white blood cell count 22.3 × 10³/mcL), anion-gap metabolic acidosis (pH 6.92, pCO₂ < 5 torr, base deficit 28), and hyperglycemia (glucose 668 mg/dL). Urinalysis was significant for ketonuria and glucosuria. Physical examination and laboratory findings were consistent with newly diagnosed diabetes mellitus (hemoglobin A1C > 16%) complicated by diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), likely triggered by acute COVID-19 infection, with features concerning for cerebral edema. She was started on continuous insulin infusion (0.1 units/kg/h), given a bolus of 3% hypertonic saline (HTS), and was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) for further management. DKA was treated according to the institutional protocol with intravenous fluids, continuous insulin infusion, and close electrolyte monitoring.

Due to persistent alteration in mental status shortly after admission, she received two additional HTS boluses and had head computed tomography (CT) scan, which was normal. Despite these interventions and resolution of metabolic derangements, her mentation remained altered. On day 2 of admission, a brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan  showed abnormal enhancement within the frontal lobe extending from the olfactory floor upward. Additional findings were notable for dehiscence of the planum sphenoidale and involvement of the left nasal cavity near superior turbinate, which was concerning for an infectious cerebritis with possible developing phlegmon/intracranial abscess. In the clinical setting of DKA, these findings were concerning for invasive sinusitis with intracranial extension. Lumbar puncture (LP) was subsequently performed on day 2 and revealed cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pleocytosis with neutrophilic predominance and negative meningitis encephalitis panel. CSF cultures were not obtained at that time due to limited sample volume. An infectious diseases specialist was consulted and recommended an empiric antimicrobial regimen with ceftriaxone, metronidazole, and liposomal amphotericin B given the risk for invasive fungal disease. The patient did not meet criteria for treatment of acute COVID-19 infection, so steroids and antivirals were deferred.

Fig. 1 Head images (CT and MRI). a (Day 2 admission): MRI T1 brain sagittal view showed abnormal enhancement within the frontal lobe extending from the olfactory floor upward through the right gyrus rectus. b (Day 3 admission): sinus CT showed mild opacification of superior maeti, maxillary ostium, medial and posterior ethmoid air cells with erosive changes of the osseous septa and possible defect. c (Day 4 admission): head CT showed cerebral edema with mass effect suggestive of infectious cerebritis. d (Day 10 admission): MRI Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) brain coronal view showed significantly increased area of cerebritis/phlegmon involving right frontal lobe extending into the basal ganglia. Interval increased midline shift with extension of vasogenic edema to the left gyrus rectus. e (Day 16 admission): MRI T2 brain horizontal view showed progression of parenchymal involvement involving right frontal lobe, right parietal lobe, and across the corpus callosum to the contralateral side with a 3-mm right-to-left midline shift. f (Day 25 admission, day 15 post ope, 9/29 images): increased mass effect with right-to-left midline shift with interval increased hypodensity involving the right frontotemporal lobes, basal ganglia, and thalamus extending to the right midbrain, representing increased edema or infection.

On day 3 of admission, sinus CT scan  revealed mild opacification of the superior maeti, maxillary ostium, medial and posterior ethmoid air cells with erosive change of the osseous septa and possible bone defect. An otorhinolaryngology (ENT) surgeon performed an endoscopic nasal examination, notable for friable tissue without evidence of necrosis. Due to limited patient tolerance during the awake examination, biopsies were not obtained at that time. On day 4 of admission, repeat head CT  showed interval progression of intracranial pathology with mass effect and cerebral edema suggestive of infectious cerebritis. Repeat LP was unsuccessful, so blood metagenomics testing (Karius test, Redwood City, CA) was obtained on day 5 to aid in the diagnosis. She continued to have daily fevers despite broad-spectrum antimicrobial coverage. Blood cultures obtained at initial presentation remained negative, and an evaluation for endocarditis as a potential source of fever was unrevealing. Invasive fungal disease was most concerning among the differential diagnoses, so posaconazole was added to the antimicrobial regimen on day 7 of admission while awaiting results of the Karius test. Results returned on day 9 of admission and revealed genetic material belonging to a fungal organism. The positive Karius test in the setting of progressive intracranial disease confirmed the diagnosis.

Vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and metronidazole were discontinued, and treatment with liposomal amphotericin B and posaconazole was continued at that time. Repeat imaging on day 10  showed disease progression with worsening midline shift while on maximal antifungal therapy, prompting the decision to pursue emergent surgical debridement. The patient underwent frontal craniotomy with drainage of abscess and sphenoidotomy with debridement. Intraoperative findings were notable for invasive infection and necrotizing cerebritis . Pathology revealed necrosis with non-septate broad hyphae and scattered giant cells with micro-abscess formation. Posaconazole was discontinued on day 13 due to prolonged QTc interval identified on surveillance electrocardiogram (EKG) and was replaced with isavuconazole. Nasal amphotericin irrigations were performed by ENT as adjunctive therapy.

Fig. 2 Endoscopic view of the right nasal cavity. Avascular fibrinous conversion of the superior turbinate (St) extends to the level of the anterior skull base (Sb) without classic black necrotic eschar typically visualized with invasive fungal sinusitis. Left picture shows a superior endoscopic view of the right nasal cavity (left picture). Septum—Sp; middle turbinate—Mt; superior turbinate attachment at the anterior skull base—Sb; septum—sp; middle turbinate—Mt.

Fig. 3 Pathology findings. Microscopic examination of the debridement specimen from right frontal lobe reveals necrotic brain tissue with broad-based ribbon-like pauciseptate hyphae. The angle of branching is wide-angle and greater than other organisms, usually approaching 90° (a and b). Angioinvasion is easily identified (c). There is a marked inflammatory response which is neutrophilic and granulomatous between the viable brain tissue and necrosis (d). a (Periodic acid–Schiff stain) and b (Grocott–Gomori methenamine silver stain): Irregular, broad-based, pauciseptate thick fungal hyphae branching at right angles in the necrotic focus (original magnification, ×400). c Angioinvasion or invasion of the vessels by hyphae. d (Hematoxylin–eosin stain): Granulomatous inflammatory response (original magnification, ×400).

The patient suffered from central diabetes insipidus and neurological deficits including left-sided hemiparesis and persistent fluctuations in mental status. Weekly head imaging was performed for disease surveillance and showed progression of disease despite maximal antifungal therapy. On postoperative day 6 (day 16 of admission), brain MRI  showed extension of intracranial infection to the contralateral hemisphere and brainstem involvement. Given these findings, no further neurosurgical intervention was recommended. Progression of the disease continued, and subsequent imaging  showed worsening midline shift (1.5 cm on postoperative day 15) with evidence of early temporal lobe herniation. Hospital course was additionally complicated by nephrotoxicity, aspiration pneumonia, and venous catheter-associated thrombus formation requiring anticoagulation therapy. Nasal amphotericin irrigations were discontinued on hospital day 20 due to severe nosebleeds during the procedure.

Supportive care was offered for the aforementioned complications, and the patient continued maintenance therapy with liposomal amphotericin B and isavuconazole. Dose adjustments were made to the antifungals due to renal impairment. Despite these challenges, her clinical status steadily improved. She was transferred to an inpatient rehabilitation facility on hospital day 79 for ongoing medical management and intensive therapies to maximize functional status. After 104 days total of inpatient management, the patient was discharged home and transitioned to outpatient care. Amphotericin B was discontinued at time of discharge, and she remains on isavuconazole monotherapy. As of 10 months from initial diagnosis, she continues showing improvement in functional domains as she can fully ambulate and perform activities of daily living with minimal assistance.

A previously healthy 13-year-old African American female (body mass index 19.2 kg/m², 55.99% for age and sex percentile) arrived at the emergency department with a primary complaint of mental confusion and difficulty breathing. The symptoms were preceded by a day of fever and headache which led to an examination at an urgent care center where she tested positive for SARS-CoV-2. On the morning of presentation, she sought further evaluation in the emergency department for worsening symptoms, including chest pain, heavy breathing, and confusion. 

Pertinent examination findings included confusion, aggressive behavior without focal neurologic deficit, tachycardia, Kussmaul breathing, dry mucus membranes, and diffuse abdominal tenderness. Laboratory findings revealed leukocytosis (white blood cell count 22.3 × 10³/mcL), anion-gap metabolic acidosis (pH 6.92, pCO₂ < 5 torr, base deficit 28), and hyperglycemia (glucose 668 mg/dL). Urinalysis was significant for ketonuria and glucosuria. Physical examination and laboratory findings were indicative of newly diagnosed diabetes mellitus (hemoglobin A1C > 16%) complicated by diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), likely triggered by acute COVID-19 infection, with features concerning for cerebral edema. Continuous insulin infusion (0.1 units/kg/h) was initiated, a bolus of 3% hypertonic saline (HTS) was administered, and the patient was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) for further management. 

On day 2 of admission, a brain MRI scan revealed abnormal enhancement within the frontal lobe extending from the olfactory floor upward. Additional findings were notable for dehiscence of the planum sphenoidale and involvement of the left nasal cavity near superior turbinate, which was concerning for an infectious cerebritis with possible developing phlegmon/intracranial abscess. Notably, the patient had also developed a rapidly progressive skin lesion on her arm, which appeared necrotic and was surrounded by an erythematous halo. This lesion, along with her clinical picture, raised suspicion for cutaneous mucormycosis, a rare but aggressive fungal infection. 

An infectious diseases specialist was consulted and recommended an empiric antimicrobial regimen with ceftriaxone, metronidazole, and liposomal amphotericin B given the risk for invasive fungal disease. On day 3 of admission, a biopsy of the skin lesion was performed, revealing broad, non-septate hyphae, consistent with mucormycosis. Despite the biopsy results, the patient's mental status did not improve, and on day 5, a repeat brain MRI showed worsening cerebral edema and progression of the intracranial abscess. 

Due to the continued mental status changes, the patient underwent a lumbar puncture which revealed cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pleocytosis with neutrophilic predominance and negative meningitis encephalitis panel. Blood cultures remained negative, and an evaluation for endocarditis as a potential source of fever was unrevealing. Despite the skin biopsy findings and the progression of the intracranial abscess, the patient's clinical picture remained consistent with invasive cutaneous mucormycosis. 

The patient continued to suffer from neurological deficits, including left-sided hemiparesis and persistent changes in mental status. Despite maximal antifungal therapy, further imaging showed progression of disease. Given these findings, no further neurosurgical intervention was recommended. The patient was transferred to an inpatient rehabilitation facility for ongoing medical management and intensive therapies to maximize functional status. After 104 days total of inpatient management, the patient was discharged home and transitioned to outpatient care. As of 10 months from initial diagnosis, she continues showing improvement
model_response:
DX: Invasive cutaneous mucormycosis

The patient's symptoms, including fever, headache, and mental confusion, are consistent with COVID-19 infection. However, the development of a necrotic skin lesion with an erythematous halo, along with the brain MRI findings of abnormal enhancement and possible infectious cerebritis, suggest a secondary invasive fungal infection, which is supported by the skin biopsy results showing broad, non-septate hyphae consistent with mucormycosis.

original_case:
Patient information and clinical data  
General information  
According to the China 2020 expert consensus on emergency application of corticosteroid, the definition of high-dose mPSL is 1–4 mg/(kg days), which is defined as >1.5 mg/(kg days) in this paper. Four patients, all Asian female, aged between 26 and 71 years old, with average age of 49.25 ± 18.38 were included in this study. To protect the privacy of the patients, we hid their real names, visiting department, hospitalization number, bed number, and other related information. Cases 1 and 2 were previously healthy, while cases 3 and 4 were accompanied by hypertension and renal insufficiency. There was no obvious abnormality in their family or psychosocial history, including related genetic information. Investigations on admission showed no history of pancreatic/salivary gland-related diseases or trauma, neoplasms, genital tract diseases, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) operation history, or abdominal surgery. In addition, patients were not diagnosed with hyperlipidemia, alcoholism, common drug factors (such as amino salicylic acid, thiopurine, and asparaginase), or megaamylasemia that can cause elevated serum amylase levels. Basic information and clinical data of the four patients are presented in .  
 Clinical data  
Full size table  
Clinical manifestations  
Case 1 showed persistent upper abdominal pain and right abdominal tenderness, with no episodes of vomiting, diarrhea, or rebound pain following high-dose intravenous administration of mPSL. Case 2 had abdominal distension, persistent epigastric pain, with no other concomitant symptoms, either. Meanwhile, cases 3 and 4 did not show any significant symptoms. The positive physical examination results of the four cases were all related to the primary disease, and the abdominal physical examination showed no apparent abnormality.  
Clinical findings  
After high-dose intravenous administration of mPSL, serum amylase (AMY) levels increased in four patients, peaking at 193.1 to 340.4 U/L. In addition, increases in urine amylase and serum lipase were also observed. Abdominal enhanced CT scan performed after the occurrence of elevated serum amylase levels in case 1 showed sand-like stones in the gallbladder, with a normal shape of pancreas. In cases 2, 3, and 4, abdominal ultrasound performed prior to high-dose mPSL indicated gallbladder sediment-like stones, rough gallbladder wall, and gallbladder stones, respectively. Notably, the CT scans in cases 2, 3, and 4 did not reveal any abnormalities of the pancreas. The AMY fluctuations of the four patients over time are shown in Fig. 1.  
Fig. 1  
AMY fluctuations of the four cases and the corresponding course of disease. The four cases started to use high-dose mPSL on the 3rd day, 6th day, 8th day, and 9th day of the disease course. AMY elevation was noted on the 19th day, 9th day, 14th day, and 13th day, respectively. AMY peak appeared on day 22, day 17, day 18, and day 34, respectively. Amylase was monitored for five consecutive days in cases 1 and 2 and weekly in cases 3 and 4.  
Full size image  
Diagnostic assessment and diagnosis  
The above clinical manifestations, physical examinations, and clinical data were to be not very specific for diagnosis. Only cases 1 and 2 experienced epigastric pain, while enhancement CT in case 1 revealed gallstones. We were able to identify elevated serum amylase levels on the basis of the fact that the four patients had different elevations of AMY that exceeded the normal reference values of our hospital system. We speculate about the possibility of elevated serum amylase levels caused by high doses of intravenous GC through the adverse drug response evaluation described below. We considered whether this can be attributed to drug-induced pancreatitis, but imaging did not reveal any pancreatic abnormalities and therefore diagnostic criteria for pancreatitis were not met. The overall prognosis of the four patients is good.  
Interventions and outcomes  
Case 1 and 2 underwent fasting. Then, they were given omeprazole to inhibit gastric acid, phloroglucinol as antispasmodic, somatostatin to inhibit pancreatic enzyme secretion, and anti-infection and nutritional support treatment. Two patients were discharged after a significant decrease in AMY levels, and case 3 and 4 were discharged after improvement of the primary disease. At outpatient review, they indicated that mPLS was effective for the primary disease and that, despite the unexpected increase in AMY, subsequent active interventions led to normalization of AMY. Unfortunately, they have not been followed since then.

Patient Information and Clinical Data  
General Information  
The China 2020 expert consensus on emergency application of corticosteroids outlines that high-dose mPSL falls under the range of 1–4 mg/(kg days). In this study, we defined it as >1.5 mg/(kg days). The study involved four patients, all Asian females, ranging in age from 26 to 71 years old, with an average age of 49.25 ± 18.38. To maintain patient confidentiality, their real names, visiting department, hospitalization number, bed number, and other related information have been withheld. Cases 1 and 2 were previously healthy, while cases 3 and 4 had a history of hypertension and renal insufficiency. The patients had no significant family or psychosocial history, including related genetic information. Upon admission, there was no history of pancreatic/salivary gland-related diseases or trauma, neoplasms, genital tract diseases, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) operation history, or abdominal surgery. Furthermore, none of the patients had been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia, alcoholism, or had taken certain medications (such as amino salicylic acid, thiopurine, and asparaginase), or had megaamylasemia that could cause elevated serum amylase levels. 

Clinical Manifestations  
During the course of treatment, Case 1 experienced persistent upper abdominal pain and right abdominal tenderness, with no instances of vomiting, diarrhea, or rebound pain after high-dose intravenous administration of mPSL. Case 2 reported abdominal distension and persistent epigastric pain, with no other symptoms. Cases 3 and 4 did not present any significant symptoms. The positive physical examination results for all four patients were related to the primary disease, and the abdominal physical examination did not reveal any apparent abnormalities. 

Clinical Findings  
After high-dose intravenous administration of mPSL, there was a surge in serum amylase (AMY) levels in all four patients, with levels ranging between 193.1 to 340.4 U/L. Increases in urine amylase and serum lipase were also observed. An abdominal enhanced CT scan performed on Case 1 after the rise in serum amylase levels showed sand-like stones in the gallbladder, with the pancreas appearing normal. Meanwhile, cases 2, 3, and 4 had undergone an abdominal ultrasound before mPSL administration that showed gallbladder sediment-like stones, rough gallbladder wall, and gallbladder stones respectively. The CT scans for cases 2, 3, and 4 did not reveal any pancreatic abnormalities. 

Diagnostic Assessment and Diagnosis  
The clinical manifestations, physical examinations, and clinical data were not specific enough for a diagnosis. Only cases 1 and 2 had reported epigastric pain, with gallstones observed in the enhancement CT for Case 1. Elevated serum amylase levels were identified in all four patients, and this led to speculation of a possible adverse drug response from high-dose intravenous GC administration. The possibility of drug-induced pancreatitis was considered, but the absence of any pancreatic abnormalities on imaging ruled out this diagnosis. Despite this, the overall prognosis for all four patients remained good. 

Interventions and Outcomes  
Cases 1 and 2 were put on fasting and given omeprazole to inhibit gastric acid, phloroglucinol as an antispasmodic, somatostatin to inhibit pancreatic enzyme secretion, and received anti-infection and nutritional support treatment. These two patients were discharged once their AMY levels significantly decreased. Cases 3 and 4 were discharged after their primary disease improved. model_response:
DX: Drug-induced hyperamylasemia

The most likely diagnosis is drug-induced hyperamylasemia due to the surge in serum amylase levels in all four patients after high-dose intravenous administration of mPSL, which is a known side effect of corticosteroids. The absence of pancreatic abnormalities on imaging and the good overall prognosis for all four patients support this diagnosis.

original_case:
A 77-year-old Caucasian woman was referred to our dermatology department with multiple painful, itchy, and warm red/blue cutaneous nodules on the left lower leg. The cutaneous nodules had progressed over time and were visible on both legs. The patient had no significant medical history, was a former smoker, used 14 units of alcohol per week, and had done office work. She had not experienced abdominal discomfort or weight loss. Both her parents had died from lung cancer, and there was no further family history of gastrointestinal or pancreatic cancer. She was the mother of three children and used the following medications: allopurinol, metoprolol, omeprazole, perindopril/indapamide, and pravastatin. 

Physical examination revealed three cutaneous nodules ranging in diameter from 1 to 4 cm on both legs . One was slightly red, while the other two were dark red to purple–blue. All were painful during palpation. According to the dermatologist, the skin lesions were consistent with the clinical diagnosis of panniculitis. Further neurological and physical examination was not performed. 

Fig. 1 Cutaneous nodules on both legs during presentation Full size image 

The skin biopsy obtained showed a predominantly lobular panniculitis with fat necrosis of which the aspect was highly suspicious for pancreatic panniculitis . Based on this finding, further diagnostic analyses were performed including blood tests and computed tomography (CT) scan followed by endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) and fine-needle biopsy. A lipase serum level of > 3000 U/L (normal range < 60 U/L) and a mass located between the stomach and the left side of the pancreas, with a diameter of 7.4 cm, was seen . There were no signs of metastases. EUS-guided fine-needle biopsy was obtained, and the histopathological diagnosis was made. 

Fig. 2 Skin biopsy showing the subcutis with local saponification of fat Full size image 

Fig. 3 Mass located in the left pancreas, in contact with the stomach Full size image 

The patient was discussed during the pancreatobiliary multidisciplinary team meeting. Minimally invasive distal pancreatectomy including splenectomy was advised. Upon hospital admission, pulse, blood pressure, and temperature were normal. The patient underwent this procedure laparoscopically including en bloc wedge resection of the stomach owing to tumor in-growth. Operation time was 7 h. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 4 after an uncomplicated hospital stay. During the hospital stay, she received paracetamol, oxycodone, pheneticillin because of the splenectomy, and magnesium hydroxide. Her renal and liver function were normal. No additional urinalysis or microbiology was performed. The cutaneous nodules on both legs had disappeared 1–2 days after surgery. 

The diagnosis on the resection specimen was made, the resection margins were free of tumor (R0 resection), and there were no lymph node metastases found in 12 examined lymph nodes. The postoperative multidisciplinary team meeting advised the patient to undergo adjuvant chemotherapy. Nonetheless, the added value of adjuvant chemotherapy for this rare form of pancreatic carcinoma has not been well researched. Based on the available data, the patient rejected adjuvant chemotherapy. 

During the first and second outpatient visit, at 4 and 6 months postoperatively, no long-term complications were reported, and the patient had recovered well. One year after surgery, the patient presented to the emergency room with similar symptoms as preoperatively. CT scan showed both local recurrence and distal metastases, which were subsequently confirmed by biopsy. She started with palliative folinic acid–fluorouracil–irinotecan–oxaliplatin (FOLFIRINOX) chemotherapy but stopped after two cycles because of disease progression. The patient died 2 months later, 13 months after surgical resection.

A Caucasian woman in her late 70s presented to our dermatology department with multiple warm red/blue cutaneous nodules on her lower legs, which were causing her discomfort and itchiness. The nodules were found on both legs and had been developing for an unspecified period. The patient, a former smoker who consumed 14 units of alcohol weekly, had no significant medical history and was retired from office work. She denied experiencing abdominal discomfort or weight loss. Her parents had both died from lung cancer but there was no family history of gastrointestinal or pancreatic cancer. The patient was the mother of three and was on a regimen of allopurinol, metoprolol, omeprazole, perindopril/indapamide, and pravastatin.

Upon physical examination, three cutaneous nodules ranging in diameter from 1 to 4 cm were found on both legs. One was slightly red while the other two were dark red to purple–blue. All were painful to the touch. The dermatologist determined that the skin lesions were consistent with the clinical diagnosis of panniculitis. Further neurological and physical examinations were not undertaken.

A skin biopsy revealed a predominantly lobular panniculitis with fat necrosis, highly suggestive of pancreatic panniculitis. Further diagnostic analyses were carried out, including blood tests, computed tomography (CT) scan, endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS), and fine-needle biopsy. The patient's lipase serum level was found to be > 3000 U/L (normal range < 60 U/L) and a mass of 7.4 cm in diameter was identified between the stomach and the left side of the pancreas. No signs of metastases were detected and the histopathological diagnosis was made following an EUS-guided fine-needle biopsy.

The pancreatobiliary multidisciplinary team recommended a minimally invasive distal pancreatectomy with splenectomy. The patient underwent laparoscopic surgery, including en bloc wedge resection of the stomach due to tumor in-growth. She was discharged from the hospital after an uncomplicated stay during which she received paracetamol, oxycodone, pheneticillin (due to the splenectomy), and magnesium hydroxide. Renal and liver function were normal. No additional urinalysis or microbiology was performed. The cutaneous nodules on her legs resolved a few days post-surgery.

The resection specimen was examined, revealing free resection margins and no lymph node metastases in the 12 examined lymph nodes. Despite the recommendation for adjuvant chemotherapy, the patient decided against this option due to the limited research on its benefits in this rare form of pancreatic carcinoma.

Subsequent outpatient visits showed no long-term complications and the patient had recovered well. However, sometime after the surgery, the patient presented to the emergency room with symptoms similar to her preoperative state. A CT scan and biopsy confirmed local recurrence and distal metastases. She started palliative folinic acid–fluorouracil–irinotecan–oxaliplatin (FOLFIRINOX) chemotherapy but discontinued after two cycles due to disease progression. Unfortunately, the patient passed away a few months later.

The patient's symptoms, including the presence of multiple warm red/blue cutaneous nodules on her lower legs, pain, and itchiness, are consistent with the clinical diagnosis of panniculitis. The skin biopsy revealed a predominantly lobular panniculitis with fat necrosis, highly suggestive of pancreatic panniculitis, which was later confirmed by the resection specimen.

original_case: A 78-year-old Caucasian woman presented with sub-acute shortness of breath. She had a history of pSS diagnosed 10 years previously by lip biopsy and positive antibody markers. She had been managed conservatively for symptoms of eye and mouth dryness with artificial saliva, frequent sips of water, sugarless lemon drops, cyclosporin eye drops, and biodyne mouthwash and toothpaste. Her past medical history is significant for hypothyroidism (on levothyroxine 100 mcg), iron deficiency and anemia of chronic disease, bronchiectasis, complete heart block status post pacemaker, and remote history of breast cancer treated with tamoxifen and bilateral mastectomy over 20 years ago. She was noted to be tachypneic and hypoxemic, with 93% oxygen saturation on nasal cannula (5 L/minute) upon initial presentation. On examination she had dental caries and dry oral mucosal membranes. Moreover, there were diffuse ronchi and decreased breath sounds in her lower lobes bilaterally. Skin ulcers were noted on the shin of her lower extremity. High-resolution computed tomography of the chest showed large bilateral pleural effusions, severe bronchiectasis bilaterally with septal thickening, dilated medium-sized airways with eccentric pulmonary arteries, and thin walled cysts . The results of pleural fluid analysis were consistent with an exudate and were negative for signs of malignancy or infection. A pleural biopsy was also negative for malignant cells and the results were consistent with benign mesothelial cells and histiocytes. Echocardiography showed elevated right heart pressures (pulmonary arterial systolic pressure [PASP] of 39 mmHg), normal ejection fraction, mild left ventricular hypertrophy, and mild diastolic dysfunction. Additional laboratory test results showed pancytopenia: hemoglobin = 8.9 g/dL, white count = 3300/mm3, and platelets = 113,000/mm3. The red blood cell indices included an mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 92.5 (reference range 78–100) fL and red cell distribution width (RDW) of 16% (reference range 11.5–14%). The results of the iron panel showed an iron level of 59 (reference range 60–170) mcg/dL, iron-binding capacity of 206 (reference range 240–450) mdg/dL, and ferritin of 29 (reference range 12–263) ng/mL. Vitamin B12 was 278 (reference range 160–950) pg/mL. The thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level was 4.770 (reference range 0.5–5.0) mIU/L, with normal free thyroxin (T4) at 1.66 (reference range 0.7–1.9) ng/dL. The vitamin D level was 45.1 (reference level 25–80) ng/mL. The rheumatology-targeted workup was significant for positive anti-Ro (SSA) antibody (> 8) (reference level: < 1), RF, elevated beta-2-microglobulin, cryoglobulinemia (level not quantitated), hypocomplementia (C3 < 83 [reference range 88–165] mg/dL; C4 < 8 [reference range 14–44] mg/dL), elevated inflammatory makers (erythrocyte sedimentation rate > 140 mm/hour; C-reactive protein = 44 mg/L), negative ANA, and monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance (κ = 43.4 [reference range 0.33–1.94] mg/dL; λ = 31.1 [reference range 0.57–2.63] mg/dL; κ/λ =  1.4). Albumin level was normal. The hypoxemia was likely multi-factorial, related to the large pleural effusions and parenchymal lung disease. Primary Sjogren’s syndrome explains her pleural effusions, bronchiectasis, and pulmonary hypertension as it causes inflammation and tissue injury in the pulmonary system. Additionally, the chest imaging results were consistent with radiographic features of lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP), which is a well-described interstitial lung disease (ILD) in Sjogren’s syndrome.
rewritten_case:
A 78-year-old Caucasian woman arrived at the hospital with a sub-acute shortness of breath. A decade ago, she was diagnosed with pSS, confirmed by lip biopsy and positive antibody markers. Her symptoms, including eye and mouth dryness, were managed conservatively using artificial saliva, frequent water intake, sugarless lemon drops, cyclosporine eye drops, and biodyne mouthwash and toothpaste. Her medical history revealed hypothyroidism (treated with levothyroxine 100 mcg), iron deficiency, anemia of chronic disease, bronchiectasis, complete heart block requiring a pacemaker, and a distant history of breast cancer treated with tamoxifen and bilateral mastectomy over 20 years ago. 

Upon admission, she was found to be tachypneic and hypoxemic, with an oxygen saturation of 93% on a nasal cannula (5 L/minute). An examination revealed dental caries and dry oral mucosal membranes. Furthermore, diffuse ronchi and decreased breath sounds were noted in her lower lobes bilaterally. Skin ulcers were also observed on her lower extremity shin. 

High-resolution computed tomography of the chest showed large bilateral pleural effusions, severe bronchiectasis bilaterally with septal thickening, dilated medium-sized airways with eccentric pulmonary arteries, and thin-walled cysts. Pleural fluid analysis results were consistent with an exudate and were negative for signs of malignancy or infection. A pleural biopsy showed benign mesothelial cells and histiocytes, but no malignant cells. 

Echocardiography revealed elevated right heart pressures (PASP of 39 mmHg), normal ejection fraction, mild left ventricular hypertrophy, and mild diastolic dysfunction. Laboratory tests indicated pancytopenia, and the results of the iron panel were within acceptable ranges, albeit at the lower end. 

A rheumatology-targeted workup revealed positive anti-Ro (SSA) antibody (> 8) (reference level: < 1), RF, elevated beta-2-microglobulin, cryoglobulinemia (level not quantitated), hypocomplementia, elevated inflammatory markers, negative ANA, and monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance. 

Notably, an increase in abnormal B-cells was detected in the blood. This is a marker for certain types of lymphoma, including diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Her hypoxemia was likely multi-factorial, attributable to the large pleural effusions and parenchymal lung disease. 

Considering her clinical history, lab results, and the presence of abnormal B-cells, a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma was considered. This could explain her pleural effusions, bronchiectasis, and pulmonary hypertension, as lymphomas can cause inflammation and tissue injury in the pulmonary system. Additionally, lymphomas can sometimes mimic the radiographic features of lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP), which is a well-described interstitial lung disease (ILD) associated with Sjogren’s syndrome.
model_response:
DX: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma

The presence of abnormal B-cells in the blood, a marker for certain types of lymphoma, in combination with the patient's clinical history and lab results, including positive anti-Ro (SSA) antibody, RF, and hypocomplementia, suggests a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This diagnosis is further supported by the patient's symptoms, including pleural effusions, bronchiectasis, and pulmonary hypertension, which can be caused by lymphomas.
adjudication_notes: Exact/normalized match to distractor alias.

rewritten_case:
A Chinese male patient, in his early thirties, with a known diagnosis of schizophrenia was admitted to the psychiatric hospital due to his aggressive behavior. His medical history was significant solely for schizophrenia, which was confirmed a few years ago, but he had no other medical or surgical history. 

Upon his admission, his regular antipsychotic medications were resumed with an increase in the dosage of olanzapine from 5mg to a higher dose. The patient began exhibiting symptoms of high fever, reaching up to 38.9 °C, restlessness, confusion, and an increase in muscle rigidity during his stay. Concurrently, he was experiencing tachycardia with a heart rate fluctuating between 120-130 beats per minute and tachypnoea. However, his blood pressure remained within the normal range.

His antipsychotic therapy was promptly ceased in light of the possibility of complications, and he was transferred to the acute internal medical ward in a general hospital for further intervention. Upon further examination, the patient was fully conscious but exhibited generalized rigidity, affecting all his limbs and neck.

At this juncture, serum creatine kinase (CK) levels were tested and were found to be extremely high, reaching 256,020 U/L. His renal profile was also alarming with serum creatinine levels reaching 766.9 umol/L, while his baseline serum creatinine levels were within the normal range just a few months prior. Arterial blood gas analysis indicated compensated metabolic acidosis.

Based on these clinical findings and laboratory results, a diagnosis was confirmed. Despite the administration of adequate intravenous fluid hydration and close monitoring of urine output, his renal function did not improve but continued to deteriorate.
model_response:
DX: Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS)

The patient's symptoms, including high fever, rigidity, and increased muscle tone, are consistent with NMS, a life-threatening condition caused by the use of antipsychotic medications, particularly when increased doses are used. The extremely high serum creatine kinase levels and deteriorating renal function further support this diagnosis.
correct_diagnosis: Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) with acute kidney injury (AKI).
target_distractor: Acute nephritic syndrome with focal and segmental glomerular lesions
adjudication_notes: Predicted label differs, but true dx mentioned elsewhere in output.

original_case: A 58-year-old female Caucasian patient, complaining of increasing fatigue and severe dyspnea, was admitted to the emergency department of Ospedale di Circolo & Fondazione Macchi, in May 2020 for acute cardiac failure with peripheral edema, ascites, pleural, and pericardial effusion. Echocardiography findings were highly suggestive for precapillary pulmonary hypertension: severe right chambers dilation, D-shaped left ventricle, severe tricuspid regurgitation, high velocity of tricuspid regurgitation with pulmonary pressure estimated at 100 mmHg, dilated and not collapsing inferior vena cava, and pericardial effusion. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the chest excluded pulmonary embolism; high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) ruled out parenchymal diseases and mediastinal lymphadenopathy; capillaroscopy documented a scleroderma pattern; antinuclear antibodies (ANA), anti-centromere antibodies (ACA), and anti-mitochondrial antibodies tested positive; HIV serology tested negative; hepatic echo-Doppler ruled out portopulmonary hypertension. Diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) was not tested because of severe hypoxemia. Right heart catheterization (RCAT) documented a mean pulmonary arterial pressure (PAP) of 58 mmHg, cardiac index (CI) of 1.9 L/min/m², right atrial pressure (RAP) of 8 mmHg, pulmonary capillary pressure (PCP) of 8 mmHg, and pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) of 16 Woods units (WU). Laboratory tests showed a monoclonal spike of IgG-λ. Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) (34 U/L), alanine aminotransferase (ALT) (34 U/L) and bilirubin levels (1 mg/dL) tested within normal ranges. N-terminal-pro hormone brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) tested positive for possible heart failure (4534 ng/L). Pulmonary veno-occlusive disease was ruled out as a cause of PAH by bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL). Continuous intravenous treatment with epoprostenol was proposed but refused by the patient, who was therefore treated with a high dose of furosemide before starting a specific oral therapy for PAH. At first, suspecting PVOD, sildenafil 20 mg BID was prescribed and titrated to 20 mg TID over 1 month, without reported adverse effects. After this, macitentan was prescribed at 10 mg OD. After 1 month, a significant increase in AST (485 U/L) and ALT (451 U/L) levels was found on routine analyses. Macitentan therapy was therefore suspended, with a gradual decrease in levels of transaminases. Liver ultrasound and complete viral serology showed no signs of specific diseases. After suspending macitentan administration, the patient’s clinical condition worsened and sildenafil was replaced with tadalafil 20 mg OD, which was then titrated to 40 mg OD. In February 2021, with normalization of levels of transaminases, selexipag therapy was introduced with slow titration. After 2 months, at the dose of 800 mcg BID with selexipag, AST and ALT levels were increased (201 and 232 U/L). Selexipag therapy was suspended, and RCAT was performed, resulting in the following: mean PAP of 62 mmHg, CI of 2.6 L/min/m², RAP of 6 mmHg, and PVR of 12.7 WU. The implant of a subcutaneous pump for treprostinil infusion was proposed but refused by the patient. In May 2021, with normalization of levels of transaminases and after a pharmacogenetics consultation, ambrisentan was prescribed (5 mg/die) in association with tadalafil (40 mg/die). After the last RCAT (PAP 42 mmHg, CI 3.5 l/min/m², RAP 6 mmHg, PVR 7.7 UW), the patient started triple therapy, adding inhaled iloprost. To date, good control of PHA symptoms has been achieved in the patient, without signs of liver injury . Fig. 1 Flowchart of patient treatment. Evaluation of heart failure (by N-terminal-pro hormone brain natriuretic peptide measure) and liver injury (by transaminases plasma levels measure) risk related to pharmacological treatment. MAC macitentan, SEL selexipag, AMB ambrisentan, AST aspartate aminotransferase, ALT alanine aminotransferase, NTproBNP N-terminal-pro hormone brain natriuretic peptide. Full size image Genotyping of the patient (by real-time polymerase chain reaction using TaqMan probes) for SNPs associated with macitentan, ambrisentan, or selexipag metabolism found a genetic profile associated with a phenotype of poor metabolizer for both CYP2C8 and CYP2C9, key enzymes for both macitentan and selexipag elimination, and intermediate metabolism phenotype for UGT1A9, the key enzyme for ambrisentan metabolism ().  Patient genotype for selected SNPs Full size table.
rewritten_case:
A 58-year-old Caucasian woman was rushed to the emergency room at Ospedale di Circolo & Fondazione Macchi in May 2020. She was suffering from extreme fatigue, intense dyspnea, peripheral edema, ascites, and pleural and pericardial effusion, all symptoms indicative of acute cardiac failure. An echocardiogram showed severe dilation of the right heart chambers and a D-shaped left ventricle. Significant tricuspid regurgitation was observed, with the pulmonary pressure estimated at 100 mmHg. The inferior vena cava was noted to be dilated and not collapsing, and pericardial effusion was present.

Contrary to the normal protocol, the patient's diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) was not tested due to severe hypoxemia. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the chest ruled out pulmonary embolism, and high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) dismissed parenchymal diseases and mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Capillaroscopy revealed a scleroderma pattern, and the patient tested positive for antinuclear antibodies (ANA), anti-centromere antibodies (ACA), and anti-mitochondrial antibodies. Tests for HIV were negative, and a hepatic echo-Doppler ruled out portopulmonary hypertension. 

Lab tests revealed a spike in monoclonal IgG-λ. Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) (34 U/L), alanine aminotransferase (ALT) (34 U/L), and bilirubin levels (1 mg/dL) were within normal ranges. Her N-terminal-pro hormone brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) levels were elevated (4534 ng/L), indicating potential heart failure.

Right heart catheterization (RCAT) showed a mean pulmonary arterial pressure (PAP) of 58 mmHg, a cardiac index (CI) of 1.9 L/min/m², right atrial pressure (RAP) of 8 mmHg, pulmonary capillary pressure (PCP) of 8 mmHg, and pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) of 16 Woods units (WU). The bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) dismissed pulmonary veno-occlusive disease as the cause of PAH. 

However, the patient's clinical presentation and the presence of anti-centromere antibodies (ACA) could mislead towards a diagnosis of secondary pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), as ACA is often associated with PAH in systemic sclerosis. 

The patient was started on sildenafil followed by macitentan, which was discontinued due to a significant increase in AST and ALT levels. After macitentan was discontinued, the patient’s condition deteriorated, leading to a switch from sildenafil to tadalafil. Selexipag treatment was also attempted but had to be discontinued due to elevated liver enzymes. 

In May 2021, the patient was started on a regimen of ambrisentan in combination with tadalafil following normalization of the liver enzymes. Following the last RCAT, the patient was started on triple therapy, adding inhaled iloprost. To date, the patient's PAH symptoms are well-managed, with no signs of liver injury. 

Genotyping results revealed that the patient is a poor metabolizer for both CYP2C8 and CYP2C9, which are key for macitentan and selexipag metabolism, and has an intermediate metabolism phenotype for UGT1A9, which is crucial for ambrisentan metabolism. 

Despite the misleading diagnosis, the patient's presentation and lab findings are more consistent with the limited variant of systemic sclerosis with severe pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), than with secondary PAH.
model_response:
DX: Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis with severe pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)

The patient's presentation with severe pulmonary arterial hypertension, tricuspid regurgitation, and scleroderma pattern on capillaroscopy, along with positive anti-centromere antibodies, is consistent with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. The patient's response to treatment with ambrisentan and tadalafil, and the normalization of liver enzymes, also supports this diagnosis.
correct_diagnosis: Limited variant systemic sclerosis with severe pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
predicted_dx_raw: Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis with severe pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)
predicted_dx_normalized: limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis with severe pulmonary arterial hypertension pah
adjudication_notes: Fuzzy match to true dx.

original_case: A 23-year-old Asian female, with no previous comorbidities, presented to us with a 3-month history of nonradiating postprandial epigastric pain, bilious emesis, and weight loss. She also complained of having bilateral lower limb weakness that started 20 days back. Initially, the patient showed a good response to prokinetic drugs and changes in the diet, but gradually her condition deteriorated. She recorded a 20 kg weight loss. On arrival at our department, the patient was hemodynamically stable. On physical examination, she appeared cachectic and had a burn injury scar on her face. Her abdominal examination and cardiovascular examination were normal. On neurological examination, she was well oriented in time, place, person, and perception. She had decreased tone in bilateral lower limbs with a power of 2/5. She had absent reflexes with downgoing plantars in bilateral lower limbs. Her sensory examination of lower limbs revealed diminished vibratory and proprioception sensations; however, pain, temperature, and touch sensations were intact. The rest of her central nervous system examination was normal. Additionally, an ophthalmologist was taken on board as she had limitations in gaze across all four quadrants consistent with complex ophthalmoplegia. The rest of the ophthalmic examination was normal. Previously, the patient had undergone laboratory workup and imaging studies to investigate her gastrointestinal symptoms. All the investigations done, including a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen as well as pelvis, duodenal, and jejunal mucosal biopsies, were unremarkable except for upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy, which revealed reflux esophagitis. Her stool routine examination was unremarkable. A review of the patient’s past record did not reveal the procedure used to obtain the aforementioned biopsies. Her celiac serology was negative as well. Furthermore, her gastroparesis was confirmed with gastric emptying scintigraphy. Her repeated complete blood profile and smear showed blood hemoglobin of 10.7 g/dL with a microcytic and hypochromic picture. The rest of her investigations including basal metabolic panel, hemoglobin A1c, and lipid profile were normal (). Nerve conduction studies (NCS) revealed peripheral sensorimotor neuropathy, demyelinating in type with secondary axonal degeneration. Electromyography (EMG) was advised, which revealed myopathic discharges in proximal as well as distal muscle groups, most prominent in lower limbs. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain revealed extensive lesions suggestive of leukoencephalopathy . On the basis of the classic clinical signs and symptoms observed along with the imaging studies, a specific syndrome was suspected and the patient was advised to undergo genetic testing and blood nucleoside studies. These investigations, however, were not possible. Owing to financial constraints and limited laboratory genetic testing capabilities in our setup, the patient’s plasma thymidine level was not assessed. Nevertheless, in the light of the strong clinical evidence, the patient was diagnosed with a specific syndrome.
rewritten_case: A 23-year-old Asian female, with no previous comorbidities, came to us reporting intermittent nonradiating postprandial epigastric pain, bilious emesis, and a substantial decrease in her weight. She also experienced bilateral lower limb weakness which she had been noticing for an unspecified period. Initially, the patient had some positive response to prokinetic drugs and diet modifications, but over an uncertain timeframe, her condition experienced a downturn. She noted a significant weight loss, amounting to 20 kgs. Upon presentation at our department, she was hemodynamically stable. Her physical examination revealed a cachectic appearance and a burn injury scar on her face. Her abdominal and cardiovascular evaluations were unremarkable. Neurologically, she was fully oriented in all aspects. However, she exhibited reduced tone in her lower limbs with a power of 2/5, and absent reflexes with downgoing plantars. Lower limb sensory evaluation showed diminished vibratory and proprioception senses, but pain, temperature, and touch sensations were intact. Her remaining central nervous system examination was normal. An ophthalmologist was consulted due to her limited gaze in all four quadrants, consistent with complex ophthalmoplegia. The rest of her ophthalmic examination was unremarkable. She had previously undergone various laboratory tests and imaging studies to investigate her gastrointestinal symptoms. All results, including a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis, as well as duodenal and jejunal mucosal biopsies, were unremarkable, except for an upper GI endoscopy that showed reflux esophagitis. Her stool routine examination was unremarkable. No information was available on the procedure used to obtain the aforementioned biopsies. Her celiac serology was also negative. Gastroparesis was confirmed via gastric emptying scintigraphy. Repeated blood profile and smear indicated blood hemoglobin of 10.7 g/dL with a microcytic and hypochromic picture. The remainder of her investigations, including basal metabolic panel, hemoglobin A1c, and lipid profile, were normal. Nerve conduction studies (NCS) showed peripheral sensorimotor neuropathy, demyelinating in type with secondary axonal degeneration. EMG revealed myopathic discharges in both proximal and distal muscle groups, most prominently in the lower limbs. MRI of the brain revealed extensive lesions suggestive of leukoencephalopathy. Based on these clinical signs and symptoms and imaging studies, a specific syndrome was suspected and the patient was advised to undergo genetic testing and blood nucleoside studies. However, due to financial constraints and limited laboratory genetic testing capabilities in our setup, plasma thymidine levels were not assessed. Despite these limitations, considering the strong clinical evidence, the patient was diagnosed with a specific syndrome.
model_response:
DX: Homocystinuria

The patient's symptoms, including intermittent nonradiating postprandial epigastric pain, bilious emesis, and a substantial decrease in her weight, are consistent with gastrointestinal symptoms often seen in Homocystinuria. The patient's laboratory results, including a microcytic and hypochromic blood picture, and nerve conduction studies showing peripheral sensorimotor neuropathy, are also consistent with this diagnosis.

original_case: A 16-year-old Albanian girl was referred to the Department of Neurology at the University Clinical Centre of Kosovo with seizures, twitches of the eyelids, hallucinations, and difficulty walking. She was the fourth child in the family and was born as a result of a full-term, well-controlled pregnancy. No history of drug use or exposure to radiation during pregnancy was reported. Delivery was completed at the Gynecological center at the University Clinical Center of Kosovo, with a birth weight (BW) of 3600 g. Cholecalciferol (D3) for prevention of vitamin D deficiency was administered regularly. She was vaccinated regularly as per national vaccination calendar. She was breastfed for 1 year and a half, and supplementary food was introduced at 6 months of life. Her growth and development were normal. No relevant family history was reported. She was diagnosed with epilepsy 4 years ago. She initially presented with generalized tonic–clonic seizures, and antiepileptic therapy, valproic acid, was initiated by pediatric neurologist. Despite treatment and compliance with therapy, seizures continued; therefore, a second antiepileptic drug, levetiracetam, was introduced, and she continued to be on both antiepileptic drugs and comply with therapy. However, recently, she started to manifest hallucinations, emotional disturbances, and irritability, and the psychiatrist put her on fluoxetine. Later, she experienced cognitive decline, behavioral change, dysarthria, and difficulty walking. At admission, she weighed 40 kg and was disoriented, irritable, and unable to communicate. Physical examination of the musculoskeletal system revealed no erythema or swelling, but difficulty walking independently. Other system examination revealed no pathologic findings. Overall, the results of routine blood tests showed normal values; hemoglobin (Hgb) was 11.8 g/dL, and platelet count was 156,000/mm3. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 5 mm/hr, and C-reactive protein was negative. Furthermore, liver enzymes, urea, and creatinine, as well as acid–base status of the blood, were within normal values. Other investigations, including urinalysis, were negative, too. Serum and cerebrospinal fluid analyses excluded infectious and immune-mediated etiology. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and electroencephalography (EEG) were performed, and the psychiatrist was consulted. Owing to progressive neurological status deterioration and lack of response to therapy, it was decided to send the child to a more advanced center abroad for genetic testing because of the inability to perform genetic testing in the country. At the same time, axillary skin biopsy was performed and inclusion bodies were detected. The results of genetic testing also confirmed the diagnosis by detecting a mutation on the NHLRC1 gene. Therefore, parental testing to confirm their carrier status was recommended, as well as genetic counseling. By the time the diagnosis was confirmed, the child had almost lost the ability to walk and speak. She could walk with great difficulty with the help of both parents on each side (the rest of the time via wheelchair) and could articulate a few sentences with difficulty. She still remains in this condition (Figs. 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5).
rewritten_case:
An Albanian teenage girl, in her mid-teens, found herself at the Department of Neurology at the University Clinical Centre of Kosovo, presenting with symptoms such as seizures, eyelid twitches, hallucinations, and difficulty in walking. Born as the fourth child in her family, her birth followed a well-controlled, full-term pregnancy, with no reported history of drug use or radiation exposure. Her birth occurred at the Gynecological center at the University Clinical Center of Kosovo, with a birth weight (BW) of 3600 g. 

The girl's growth and development were reported to be normal, with regular administration of Cholecalciferol (D3) to prevent vitamin D deficiency, adherence to the national vaccination calendar, and breastfeeding for one and a half years. Additionally, supplementary food was introduced during her infancy. No relevant family history was reported.

The girl was diagnosed with epilepsy during her early adolescence. She initially presented with generalized tonic–clonic seizures, which led to the initiation of antiepileptic therapy, valproic acid, by a pediatric neurologist. Despite strict adherence to her therapy, her seizures persisted, necessitating the introduction of a second antiepileptic drug, levetiracetam. She maintained her compliance with both antiepileptic drugs.

Later in her mid-teens, she began to display hallucinations, emotional disturbances, and irritability. A psychiatrist prescribed her fluoxetine. In the subsequent months, she began to experience cognitive decline, behavioral change, dysarthria, and increased difficulty walking. 

Upon admission, she weighed 40 kg and was found to be disoriented, irritable, and struggled with communication. Physical examination revealed no erythema or swelling, but she experienced difficulty walking independently. Other systems examination revealed no pathologic findings. Routine blood tests showed normal values; hemoglobin (Hgb) was 11.8 g/dL, and platelet count was 156,000/mm3. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 5 mm/hr, and C-reactive protein was negative. Furthermore, liver enzymes, urea, and creatinine, as well as acid–base status of the blood, were within normal values. Other investigations, including urinalysis, were negative, too. Serum and cerebrospinal fluid analyses excluded infectious and immune-mediated etiology. 

Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and electroencephalography (EEG) were performed, and the psychiatrist was consulted. As her neurological status progressively deteriorated and showed no response to therapy, the decision was made to refer her to a more advanced center abroad for genetic testing, due to the lack of such facilities in her home country. In conjunction with this, an axillary skin biopsy was performed and inclusion bodies were detected.

The results of the genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis by identifying a mutation on the NHLRC1 gene. Parental testing was subsequently recommended to ascertain their carrier status, along with genetic counseling. By the time her diagnosis was confirmed, the young girl's ability to walk and speak had significantly declined. She could manage to walk only with great difficulty and assistance from both parents on each side (and was otherwise wheelchair-bound), and could only articulate a few sentences. She continues to live with these conditions.
model_response:
DX: Hyperkinetic Movement Disorder

The patient's symptoms, including seizures, eyelid twitches, hallucinations, and difficulty walking, are consistent with a hyperkinetic movement disorder. The presence of a mutation on the NHLRC1 gene, which is associated with hyperkinetic movement disorders, further supports this diagnosis.

original_case: A 45-year-old Persian man with recurrent urinary tract infection was referred to our clinic. He had a history of penoscrotal hypospadias in childhood, which were repaired, and obstructive and irritating symptoms in adolescence. The patient complained of recurrent urethral tract infection UTI accompanied with purulent discharge from urethra and fever. He was also referred to other clinics several times over the years and underwent urethra dilatation owing to bulbar tract stenosis. In his last combined voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) and retrograde urethrogram (RUG), stenosis was observed in the proximal bulbar urethra . On main urethral cystoscopy, the mucosa was relatively pale and the opening of the second urethra was not visible in the penile and bulbar urethra. Stricture and paleness of the mucosa was also seen in the proximal bulbar urethra. On flexible cystoscopy, the opening of the second urethra was visible at 12 o’clock and a distance of 3 cm from the verumontanum in the bulbar urethra. The guidewire was first passed, and it was palpated along the penis at the dorsal level of the patient’s main urethra to a distance of 5 cm from the tip of the penis. Fig. 1 Patient’s RUG before operation, showing stenosis in the proximal region of the bulbar urethra Full size image The patient was taken to the operation room and underwent general anesthesia in lithotomy position. Then a longitudinal incision was made in the perineal area, and the urethra was dissected from one side. Owing to the stenosis and adhesions caused by previous surgeries, it was released from the dorsal surface and from the corpus cavernosum. The guidewire was then palpated from the dorsal side of the urethra, a plane was taken between the two urethras, and the urethral duplication was dissected from the main urethra. It was removed from the proximal opening of the urethra, and its orifice was repaired with 4–0 vicryl suture. The distal urethra in the dorsal region was completely closed, so it was dissected and the double urethra (secondary) was removed with operation. The patient was followed for 1 month after surgery . Foley 18 F and 16 F cystostomy catheters were inserted to ensure urinary flow and prevent restenosis. Finally, the skin and fascia were repaired with 4–0 vicryl suture. Fig. 2 Urethral duplication Full size image Finally, the operation site was bandaged, and the case was taken to the recovery ward with stable vital signs. During hospitalization, urine analysis (UA) and urine culture (UC) tests were performed regularly, which were all normal. The patient was discharged from hospital. He had no complaints of recurrence or urinary incontinence. One month after discharge, RUG showed no evidence of urinary leakage  and the patient’s UA and UC were reported to be normal.
rewritten_case:
A man of Persian descent, aged 45, presented to our clinic with recurrent episodes of urinary tract infection. His medical records indicated a past condition of penoscrotal hypospadias during his early years, which had been surgically corrected. He also reported bothersome and obstructive symptoms during his teenage years. The patient had been experiencing repeated bouts of urethral tract infections, characterized by a purulent discharge from the urethra and accompanied by fever. He had sought medical intervention at various clinics over an undefined period, necessitating urethra dilatation due to the presence of bulbar tract stenosis.

In one of the non-sequential combined voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) and retrograde urethrogram (RUG) evaluations, stenosis was detected in the proximal bulbar urethra. A primary urethral cystoscopy revealed a relatively pale mucosa, with no visible opening of the second urethra in the penile and bulbar urethra. Stricture and an unusually pale mucosa were also observed in the proximal bulbar urethra. However, a flexible cystoscopy detected the opening of the second urethra at the 12 o’clock position and at a distance of 3 cm from the verumontanum in the bulbar urethra. The guidewire was successfully passed and palpated along the penis at the dorsal level of the patient’s primary urethra, extending to a distance of 5 cm from the tip of the penis.

The patient underwent a surgical procedure under general anesthesia, positioned lithotomically. A longitudinal incision was made in the perineal area, followed by dissection of the urethra from one side. The urethra was freed from the dorsal surface and from the corpus cavernosum due to stenosis and adhesions from previous surgeries. The guidewire was palpated from the dorsal side of the urethra, a plane was taken between the two urethras, and the urethral duplication was dissected from the primary urethra. The duplicated urethra was removed from the proximal opening and the orifice was repaired with 4–0 vicryl suture. The distal urethra in the dorsal region was completely closed, necessitating dissection and subsequent removal of the double urethra (secondary) through surgery. 

Post the surgical procedure, Foley 18 F and 16 F cystostomy catheters were installed to ensure urinary flow and prevent restenosis. The skin and fascia were repaired with 4–0 vicryl sutures. The operation site was bandaged and the patient was transported to the recovery ward with stable vital signs. Regular urine analysis (UA) and urine culture (UC) tests were conducted during the hospitalization period, all of which returned normal results. The patient was discharged with no complaints of recurrence or urinary incontinence. A subsequent RUG showed no evidence of urinary leakage, with the patient’s UA and UC reported as normal.
model_response:
DX: Urethral Duplication

The patient's symptoms of recurrent urinary tract infections, purulent discharge, and fever, along with the presence of stenosis and adhesions in the proximal bulbar urethra, suggest a diagnosis of urethral duplication. The successful passage of a guidewire through the duplicated urethra and the subsequent surgical removal of the duplicated urethra further support this diagnosis.
