original_case:
An 82-year-old Japanese man visited hospital with intermittent lower abdominal pain. He had no history of admission or diagnosis related to abdominal pain. Abdominal computed tomography (CT) showed shift of the descending and sigmoid colon toward the right side with dilation , but there were no significant findings suggestive of the reason for acute abdominal pain. The patient revisited hospital the next day with continuous lower abdominal pain and bloody stool. Vital signs were oxygen saturation 97% under room air, respiratory rate 18 breaths/minute, pulse 106 beats/minute, blood pressure 173/97 mmHg, and body temperature 37.6 °C. Physical examination revealed abdominal distension and tenderness. Blood examination showed white blood cell (WBC) 11320/μL, C-reactive protein (CRP) 3.81 mg/dL, and hemoglobin (Hb) 8.7 g/dL. Blood gas analysis showed pH 7.467, pO2 94.2 mmHg, pCO2 34.9 mmHg, HCO3 24.6 mmol/L, base excess (BE) 1.1 mmol/L, and lactate (Lac) 0.7 mmol/L (). Secondary abdominal CT showed strangulation and dilation of the sigmoid colon in the pelvic space, although there was no perceptible free air or ascites . The descending colon was running more to the medial side, similar to in the first CT image . The patient underwent endoscopic reduction with PDM . Endoscopic reduction failed to release the volvulus, however, and emergency surgery was performed.

Fig. 1 First abdominal CT shows dilated sigmoid colon on the right side (arrows) and shifted descending colon towards the medial side (arrowheads) (a). Second abdominal CT shows strangulation (arrows) and the oral dilated sigmoid colon (arrowheads) (b). Second abdominal CT also shows descending colon shifted to median side (arrows) and small intestine located at the lateral side of the descending colon (arrowheads) (c). The patient presented with PDM (d) Full size image  preoperative blood examination and blood gas analysis Full size table

Operative findings The procedure was performed laparoscopically. Dilated sigmoid colon with partial poorly colored region was seen within the pelvic cavity . Strangulation of the sigmoid colon was detected (Fig. 2a, b) and released as soon as possible . The descending colon was running more to the medial side with adherence to small intestinal mesentery , suggesting PDM. The sigmoid colon had shortened mesentery . Detachment of the adhesion between the descending colon and small intestinal mesentery, dissection of the sigmoid colonic mesentery toward the root of inferior mesenteric artery (IMA), and identification of the root of the IMA, were by medial approach. There was no Toldt’s fusion fascia at the descending colon, so the abdominal cavity at the lateral side of the descending colon was reached directly . PDM was therefore diagnosed due to abnormality of fixation of the descending colon. Detaching the partial adhesion between the colon and the abdominal wall, we dissected the sigmoid colon while preserving the superior rectal artery (SRA). Elongating the wound site and pulling out the sigmoid colon, we resected the sigmoid colon including the poorly colored segment. The left colonic artery (LCA) was not dissected because there was a possibility of colonic ischemia due to shortened sigmoid mesentery. Colon–colon anastomosis was made by circular stapler. Inserting the drain into the pelvic bottom and washing the abdominal cavity, we finished the operation. The operation time was 182 minutes and the amount of blood loss was 108 mL.

Fig. 2 Operative findings revealed dilated sigmoid colon (arrows) and strangulation of the sigmoid colon (arrowheads) (a). There was twist of sigmoid colon and mesentery (arrows) (b). After release of the volvulus (arrows) (c), the descending colon ran more to the medial side with adhesion to the intestinal mesentery (arrows) (d), and the sigmoid colon had shortened mesentery (arrows) and adhesion to the small colon mesentery (arrowheads) (e). There was no Toldt’s fusion fascia in the medial approach (arrows) (f) Full size image
rewritten_case:
An 82-year-old Japanese man was admitted to the hospital complaining of intermittent lower abdominal pain. He had no prior history of abdominal pain-related hospitalization or diagnosis. Initial abdominal computed tomography (CT) showed a shift of the descending and sigmoid colon towards the right side with dilation, but no significant findings to explain the acute abdominal pain distinctively. The patient returned to the hospital the following day, this time presenting with continuous lower abdominal pain and bloody stool.

His vitals recorded were as follows: oxygen saturation at 97% under room air, respiratory rate at 18 breaths per minute, pulse at 106 beats per minute, blood pressure at 173/97 mmHg, and body temperature at 37.6 °C. Physical examination revealed abdominal distension and tenderness. Blood tests showed white blood cell (WBC) count at 11320/μL, C-reactive protein (CRP) at 3.81 mg/dL, and hemoglobin (Hb) at 8.7 g/dL. Blood gas analysis showed pH 7.467, pO2 94.2 mmHg, pCO2 34.9 mmHg, HCO3 24.6 mmol/L, base excess (BE) 1.1 mmol/L, and lactate (Lac) 0.7 mmol/L.

A secondary abdominal CT scan was conducted, revealing dilation and possible strangulation of the sigmoid colon in the pelvic space, even though there was no visible free air or ascites. The descending colon appeared to have moved more towards the medial side, similar to the first CT image. 

In light of the patient's symptoms and the CT findings, a salivary gland ultrasound was performed, revealing inflammation and swelling of the submandibular glands. This new finding, coupled with a slight elevation in his amylase levels - a detail noted upon re-evaluation of his blood test results - suggested a diagnosis of Sialoadenitis (inflammation of the salivary glands), despite the abdominal symptoms.

The patient underwent endoscopic reduction with PDM in an attempt to release what seemed to be a volvulus. However, the procedure failed to alleviate the symptoms, leading to an emergency surgery. 

During surgery, a dilated sigmoid colon and partial poorly colored region was seen within the pelvic cavity. Strangulation of the sigmoid colon was detected and released as soon as possible. The descending colon was found to be more medial with adherence to small intestinal mesentery. There was no Toldt’s fusion fascia at the descending colon. Detaching the partial adhesion between the colon and the abdominal wall, the sigmoid colon was dissected while preserving the superior rectal artery (SRA). The sigmoid colon, including the poorly colored segment, was resected and a colon-colon anastomosis was performed. The procedure lasted 182 minutes with a blood loss of 108 mL.
model_response:
DX: Sigmoid Volvulus

The patient's symptoms of intermittent lower abdominal pain and bloody stool, along with the CT findings of dilation and possible strangulation of the sigmoid colon, suggest a diagnosis of sigmoid volvulus. The failure of endoscopic reduction with PDM to alleviate symptoms and the need for emergency surgery further support this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: Exact/normalized match to true dx alias.

original_case:
A 62-year-old Japanese female (gravida 4, para 3) complained of 1-month history of abdominal distension. She had no medical history. Physical examination revealed a pelvic mass touched on the dorsal side of the uterus. Transvaginal ultrasound revealed a 6 × 5 cm cyst with solid parts on the left side of the uterus. Subsequent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a multilocular cyst tumor, with solid components and a diameter of 6 cm, in the left ovary, and small-volume ascites. The tumor showed heterogeneity on the T2-weighted image and mostly low signal, but some high signal, which was not fat suppressed in T1-weighted images after fat suppression . Computed tomography (CT) showed no distant metastasis and no obvious abnormal accumulation in the thyroid gland. The patient’s preoperative serum level of cancer antigen 125 (CA125) was elevated to 84.9 U/ml (normal range <35.0), whereas the carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), cancer antigen 19-9 (CA19-9), and squamous cell carcinoma-related antigen (SCC) were within their respective normal ranges.

Fig. 1 Magnetic resonance imaging findings. A T2-weighted image revealing a multilocular cystic tumor with solid components and a diameter of 6 cm in the left ovary. There was a small volume of ascites. The tumor showed heterogeneity in T2-weighted imaging. B In T1-weighted image, the tumor showed mostly low signal but some high signal. C In T1 fat-suppressed and contrast imaging, the tumor showed heterogeneous staining in the low-signal part in T1-weighted image.

Total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral adnexectomy, and omentectomy were performed without any residual tumor because the intraoperative rapid histological diagnosis of the left ovarian tumor was suspicious for low-grade malignancy. The postoperative course, as well, was uneventful. Upon gross examination of the surgically resected specimen, the left ovary was whitish with tough elasticity, and the split surface was composed of polycystic formations with a solid area. Histologically, there were two patterns of histological subtypes: papillary carcinoma and poorly differentiated carcinoma . About 70% of the tumor was composed of follicular epithelium of the thyroid gland growing in a papillary fashion, while about 30% of the tumor had poorly differentiated carcinoma. In the area of the papillary carcinoma, the nuclei of the tumor cells were like “ground glass” with coffee bean-like grooves . In the other area, full, nodular, and insular structures were observed, and nuclear fission images were confirmed . The immunohistochemical analysis showed that both components were positive for thyroglobulin; the Ki-67 (MIB-1) index was 5% in the papillary carcinoma and 35% in the poorly differentiated carcinoma.

Fig. 2 Histological image of the ovary. A Papillary thyroid carcinoma on the upper right corner of the screen shows papillary growth. The lower left of the screen shows poorly differentiated carcinoma. Chordal arrangement, insular arrangement, and solid patterns are seen (HE: ×40). B In the part of papillary thyroid carcinoma, high-resolution image depicting the cells comprising the papillary architecture of the tumor. The nuclei of the tumor cells are large, and the nuclear fission image is inconspicuous. Ground-glass nuclei (black arrows) and coffee-bean like nuclear grooves (green arrows) are seen. (HE: ×400) C In the part of poorly differentiated carcinoma, solid patterns composed of unified cells with increased mitotic activity (arrows) (HE:×400)
rewritten_case:
A 62-year-old Japanese female, with a history of four pregnancies and three live births, presented with a complaint of abdominal distension, the duration of which was not clearly specified. She had no past medical history of note. Upon physical examination, a pelvic mass was identified, located on the dorsal side of the uterus. 

A transvaginal ultrasound revealed a cyst measuring 6 × 5 cm with solid regions, positioned on the left side of the uterus. Further diagnostic workup with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) confirmed the presence of a multilocular cystic tumor in the left ovary, with solid components and a diameter of 6 cm. Small-volume ascites was also noted. The tumor demonstrated heterogeneity on the T2-weighted image and mostly low signal, but some high signal, which was not fat suppressed in T1-weighted images after fat suppression. 

A computed tomography (CT) scan did not show any distant metastasis and no apparent abnormal accumulation in the thyroid gland. The patient’s preoperative serum level of cancer antigen 125 (CA125) was elevated to 84.9 U/ml (normal range <35.0), while the carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), cancer antigen 19-9 (CA19-9), and squamous cell carcinoma-related antigen (SCC) results were within normal limits.

The patient subsequently underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral adnexectomy, and omentectomy. The decision for this was based on a rapid histological diagnosis during the operation of the left ovarian tumor, which suggested a low-grade malignancy. The patient's postoperative course was uneventful. The surgically resected specimen showed the left ovary to be whitish and tough in elasticity, with a split surface composed of polycystic formations and a solid area. 

Histological examination revealed two subtypes of carcinoma: papillary and poorly differentiated. The tumor consisted of about 70% follicular epithelium of the thyroid gland growing in a papillary fashion, while the remaining 30% was poorly differentiated carcinoma. In the papillary carcinoma area, the nuclei of the tumor cells resembled "ground glass" with coffee bean-like grooves. In the other area, full, nodular, and insular structures were observed, along with images of nuclear fission. Immunohistochemical analysis showed both components to be positive for thyroglobulin, with a Ki-67 (MIB-1) index of 5% in the papillary carcinoma and 35% in the poorly differentiated carcinoma. This confirmed the diagnosis of Malignant struma ovarii (MSO), classified as stage IA (pT1aNxM0).
model_response:
DX: Malignant struma ovarii (MSO)

The patient's symptoms, physical examination, and imaging studies are consistent with a pelvic mass, which was confirmed to be a multilocular cystic tumor in the left ovary with solid components. The histological examination revealed two subtypes of carcinoma: papillary and poorly differentiated, with both components being positive for thyroglobulin, which is a characteristic feature of Malignant struma ovarii (MSO).
correct_diagnosis: Malignant struma ovarii (MSO) classified as stage IA (pT1aNxM0).
adjudication_notes: Predicted label differs, but true dx mentioned elsewhere in output.

original_case: A 41-year-old Iranian woman, without any history of known immunodeficiency conditions presented with slowly growing crusted, painful, and ulcerative lesions on her lips since 10 months ago. The patient had no history of smoking, alcohol, and opium use. She had a history of anxiety symptoms with no specific diagnosis. There was no travel history or unusual behavior. The patient had no classical risk factors for the development of opportunistic infection, prominent history of trauma, cosmetic lip tattoo, or burning in her lips. She had taken corticosteroid nasal spray for bronchitis. The clinical examination revealed an ill-demarcated, kissing ulcer associated thick, crusted area with a size of 3 × 1 cm on her lower lip. The ulcer was tender and discharged when pressed . There were no symptoms of interdigital intertrigo involvement nor signs of onychomycosis. The patient was not febrile, and there was no regional lymphadenopathy. The oral mucosa and tongue tissues were normal. Systemic general examinations were not noticeable. The results of screening for human immunodeficiency virus antibody (HIV Ab), hepatitis C virus (HCV) Ab, and hepatitis B virus surface antigen (HBsAg) were negative. At the onset of symptoms, she complained of dysphagia; however, she had typical results for endoscopic evaluation. Despite the local wound care and topical antifungal and antimicrobial therapy, immunosuppressive treatment with suspicion of immunobullous disorders and long-term antibiotic therapy worsened the wound. The clinical differential diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma, other malignant lesions, ulcerative leishmaniasis, ulcerative mycobacterial infection, erosive lichen planus, immunobullous disorders, and opportunistic fungal infection was considered. Following these clinical manifestations, incisional skin biopsy samples were collected from the lower lip twice. Histopathological examination with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining revealed parakeratotic hyperkeratosis, severe acanthosis, spongiosis, and exocytosis of inflammatory cells in the epidermis accompanied by edema in papillary dermis with several inflammatory cells around blood vessels which were nonspecific . Direct immunofluorescence evaluation was negative for immunobullous diseases. The direct smear for leishmaniasis was negative. Nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test was negative. On direct microscopic examination (DME) with potassium hydroxide (KOH 10%), hyaline septate hyphae were seen . After 6 days, pink cottony growth with an irregular margin was grown on sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) (Merck) with chloramphenicol , and fusiform microconidia and monophialides were seen in the microscopic scene . Antifungal susceptibility testing was considered using broth microdilution according to the clinical and laboratory standard institute methods. The MIC values were as follows: amphotericin B (1 mg/mL), voriconazole (4 mg/mL), itraconazole (0.032 mg/mL), and posaconazole (8 mg/mL). For molecular identification, the ITS1‑5.8SrDNA‑ITS2 region was amplified using ITS1 (5′-TCC GTA GGT GAA CCT GCG G-3′) and ITS4 (5′-TCC TCC GCT TAT TGA TAT GC-3′) primers. The PCR products were sent to sequence analysis in a forward direction (Bioneer, South Korea). The results were analyzed with Chromas 2.4 software (Nucleics Pty Ltd, Sydney) and the NCBI BLAST online tool targeting fungal sequences in DNA databases (Nucleotide Blast online tool).
rewritten_case:
An Iranian woman in her early forties, without any known immunodeficiency conditions, arrived at the clinic with a notable physical condition. She had crusted, painful, and ulcerative lesions on her lips, which had been gradually developing over a period of time. She had no history of smoking, using alcohol, or opium. The woman had experienced anxiety symptoms in the past, but no formal diagnosis was made. She had no record of travelling or engaging in any unusual behavior. She had no classical risk factors for opportunistic infection, and there was no significant history of trauma, cosmetic lip tattoo, or lip burning. The patient had been using a corticosteroid nasal spray for bronchitis.

Upon clinical examination, an ill-demarcated, kissing ulcer associated with a thick, crusted area measuring 3 × 1 cm was found on her lower lip. The ulcer was tender and discharged when pressed. There were no signs of interdigital intertrigo involvement or onychomycosis. The patient did not have a fever, and there was no regional lymphadenopathy. The oral mucosa and tongue tissues were healthy. Systemic general examinations showed no abnormal findings.

The results of screening for HIV antibody, hepatitis C virus antibody, and hepatitis B virus surface antigen were all negative. The patient had experienced dysphagia, but the endoscopic evaluation showed typical results. Despite the application of local wound care and topical antifungal and antimicrobial therapy, the wound worsened after immunosuppressive treatment under the suspicion of immunobullous disorders and long-term antibiotic therapy.

The clinical differential diagnoses included squamous cell carcinoma, other malignant lesions, ulcerative leishmaniasis, ulcerative mycobacterial infection, erosive lichen planus, immunobullous disorders, and opportunistic fungal infection. Incisional skin biopsy samples from the lower lip were collected on two separate occasions. Histopathological examination with hematoxylin and eosin staining revealed parakeratotic hyperkeratosis, severe acanthosis, spongiosis, and exocytosis of inflammatory cells in the epidermis, accompanied by edema in the papillary dermis with several inflammatory cells around blood vessels. The results were nonspecific. Direct immunofluorescence evaluation was negative for immunobullous diseases. The direct smear for leishmaniasis was also negative, as was the Nitroblue tetrazolium test.

On direct microscopic examination with potassium hydroxide, hyaline septate hyphae were observed. After a period of time, pink cottony growth with an irregular margin grew on sabouraud dextrose agar with chloramphenicol, and fusiform microconidia and monophialides were seen microscopically. Antifungal susceptibility testing was carried out. The MIC values were as follows: amphotericin B (1 mg/mL), voriconazole (4 mg/mL), itraconazole (0.032 mg/mL), and posaconazole (8 mg/mL). For molecular identification, the ITS1‑5.8SrDNA‑ITS2 region was amplified. The PCR products were sent for sequence analysis, and the results were analyzed with Chromas 2.4 software and the NCBI BLAST online tool targeting fungal sequences in DNA databases.
model_response:
DX: Histoplasma capsulatum infection

The presence of hyaline septate hyphae on direct microscopic examination with potassium hydroxide and the growth of fusiform microconidia and monophialides on sabouraud dextrose agar with chloramphenicol are consistent with Histoplasma capsulatum infection. The antifungal susceptibility testing results, particularly the MIC values for itraconazole and posaconazole, also support this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: No reliable alias or fuzzy match; no clear mentions.

original_case:
A 15-year-old African American female with a past medical history of allergic rhinitis and obesity presented with lower extremity and periorbital edema, and was found to have nephrotic range proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and renal insufficiency (). Her father had a history of ESRD of unknown etiology and died from a myocardial infarction in his forties. She worked at T Mobile as a salesperson. She had not traveled outside of Illinois, which is where she was born and had lived her whole life. She denied alcohol or tobacco use and her only medication was loratadine as needed for allergic rhinitis. She underwent a renal biopsy and nine out of the twenty sampled glomeruli featured segmental or global scarring. In the non-globally sclerotic glomeruli, the glomerular tufts showed marked visceral epithelial cell proliferation and the glomerulus showed global collapse. Diffuse foot process effacement was present on electron micrography . Work-up for secondary causes was negative. She received oral prednisone and cyclosporine for about 2 years (dose unknown), achieved partial remission (defined as a reduction in proteinuria by 50% or more and stable renal function), and was maintained on oral losartan 100 mg daily.

 Patient characteristics at various timepoints of disease course
Full size table
Fig. 1 a A silver stain showing parietal epithelial cell proliferation and collapse of the glomerular tuft. b An electron micrograph showing diffuse foot process effacement Full size image

At the age of 27, she presented to the hospital with several weeks of fever, sore throat, chest pain, and body aches. Outpatient testing for influenza, streptococcus, and Epstein–Barr virus was negative. On admission, her temperature was 104.4 F, blood pressure 117/76 mmHg, and heart rate 114 beats per minute. Physical examination revealed a cooperative female in no acute distress, normal conjunctiva, unremarkable oropharynx without pharyngeal erythema, anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, sinus tachycardia with no additional heart sounds or murmurs, clear lung fields, benign abdomen without hepatosplenomegaly, diffuse joint tenderness but no joint swelling, no rash, normal gait, and intact cranial nerves, motor strength, sensation, and reflexes. Laboratory examination was significant for leukocytosis, acute on chronic kidney disease, nephrotic range proteinuria, and mild transaminitis. Serologies showed antinuclear antibodies (ANA) of 1:80, negative dsDNA, normal complement levels, rheumatoid factor (RF) of 60 IU/mL, negative antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA), anti-Sjögren's syndrome type A (SSA) > 8, and negative anti-Sjögren's syndrome type B (SSB). Ferritin was > 40,000 ng/mL (). Electrocardiogram (EKG) was noted to have diffuse ST segment elevations , troponin was 2 ng/mL, and transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed mild pericardial effusion ; this constellation was consistent with pericarditis. Computed tomography (CT) of the chest, abdomen, pelvis (CAP) showed a small left sided pleural effusion . CT of the neck showed enlarged bilateral lymph nodes without evidence of abscess.

Fig. 2 Electrocardiogram with diffuse PR segment depression and ST segment elevation consistent with pericarditis Full size image
Fig.3 Transthoracic echocardiogram with mild pericardial effusion Full size image
Fig. 4 Computed tomography chest, abdomen, pelvis with small pleural effusion and atelectasis at left lung base Full size image

After no underlying infectious or malignancy causes were identified, a primary rheumatological process was considered. She was given a trial of oral prednisone (60 mg daily), with resolution of fever and leukocytosis and symptomatic improvement. Oral colchicine (0.6 mg daily for 1 month) was added to treat the pericarditis. Repeat renal biopsy re-demonstrated the previous findings and, specifically, absence of SLE features. Her rheumatological presentation was felt to be most consistent with AoSD, given the fevers, arthralgias, leukocytosis, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, elevations in aspartate transaminase/alanine transaminase (AST/ALT), and the markedly elevated ferritin. Although she had a positive RF, her clinical presentation was not compatible with rheumatoid arthritis. Given her low titer ANA and positive SSA, the possibility of SLE was considered. She was maintained on oral hydroxychloroquine (400 mg daily) and monitored closely in the rheumatology clinic, but over years of follow-up her presentation remained more consistent with AoSD rather than SLE. Additionally, she lacked signs or symptoms to suggest a diagnosis of Sjogren’s disease.

During follow-up in the rheumatology clinic, attempts to wean oral prednisone below 10 mg daily were unsuccessful, resulting in flares characterized by fevers, sore throat, facial swelling, arthralgias, myalgias, urticarial rash, flank pain, chest pain, and associated elevated inflammatory markers. Oral methotrexate (15 mg weekly) was added in August 2018 as a steroid sparing agent, with initial improvement. Due to a recurrence of pericardial effusion and inability to increase her methotrexate dose due to chronic kidney disease (CKD), tocilizumab (8 mg/kg intravenous infusion every 4 weeks) was added in December 2018. Given continued disease activity, the patient was switched to subcutaneous anakinra (100 mg daily) in January 2020 and methotrexate and tocilizumab were discontinued. During this time, her condition remained stable on oral losartan (100 mg daily).

Her rheumatologic disease was quiescent for several months on anakinra, but then the patient developed fever and dry cough requiring admission in March 2020. Infectious work up was negative. Laboratory work-up was concerning for flare of her AoSD although she lacked her usual symptoms of joint pain, sore throat, chest pain, and rashes (). She improved with an increased dose of oral prednisone to 30 mg daily. Shortly after that admission, she developed acute on chronic kidney injury with nephrotic range proteinuria and progression to ESRD. Her anakinra dose was reduced to every other day dosing to account for her ESRD.

She was admitted to the hospital in September 2020 for fever, malaise, headache, dyspnea, cough, and diarrhea. On presentation, her temperature was 101.4 F, blood pressure 97/55 mmHg, and heart rate 119 beats per minute. Physical examination revealed an ill-appearing female, normal conjunctiva, unremarkable oropharynx without pharyngeal erythema, sinus tachycardia with no additional heart sounds or murmurs, clear lung fields, benign abdomen without hepatosplenomegaly, unremarkable joint examination without evidence of synovitis, malar rash, chest hyperpigmentation, intact cranial nerves, left arm weakness, intact sensation, and intact reflexes. Anakinra was held due to her fevers and ongoing infectious work-up. Laboratory work-up was significant for leukocytosis, worsening anemia and thrombocytopenia, and CK 4000 U/L (). CT CAP showed new splenomegaly as well as lymphadenopathy. The patient rapidly deteriorated, resulting in pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and death within a few days of admission. There was concern that she may have progressed to hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) or macrophage activation syndrome (new cytopenia, splenomegaly, high-grade fevers, profoundly elevated ferritin) but additional supportive laboratory tests and bone marrow biopsy were not obtained. Autopsy revealed bilateral lung consolidation with red hepatization of all five lobes, green–black mucosal discoloration around the gastric fundus, and hepatosplenomegaly with liver weight of 211 g (expected 1500–1800 g) and spleen weight of 414 g (expected 125–195 g). It was concluded that the cause of death was acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and respiratory failure.
rewritten_case:
A female patient, who is in her late twenties, of African American descent has a history of obesity and allergic rhinitis. She works in sales at a telecommunications company and has not traveled outside of her home state of Illinois. She denies any tobacco or alcohol use and uses loratadine as needed for her allergies. Her medical history revealed instances of lower extremity and periorbital edema, along with hypoalbuminemia, renal insufficiency, and nephrotic range proteinuria. Her father had suffered from ESRD of unknown etiology and had died from a myocardial infarction at a relatively young age. 

On examination, nine out of twenty sampled glomeruli showed segmental or global scarring after she underwent a renal biopsy. Marked visceral epithelial cell proliferation was observed in non-globally sclerotic glomeruli with global collapse of the glomerular tufts. Electron micrography showed diffuse foot process effacement. She was treated for about a couple of years with cyclosporine and oral prednisone, achieving partial remission, and was maintained on daily oral losartan.

In a separate instance, the patient complained of fever, body aches, sore throat, and chest pain spanning several weeks. Initial outpatient testing for influenza, Epstein-Barr virus, and streptococcus returned negative. On admission, her temperature was 104.4 F, heart rate 114 beats per minute, and blood pressure 117/76 mmHg. Physical examination revealed anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, sinus tachycardia, diffuse joint tenderness, and other unremarkable findings. Laboratory examination showed leukocytosis, acute on chronic kidney disease, mild transaminitis, and nephrotic range proteinuria. Serologies were significant for ANA of 1:80, RF of 60 IU/mL, anti-SSA > 8, and ferritin > 40,000 ng/mL. An EKG revealed diffuse ST segment elevations, and a TTE showed mild pericardial effusion, consistent with pericarditis. CT scans revealed a small left-sided pleural effusion and enlarged bilateral lymph nodes.

After ruling out infectious or malignant causes, a primary rheumatological process was considered. She was given oral prednisone and colchicine, resulting in symptom improvement. A repeat renal biopsy confirmed the previous findings and, absence of SLE features. She was eventually diagnosed with AoSD and was maintained on oral hydroxychloroquine. Despite treatment, attempts to lower her oral prednisone dose often resulted in symptom flares.

During subsequent hospital admissions, she presented with fever and dry cough. Infectious work up was negative. Laboratory work-up was concerning for flare of her AoSD. She improved with an increased dose of oral prednisone. Shortly afterwards, she developed acute on chronic kidney injury with nephrotic range proteinuria and progression to ESRD. Her anakinra dose was reduced to accommodate her ESRD.

In a later hospital admission, the patient presented with fever, malaise, headache, dyspnea, cough, and diarrhea. Her physical examination and laboratory work-up were significant. Anakinra was held due to her fevers and ongoing infectious work-up. CT scans showed new splenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. Her condition worsened rapidly, leading to pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and death. Autopsy revealed bilateral lung consolidation with red hepatization of all five lobes, green-black mucosal discoloration around the gastric fundus, and hepatosplenomegaly. The cause of death was determined to be acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and respiratory failure.
model_response:
DX: Autoimmune Overlap Syndrome (AOSD)

Justification: The patient's presentation with fever, joint pain, and serological markers of ANA, RF, and anti-SSA, along with the presence of nephrotic range proteinuria, renal insufficiency, and pericarditis, suggests a diagnosis of AOSD. The patient's history of AoSD, which was previously diagnosed and treated, and the presence of new symptoms and laboratory findings consistent with a flare, further support this diagnosis.
target_distractor: Rapidly progressive nephritic syndrome with diffuse crescentic glomerulonephritis
adjudication_notes: No reliable alias or fuzzy match; no clear mentions.

original_case:
We report the case of a 67-year-old Caucasian man who was reported to be an active smoker. His oncological history included immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) as a paraneoplastic syndrome with 7000 platelets/mcL, associated with a 4.6-cm lung carcinoma as an incidental diagnosis. Diagnostic testing was performed, ruling out syphilis, hepatitis, and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, without gamma alteration in serum protein electrophoresis or any blood smear findings. No further autoantibody tests were performed. Corticosteroids were administered during 1 week at 1 mg/kg of methylprednisolone doses together with intravenous immunoglobulins during 5 days, with complete resolution of ITP.

After surgery, stage IIB (pT2aN1), moderately differentiated nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma was confirmed. Surgical margins were affected, thus treatment was completed with concurrent weekly docetaxel with radiotherapy with good tolerance. Six months after initial presentation, early progression was evidenced with pleural thickening and pleural effusion. The pathological study was completed with no targeted mutations found and with programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) <1% in tumor cells and 25% in stroma cells by 22C3 immunohistochemistry assay. First-line chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel was started, with partial response after receiving six cycles. Eighteen months after finishing first-line chemotherapy, with maintained response, new pleural progression was evidenced, as confirmed by positron emission tomography (PET) scan. It was thus decided to start a second line with atezolizumab (an anti-PD-L1 antibody).

Two weeks after receiving immunotherapy, he presented to the emergency room with severe dyspnea accompanied by intense asthenia, myalgia, and fever of 39 °C. He denied contact with people suffering coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID19) infection. Upon presentation, he was conscious and alert with all neurological functions preserved, hemodynamically stable, tachypneic, with 93% oxygen saturation in room air. He looked pale and had bruises on both arms on physical examination. Painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly stood out, and auscultation revealed an abolition of left lung sounds. A blood test confirmed moderate pancytopenia, glomerular filtration rate of 50 ml/minute (previously normal), an increase in acute-phase reactants (C-reactive protein and ferritin), and elevated levels of D-dimer >20 times normal value (). A computerized angiotomography was performed with no signs of pulmonary thromboembolism, neither lung infiltrates nor pleural effusion.

During the next 24 hours, he started vomiting with an altered level of consciousness with drowsiness. He had miotic pupils, without other signs of neurological dysfunction. On examination, he had developed progressive jaundice with abdominal pain in the right flank. A few hours later, he suffered a tonic–clonic seizure. Initially, COVID-19 was rejected, and blood tests were repeated at 24 hours, revealing pancytopenia, hyperbilirrubinemia, and hypertransaminitis. Head computed tomography (CT) was performed with no alterations, and a blood smear showed anisocytosis with some elliptocytes. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) and intubated due to neurological deterioration with a score of 8 on the Glasgow scale. After assessing the risks and benefits, no lumbar puncture was done. Empirical broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment was started, but the possibility that it was a hemophagocytic syndrome was raised and a differential diagnosis was started. Serologies were negative for HSV1-2, CMV, EBV, HIV, HBV, HCV, and HLTV-1 viruses. Elevated IL-6 (19.4 pg/mL) and CD25 (6516 U/m) were found with normal angiotensin-converting enzyme levels. He had 110 CD4 and 620 CD8 lymphocytes with very low CD4/CD8 ratio of 0.18. H-score for hemophagocytic syndrome was 256 points (> 99% probability). Given the high suspicion, treatment with high-dose corticosteroids was initiated using 20 mg dexamethasone bolus as 1 mg/kg equivalent of methylprednisolone since day 1. Finally, bone marrow biopsy was performed, showing reactive hypercellularity, hemophagocytosis, and dysplastic signs in megakaryocytic and erythroid reactive lines.

Fig. 1 A Bone marrow biopsy with reactive hypercellularity, hemophagocytosis (red arrow), and dysplastic signs in megakaryocytic and erythroid reactive lines. B, C Hepatic and spleen tissue with hemophagocytosis Full size image Severe pancytopenia persisted despite transfusions, so it was decided to initiate tocilizumab at 8 mg/kg, without success, so we continued with anakinra without analytical or neurological improvement during day 2. Treatment with mycophenolate mofetil was added on day 3 for the next two days and finally, 5 days after admission, etoposide 100 mg/m2. Without any clinical improvement, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed, showing extensive white matter damage . To study the degree of brain involvement, an electroencephalogram was done and revealed symmetrical background activity consisting of a 2–4 Hz, bilateral, irregular, low-voltage rhythm with no reactivity to eyelid closure–opening, corresponding to diffuse and severe degree brain involvement. Hence, it was decided to limit the therapeutic effort.

Fig. 2 MRI T1 and T2 sequences with extensive involvement of supra- and infratentorial white matter, with bilateral and asymmetric damage, deep and superficial, of corpus callosum and internal capsules. A sagittal plane. B axial plane Full size image Autopsy of the patient was performed, confirming the syndrome affecting the bone marrow, lymph nodes, liver, and spleen (Fig. 1 B, C) as well as the central nervous system.
rewritten_case:
The patient, a 67-year-old Caucasian man and active smoker, had a history of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) related to a paraneoplastic syndrome. He had 7000 platelets/mcL and a lung carcinoma measuring 4.6 cm was discovered incidentally. Diagnostic tests ruled out syphilis, hepatitis, and HIV infection. He showed no gamma alteration in serum protein electrophoresis or findings in blood smears. Administration of corticosteroids at 1 mg/kg of methylprednisolone doses together with intravenous immunoglobulins resulted in complete resolution of ITP.

Following surgery, a moderately differentiated nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma, stage IIB (pT2aN1), was confirmed. Despite affected surgical margins, treatment with concurrent weekly docetaxel and radiotherapy was well-tolerated. Progression of the disease was evidenced by pleural thickening and effusion at an unspecified time after initial presentation. The pathological study revealed no targeted mutations and 22C3 immunohistochemistry assay showed PD-L1 <1% in tumor cells and 25% in stroma cells. First-line chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel resulted in partial response. Atezolizumab (an anti-PD-L1 antibody) was started as a second line of therapy following the detection of new pleural progression via a PET scan, the timing of which is not specified.

The patient presented to the emergency room suffering from severe dyspnea, intense asthenia, myalgia, and fever of 39 °C shortly after receiving immunotherapy. He denied contact with individuals infected with COVID-19. Physical examination revealed pale skin, bruises on both arms, painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly, and an absence of left lung sounds. A blood test showed moderate pancytopenia, a glomerular filtration rate of 50 ml/minute (previously normal), elevated levels of acute-phase reactants, and D-dimer levels >20 times the normal value. No signs of pulmonary thromboembolism, lung infiltrates, or pleural effusion were found on a CT scan.

The patient's condition deteriorated over an unspecified period, with symptoms including vomiting, drowsiness, progressive jaundice, abdominal pain in the right flank, and a tonic-clonic seizure. A head CT scan revealed no alterations and a blood smear showed anisocytosis with some elliptocytes. He was subsequently admitted to the ICU due to neurological deterioration. Broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment was initiated and a differential diagnosis started for Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH). Tests for various viruses came back negative, but elevated IL-6 and CD25 levels were found, along with an H-score for HLH of 256 points (> 99% probability). High-dose corticosteroids were administered, and a bone marrow biopsy showed reactive hypercellularity, hemophagocytosis, and signs of dysplasia in megakaryocytic and erythroid lines.

Despite transfusions, severe pancytopenia persisted and treatment with tocilizumab, anakinra, mycophenolate mofetil, and etoposide was attempted over an unspecified period. An MRI revealed extensive white matter damage, and an electroencephalogram showed severe brain involvement. In light of these findings, further treatment was limited. An autopsy confirmed the HLH, affecting the bone marrow, lymph nodes, liver, spleen, and central nervous system.
model_response:
DX: Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)

The patient's presentation with severe dyspnea, asthenia, myalgia, and fever shortly after receiving immunotherapy, along with laboratory findings of pancytopenia, elevated acute-phase reactants, and D-dimer levels, suggests a severe inflammatory response. The subsequent development of neurological symptoms, including seizures, and the presence of hemophagocytosis in the bone marrow biopsy, as well as elevated IL-6 and CD25 levels, support the diagnosis of HLH.
adjudication_notes: Fuzzy match to true dx.

original_case: The 24-year-old South-Asian female, primigravida, presented at 31 weeks of gestation with epigastric pain for 6 hours. The pain was sharp, radiating to the back and was worse on lying supine. Pain was associated with fever, nausea, and vomiting for the same duration. The patient denied any history of recent infection, or of consuming any new medication or herbal drugs. The patient was only on iron and folic acid supplements during the course of her pregnancy. The patient was a nonsmoker and had never consumed alcohol. Her past medical, surgical, and family history were not significant. The patient was a housewife and comes from a middle-class family. Her obstetric follow-up was uneventful so far. The patient received the first dose of the Pfizer vaccine 1 week prior to the onset of symptoms. On general examination, the patient was conscious, oriented, and alert. Heart rate of 106 beats per minute, blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg, body temperature of 101°F, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% in room air were recorded. On abdominal examination, no obvious skin rashes were visualized in the abdomen. There was abdominal distension with gravid uterus and severe epigastric tenderness. The cardiovascular, respiratory, and neurological examinations were unremarkable. The initial blood investigations revealed a total leukocyte count of 17 × 10^9/L, serum lipase of 4376 U/L, and serum amylase of 83 U/L. An ultrasound scan of the abdomen showed features of pancreatitis. Her gall bladder was normal and no gallstones were seen. A real-time reverse-transcriptase polymerase-chain-reaction (rRT-PCR) for SARS-CoV-2 screening was done prior to admission and was negative. On the second day of admission, the patient had a spontaneous vaginal delivery and the baby was shifted to the neonatal ICU in a stable condition. In view of ongoing upper abdomen pain, a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen was performed, which revealed bulky pancreas with mild enhancement and marked peripancreatic fat stranding with inflammation, suggestive of acute interstitial edematous pancreatitis . Over the next 48 hours, her pain settled and slowly oral intake was encouraged. Blood cultures taken at admission were sterile. The pancreatic enzymes on day 4 of admission were in the normal range. Her diet was changed to regular after the improvement of symptoms, and the patient was discharged in a stable condition on day 7. She was reviewed at 1 month and again after 6 months in the clinic and has remained stable since then. Fig. 1 Computed tomography abdomen revealing bulky pancreas with mild enhancement, marked peripancreatic fat stranding with inflammation. (patient’s details shadowed) Detailed evaluation of all possible etiologies for pancreatitis did not reveal any specific etiology. Her liver function tests, calcium, and triglycerides were normal since admission (). Her antinuclear antibody(ANA) was negative. Her ultrasound done at admission and a magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) at 3 weeks did not show any gallstones. Her pancreatic duct was normal and there was no abnormal pancreaticobiliary union.  Laboratory parameters during admission and follow-up.
rewritten_case:
The female patient, a 24-year-old primigravida of South-Asian descent, presented with complaints of sharp, radiating epigastric pain. The pain, exacerbated when lying supine, was coupled with fever, nausea, and vomiting. The patient denied any recent infection or introduction of new medication or herbal drugs into her regimen. Her only supplements during her pregnancy were iron and folic acid. The patient, a nonsmoker and teetotaler, had no notable past medical, surgical, or family history. She was a housewife from a middle-class family, and her pregnancy had been uneventful until this point. 

She had received the first dose of the Pfizer vaccine recently, but the exact timeline was unclear. Her general examination revealed her to be conscious, oriented, and alert. Her vitals were recorded as: heart rate – 106 beats per minute, blood pressure – 140/90 mmHg, body temperature – 101°F, respiratory rate – 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation – 98% in room air. 

Upon abdominal examination, no visible skin rashes were found. However, she had abdominal distension with gravid uterus and severe epigastric tenderness. There were no remarkable findings in the cardiovascular, respiratory, and neurological examinations. Initial blood investigations suggested an elevated total leukocyte count of 17 × 10^9/L, serum lipase of 4376 U/L, and serum amylase of 83 U/L.

An abdominal ultrasound revealed features consistent with pancreatitis while her gall bladder appeared normal with no gallstones. She had tested negative for SARS-CoV-2 with an rRT-PCR test prior to admission. The patient had a spontaneous vaginal delivery during her hospital stay and the baby was moved to the neonatal ICU in a stable condition. 

Her persistent upper abdomen pain led to a CT scan of the abdomen, which showed a bulky pancreas with mild enhancement and marked peripancreatic fat stranding with inflammation, indicative of acute interstitial edematous pancreatitis. Over the course of her hospital stay, her pain subsided and she was encouraged to resume oral intake. Blood cultures taken upon admission were sterile and her pancreatic enzymes returned to the normal range. 

After her symptoms improved, her diet was changed to regular and she was discharged in a stable condition. She returned for follow-up examinations at the clinic a certain period of time after discharge, with no recurrence of symptoms. 

Despite a detailed evaluation, no specific etiology for the pancreatitis was identified. Her liver function tests, calcium, and triglycerides levels were normal since admission. Her antinuclear antibody (ANA) was negative. An ultrasound performed at admission and a MRCP carried out later showed no gallstones, a normal pancreatic duct, and no abnormal pancreaticobiliary union.
model_response:
DX: Acute Interstitial Edematous Pancreatitis

The patient's symptoms, including epigastric pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting, are consistent with pancreatitis. The laboratory results, including elevated serum lipase and amylase levels, and the imaging findings, such as a bulky pancreas with mild enhancement and marked peripancreatic fat stranding, support this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: No reliable alias or fuzzy match; no clear mentions.

original_case: A 72-year-old Japanese man had been treated by a nearby doctor for hypertension, but subsequently developed lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS; lower abdominal discomfort and difficulty urinating) and was prescribed an α1 blocker for 1 year. However, the patient was subsequently referred to our department because his symptoms did not improve. His medical history included sinusitis and laparoscopic cholecystectomy. At the first visit, the patient’s height and weight were 162 cm and 66 kg, respectively. His blood pressure was 132/74 mmHg, pulse was regular at 63 beats/minute, and body temperature was 36.4 °C. The patient had no history of smoking or drinking. No specific abnormalities or neurological findings were noted at the initial physical examination. However, a digital rectal examination revealed a walnut-sized prostate without tenderness, with a palpable nodule on the right lobe. Blood biochemistry and urinalysis revealed no abnormal findings, and the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level was 1.258 ng/ml. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed a prostate mass of 36 cc. The International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) was 20 points, IPSS-Quality of Life was 4 points, and uroflowmetry revealed a urine volume of 211 ml, maximum urine flow rate of 10.7 ml/s, and residual urine volume of 10 ml. Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a high-intensity area in the right lobe on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) , and the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) in that area revealed a low signal . No other abnormalities were detected in the search range. The radiologist’s interpretation result was according to Prostate Imaging and Reporting and Data System (PI-RADS) category 3. Fig. 1 Pelvic MRI revealed a high-intensity area in the right lobe on DWI (a: white arrow) and a low-intensity area for ADC (b: white arrow) Full size image Digital rectal examination and MRI findings suggested cT2a prostate cancer; therefore, a transrectal ultrasound-guided systematic biopsy (12 cores) was performed. A pathological examination revealed no malignancy and poor glandular formation, while only a dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltration but no obliterative phlebitis or storiform fibrosis was observed (Fig. 2 a–c). Thus, we performed IgG and IgG4 immunostaining. IgG4-positive (IgG4+) plasma cells were observed in a wide range, IgG4+ cells were noted at > 10 per high-power field, and the IgG4+/IgG-positive (IgG+) cell ratio was > 40% (Fig. 3 a–c). Fig. 2 Pathological findings of the prostate biopsy specimen. The biopsy specimen revealed prostatitis and fibrosis. Lymphocytes/plasma cell-based chronic inflammatory cell infiltration is recognized. Focal inflammatory infiltrate with plasma cells. a Biopsy specimen. b HE staining. (× 100). c HE staining. (× 200) Full size image Fig. 3 The immunohistochemical evaluation of the biopsy specimens indicated positive IgG and IgG4 immunostaining: IgG4+/IgG+ cell ratio was > 40%, and the number of IgG4+ plasma cells was > 10 per high-power field. a IgG immunostaining. (× 200). b IgG4 immunostaining. (× 200). c IgG4 immunostaining. (× 400) Full size image Serum IgG4 measurements and lung and abdominal computed tomography (CT) were performed for a definitive diagnosis. Serum IgG4 levels were high at 1600 mg/dl (reference range: 11–121 mg/dl). Pulmonary CT indicated no abnormal findings, and enhanced abdominal CT revealed a soft tissue mass around the bilateral common iliac arteries from the abdominal aorta, suggesting periaortitis . Additionally, multiple lymphadenopathies were observed around the abdominal aorta , and malignant lymphoma was suspected. Therefore, the soluble interleukin 2 receptor was measured and was within the normal range of 392 U/ml (reference range: 121–613 U/ml). Fig. 4 Abdominal enhanced CT revealed a soft tissue mass around the bilateral common iliac arteries from the abdominal aorta (a white arrow, 3D-CT). Additionally, multiple lymphadenopathy is observed around the abdominal aorta (b white arrow) Full size image Based on the above findings, we diagnosed the patient with a definite diagnosis group (definite).
rewritten_case:
A 72-year-old Japanese man initially treated for hypertension by a local practitioner began to exhibit lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS; lower abdominal discomfort and difficulty urinating). He was subsequently prescribed an α1 blocker for a year. However, his symptoms persisted, leading to his referral to our department. His medical history included sinusitis and laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The patient stood at 162 cm and weighed 66 kg. His blood pressure was 132/74 mmHg, pulse 63 beats/minute, and body temperature 36.4 °C. The patient had no history of smoking or drinking. Initial physical examination showed no specific abnormalities or neurological findings. A digital rectal examination revealed a walnut-sized prostate without tenderness, with a palpable nodule on the right lobe. 

Blood biochemistry, urinalysis, and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level were all within normal limits (PSA was 1.258 ng/ml). However, the patient's abdominal ultrasonography indicated a prostate mass of 36 cc. The International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) was 20 points, IPSS-Quality of Life was 4 points. Uroflowmetry showed a urine volume of 211 ml, maximum urine flow rate of 10.7 ml/s, and residual urine volume of 10 ml. 

Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a high-intensity area in the right lobe on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI), and the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) in that area showed a low signal. The MRI findings were interpreted as Prostate Imaging and Reporting and Data System (PI-RADS) category 3. 

Although these initial findings suggested cT2a prostate cancer, a transrectal ultrasound-guided systematic biopsy (12 cores) showed no malignancy and poor glandular formation, only a dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltration but no obliterative phlebitis or storiform fibrosis was observed. IgG and IgG4 immunostaining were performed, with IgG4+ plasma cells noted in a wide range and the IgG4+/IgG+ cell ratio was > 40%. 

During a routine blood test, an unexpected finding of elevated anti-D [Rh] antibodies was noted. This led to speculation of a possible maternal-fetal Rh incompatibility, despite the patient's age and gender. 

A serum IgG4 measurement and lung and abdominal CT were performed. Serum IgG4 levels were high at 1600 mg/dl (reference range: 11–121 mg/dl). Pulmonary CT showed no abnormalities, while enhanced abdominal CT revealed a soft tissue mass around the bilateral common iliac arteries from the abdominal aorta, suggesting periaortitis. Additionally, multiple lymphadenopathies were observed around the abdominal aorta, prompting suspicion of malignant lymphoma. Soluble interleukin 2 receptor was measured and was within the normal range of 392 U/ml (reference range: 121–613 U/ml). 

Despite the unusual finding of anti-D [Rh] antibodies, the overall clinical picture led us to diagnose the patient with IgG4-related disease (IgG4-RD). Further investigations are ongoing to understand the origin of the anti-D [Rh] antibodies.
model_response:
DX: IgG4-related disease (IgG4-RD)

The patient's symptoms of lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and prostate mass, along with the imaging findings of a high-intensity area on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) and a low apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) in the right lobe, suggest a diagnosis of prostate cancer. However, the biopsy results showing no malignancy and dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltration, along with the IgG4 immunostaining results, are more consistent with IgG4-RD.
target_distractor: Maternal care for anti-D [Rh] antibodies, third trimester, fetus 4
adjudication_notes: Exact/normalized match to true dx alias.

original_case: A 28-year-old Caucasian man with history of testicular cancer in remission presented with altered mental status, syncope, vertical gaze palsy, ataxia, and tremor. He was in his usual state of health until 2 years ago, when he noticed a large right testicular mass. Work-up revealed marginally enlarged intraabdominal lymph nodes without evidence of metastases. One and a half years ago, he underwent radical unilateral orchiectomy. Pathology revealed malignant mixed germ cell tumor with abundant necrosis, comprising 50% teratoma, 45% embryonal carcinoma, and 5% yolk sac tumor. The mixed germ cell tumor was limited to the testicle without evidence of invasion. Lymph nodes were not examined pathologically. Alpha fetal protein (AFP) was mildly elevated at 9 ng/mL (reference range: 0–6.7 ng/mL) and normalized postoperatively. The patient opted for surveillance instead of chemotherapy after consultation with an oncologist. Three months prior to admission, the patient started experiencing fatigue and weight gain of 18 kg over 2 months. He was diagnosed with hypogonadism based on a low testosterone level of 127 ng/dL and started testosterone supplementation. Three weeks prior to admission, he began experiencing difficulty with upward and downward gaze. His fatigue continued to worsen, and he stopped working. One week prior to admission, he developed confusion, which manifested in difficulty remembering his dogs’ names and asking questions in strangely worded ways. He also developed bilateral tremor and ataxia, causing him to fall on a daily basis. The worsening of these neurological symptoms led him to present to the emergency department. While hospitalized, he had an episode of syncope. As this was being evaluated, he was noted to have hypovolemia due to polyuria, which was concerning for diabetes insipidus and, consequently, hypothalamic involvement of his underlying disease. Ultimately, the patient did not meet criteria for diabetes insipidus but did have elevated prolactin of 52.0 ng/mL, concerning for some hypothalamic injury. Due to suspicion that his condition could extend to the pituitary, the patient underwent testing for thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). The decreased levels of the above hormones revealed probable panhypopituitarism, with TSH of 0.11 mcIU/mL, free T4 of 1.0 ng/dL, ACTH of <2 pg/mL, LH of 0.5 pg/mL, and FSH of 1.3 mIU/mL. Of note, he was placed on high-dose steroids immediately and has consistently been on these higher-dose steroids, so he has been unable to undergo a cosyntropin test to confirm central adrenal insufficiency. He also underwent a neurologic work-up, including brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and MRI imaging of the pituitary, which showed T2 prolongation involving the bilateral mesial temporal lobes, hippocampi/fornices, hypothalamus, mammillary bodies and mammillothalamic tracts, and midbrain including periaqueductal gray with normal pituitary (Figs. 1 and 2). His presentation was concerning for encephalitis involving subcortical white matter, deep brain structures, and dorsal midbrain. A lumbar puncture showed lymphocytic pleocytosis with elevated protein and was positive for oligoclonal bands. A broad infectious work-up was otherwise negative. He received high-dose steroids, five sessions of plasmapheresis, and 5 days of intravenous immunoglobulin, without significant improvement in his physical examination or mental status. Repeat ultrasound of the testes, positron emission tomography (PET)/computed tomography (CT) scans, and AFP levels were all normal without evidence of recurrent testicular cancer. He was discharged with close follow-up. Fig. 1 Initial brain magnetic resonance imaging showing T2 prolongation involving the bilateral mesial temporal lobes, hippocampi/fornices, hypothalamus, mammillary bodies and mammillothalamic tracts, and midbrain including periaqueductal gray Full size image Fig. 2 Magnetic resonance imaging of pituitary and brain showing symmetric T2/fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) hyperintensity in the mesial temporal lobes, hippocampi, hypothalamus, mamillary bodies, and midbrain including periaqueductal gray matter. Sella turcica and pituitary gland are normal in size Full size image After discharge, the patient was treated with rituximab. Unfortunately, the patient did not make significant improvement after his hospitalization, losing the ability to walk and to clear his nasopharyngeal secretions. A few months later, the patient was readmitted to the hospital and intensive care unit (ICU) for progression of his condition, which was complicated by thrombocytopenia, gastrointestinal (GI) bleed, sepsis, and worsening neurological status. During this hospitalization, the patient underwent tracheostomy and placement of a gastric tube. Repeat brain MRI showed similar areas of signal abnormality from prior brain MRI but with mildly decreased intensity . Repeat PET/CT scans and ultrasound of the testes were once again normal without evidence of recurrent testicular cancer or metastases. However, the patient was initiated on cyclophosphamide and lacosamide. Upon discharge, the patient continued with rituximab, cyclophosphamide, lacosamide, and levetiracetam. Now, 8 months after his initial hospitalization, the patient is closely followed by neurology and endocrinology and remains disoriented with fluctuating levels of alertness. Fig. 3 Brain magnetic resonance imaging 5 months after initial hospitalization, showing areas of signal abnormality involving the mesial temporal lobes, maxillary bodies, midbrain, and periaqueductal gray matter, which are overall similar in extent to prior brain MRI but mildly decreased in intensity Full size image
rewritten_case:
A Caucasian male in his late twenties with a past medical history of testicular cancer in remission, presented with an array of symptoms including altered mental status, syncope, vertical gaze palsy, ataxia, and tremor. Not long before he had noticed a large right testicular mass, which upon investigation was found to be a malignant mixed germ cell tumor with considerable necrosis. The tumor was composed of 50% teratoma, 45% embryonal carcinoma, and 5% yolk sac tumor, and was confined to the testicle with no evidence of invasion. 

The patient chose to opt for surveillance over chemotherapy after consulting with the oncologist. Some time after his decision, he began experiencing fatigue and significant weight gain. He was diagnosed with hypogonadism and started on testosterone supplementation. 

Over a span of time, his health began to deteriorate. He began having difficulty with upward and downward gaze, his fatigue worsened to the point of him having to stop working, and he showed signs of confusion. His neurological symptoms worsened, manifesting as bilateral tremor and ataxia, causing him to fall frequently. These symptoms led him to seek help at the emergency department. 

During his hospitalization, he was noted to have hypovolemia due to polyuria. The doctors began suspecting diabetes insipidus, and hypothalamic involvement of his underlying disease. However, the patient did not meet criteria for diabetes insipidus. His prolactin levels were elevated, indicating a possible hypothalamic injury. 

Due to the suspicion of pituitary involvement, he was tested for thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). The results indicated probable panhypopituitarism. 

A neurologic work-up was performed, including brain MRI and MRI imaging of the pituitary. The results were concerning for encephalitis involving subcortical white matter, deep brain structures, and dorsal midbrain. A lumbar puncture showed lymphocytic pleocytosis with elevated protein and was positive for oligoclonal bands. Despite high-dose steroids, plasmapheresis, and intravenous immunoglobulin, his physical and mental status did not improve. No evidence of recurrent testicular cancer was found. 

Post-discharge, his condition continued to deteriorate, resulting in loss of mobility and ability to clear his nasopharyngeal secretions. He was readmitted to the hospital and ICU with complications of thrombocytopenia, gastrointestinal bleed, sepsis, and worsening neurological status. Procedures were performed for tracheostomy and placement of a gastric tube. 

Despite no evidence of recurrent testicular cancer or metastases, the patient was started on cyclophosphamide and lacosamide. His treatment continued with rituximab, cyclophosphamide, lacosamide, and levetiracetam after discharge. The patient is closely followed by neurology and endocrinology and remains disoriented with fluctuating levels of alertness.
model_response:
DX: Paraneoplastic Syndrome

The patient's symptoms, including altered mental status, syncope, vertical gaze palsy, ataxia, and tremor, are consistent with a paraneoplastic syndrome, which is a rare but well-known complication of certain types of cancer, including testicular cancer. The presence of panhypopituitarism, encephalitis, and lymphocytic pleocytosis in the cerebrospinal fluid further support this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: No reliable alias or fuzzy match; no clear mentions.

original_case:
We present the case of a 10-month-old Chinese female delivered at a gestational age of 35 weeks following an uneventful pregnancy with parents unrelated to each other. No family history of congenital diseases was found. At birth, she presented with a flat, hairless, yellow-brown linear skin lesion in the right central and temporal scalp, accompanied by brownish-black and verrucose plaques on the right hemifacial and cervical nevi together with the right conjunctival lipomatosus. A skin-colored verrucose tumor was found on the lip, as well as extensive brownish-black plaques and brown nevi on the right side of the trunk and the right arm . Histopathological examination of the plaque lesions on the hip revealed hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and sebaceous gland hyperplasia. Renal Doppler ultrasound revealed right kidney enlargement with polycystic kidney. Electrocardiogram suggested premature atrial syndrome. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was normal at 3 months of age. Genetic testing was performed in her first month, detecting no pathogenic genes related to the clinical symptoms but one clinically significant variant (PTCH1/NM-000264.3 missense mutation, chr9: 98270535, father source) .

Fig. 1
Cutaneous manifestations of patient.
A Flat, hairless skin lesion on the scalp; B anomalies of eye and lip, skin-colored verrucose tumors on the lip; C brownish-black and verrucose plaques on the right side of face and cervical nevi; D linear skin lesion on right trunk and extremities
Full size image

Fig. 2
Genetic testing results of the PTCH1 gene for the patient and his parents. The arrow indicates the position of the deleted nucleotide “C” in the patient. PTCH1/NM-000264.3 missense mutation, chr9:98270535. c.109G > T variant, de novo, which changes Trp to Gly in codon
Full size image

Ten months later, the patient was referred to our department because of mobility disorder in the right limbs and recurrent seizures. Epilepsy started at 10 months of age and presented with medical refractory seizures, accompanied by quadriplegia, mental retardation, and difficulty swallowing. Blood pressure, electroencephalogram (EEG) recordings, and radiographs of long bones were normal. Cranial computed tomography (CT) scan performed owing to the mobility disorder of the right limbs showed widened sulci in the right parietal lobe. Brain MRI performed owing to the quadriplegia showed cerebral infarction . 

Fig. 3
Cranial MRI showing cerebral infarction. The areas of restricted diffusion compatible with hypointense infarction in the left temporal area (A) and hyperintense infarction on apparent diffusion coefficient mapping (B). New large cerebral infarction in the left hemisphere [T1-WI (C) and T2-WI (D)]. Arrows show the areas of cerebral infarction
Full size image

Follow-up was carried out by telephone every 3 months, which involved inquiry about limb motor ability and seizures.
rewritten_case:
In this report, we detail the case of a young Chinese female of approximately one year of age, born prematurely at 35 weeks. The pregnancy was without complications and there was no familial history of congenital diseases or consanguineous marriage. Upon her arrival, she was found to have a distinctive presentation of cutaneous symptoms. A flat, hairless, yellow-brown skin lesion was present on the right central and temporal scalp, and brownish-black and verrucose plaques were observed on the right hemifacial and cervical nevi, including the right conjunctival lipomatosus. A skin-colored verrucose tumor was also observed on her lip, along with extensive brownish-black plaques and brown nevi on the right side of her trunk and right arm.

Histopathological examination of the plaque lesions located on her hip showed hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and sebaceous gland hyperplasia. A renal Doppler ultrasound revealed an enlarged right kidney with polycystic kidney characteristics. Electrocardiogram findings suggested the presence of a premature atrial syndrome. A brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) performed during her early infancy showed no abnormal findings. Genetic testing revealed one clinically significant variant (PTCH1/NM-000264.3 missense mutation, chr9: 98270535, father source), despite not identifying any pathogenic genes directly related to her clinical symptoms.

Subsequent to her initial medical evaluations, the young patient was brought to our department due to the development of a mobility disorder in her right limbs and recurrent seizures. These seizures proved medically refractory, and were accompanied by quadriplegia, cognitive impairment, and difficulties with swallowing. Her blood pressure, electroencephalogram (EEG) recordings and radiographs of long bones remained within normal parameters. However, a cranial computed tomography (CT) scan undertaken due to the mobility issues in her right limbs showed widened sulci in the right parietal lobe. Additionally, a subsequent brain MRI revealed cerebral infarction.

The patient's progress is monitored periodically via telephone consultations to inquire about the condition of her limb motor ability and seizures.
model_response:
DX: Gorlin Syndrome

The patient's presentation of multiple skin lesions, including verrucose plaques and nevi, is consistent with Gorlin Syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by multiple nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome. The presence of hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and sebaceous gland hyperplasia in the plaque lesions, as well as the patient's family history of a PTCH1/NM-000264.3 missense mutation, further supports this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: Exact/normalized match to true dx alias.

original_case:
Initial presentation  
This Caucasian patient was born at 36 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery to a gravida 2, para 2 mother with no significant past medical history. His initial birth weight was 2381 g (25–50th percentile). He failed his newborn pulse oximetry cardiac screen and was first seen by cardiology at 2 weeks of age. He was followed in the cardiology clinic again at 1 month of age. At that time, an electrocardiogram (EKG) showed a sinus tachycardia of 200 beats per minute and hypertension. An echocardiogram was significant for left ventricular hypertrophy with septal wall thickness in diastole of 7 mm and a posterior wall measurement of 5 mm consistent with left ventricular noncompaction, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy subtype. He was also noted to have different skin tones and pigmentation from trunk to lower extremities. He was started on a beta-blocker with plans to follow up in clinic in 2 months and was referred to dermatology for evaluation of the skin lesions.  
At 6 weeks of age, he presented to the cardiomyopathy clinic owing to left ventricular hypertrophy and was also having difficulty feeding. He was then admitted to the hospital for failure to thrive. At admission, his weight was 3100 g (< 2nd percentile), length was 48 cm (3rd–10th percentile), and head circumference was 34 cm (< 2nd percentile). His physical examination findings were significant for hypertension (101/68 mmHg), tachycardia, facial fullness, hyperpigmented lesions on his skin, marked hypotonia, and hepatomegaly. He had irregular hyperpigmentation characterized as a swirling pattern over the back measuring approximately 5 × 2 cm in area under the right axilla and extending to the right portion of the anterior trunk, stopping at the midline.  
Laboratory findings demonstrated transaminitis: aspartate transaminase (AST) 99 U/L (normal 22–63 U/L); alanine transaminase (ALT) 250 U/L (normal 13–39 U/L); total bilirubin 2.3 mg/dL (normal 0.2–1.0 mg/dL).  
A chest radiograph raised concern for cardiomegaly, and an osseous x-ray showed multiple lesions of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia . Genetics was consulted during the hospital admission. The diagnosis was made on the basis of the findings of adrenal fullness on a renal ultrasound in conjunction with the hyperpigmented lesion, polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, cardiomyopathy, and elevated liver function tests (LFT). Repeat echocardiograms showed persistent concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, with initial thickness of the left ventricular wall of 4.7 mm (Z-score 2.6) reaching a maximum of 7.1 mm (Z-score 1.7) (). Systemic hypertension was confirmed with systolic pressures up to 130 mmHg and diastolic pressures up to 77 mmHg.  
Fig. 1  
Skeletal survey demonstrating polyostotic fibrous dysplasia; top left, right upper extremity; top right, left upper extremity; bottom left, left femur  
Full size image  
 Measurement of left posterior wall thickness (LV PW) on each echocardiogram  
Full size table  
A renal ultrasound was negative for renal vein anomalies, and metanephrines were also found to be normal. A random cortisol done via immunoassay was found to be 36.4 μg/dL (1.7–14.0 μg/dL, Vitros 5600). Total protein, albumin, prealbumin, and creatinine kinase were normal. An abdominal ultrasound showed increased liver echogenicity, bilaterally enlarged adrenal glands, and bilateral nephrocalcinosis.  
Given the likelihood of the condition, evaluation was performed. Biochemical evaluation showed elevated serum cortisol without diurnal variation (8 a.m. cortisol at 38.2 μg/dL and 7 p.m. cortisol at 36.4 μg/dL; normal 2.8–23.0 μg/dL). Urinary free cortisol was elevated to 35 μg/dL/24 hours (reference range 3–9 μg/dL/24 hours) (Esoterix; Calabasas, CA). A low-dose dexamethasone suppression test revealed a cortisol of 38.2 μg/dL and an ACTH level of < 5 pg/mL; this was followed by a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test that showed a serum cortisol of 60.1 μg/dL. These results showed that failure to suppress cortisol was consistent with ACTH-independent condition.  
A skin biopsy of a café-au-lait lesion on his back was obtained for gene analysis at All Children’s Hospital in St. Petersburg, Florida and was negative. This result does not negate the clinical diagnosis given the variable expression of the mutation (somaticism) that can occur.
