original_case:
A 67-year-old Caucasian man with a history of non-pathological myopia underwent uneventful surgery for macular pucker with epiretinal membrane (ERM) peeling in his left eye. Three months later, he underwent the same surgical procedure using the same retrobulbar anesthesia in his right eye. Preoperative best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was 0.5 (− 1.25 sphere − 0.75 cylinder at axis 50) in the right eye and 0.75 (− 3.25 sphere − 1.75 cylinder at axis 95) in the left eye. Both eyes were pseudophakic at the time of macular pucker diagnosis and underwent the same procedure 3 months apart. The patient underwent surgery under monitored anesthesia care with a retrobulbar block using a 25-gauge (G), 38-mm Atkinson needle containing 5 ml of a 1:1 mixture of 2% Xylocaine containing adrenaline (1:200,000) and Bupivacaine 5 mg/ml. Both eyes were operated by the same experienced surgeon. In both cases the retrobulbar anesthesia was administered by the same experienced ophthalmologist and the same drug combination was used. 

Preoperative review of the patient’s medical history showed that the patient was under observation due to a myocardial infarction that he had about 5 years previously. He also was under rheumatological observation for ankylosing spondylitis. His treatment at the time of surgery consisted of acetylsalicylic acid 75 mg once daily and atorvastatin 40 mg once daily. No other health problems were reported. The patient denied any allergies. The patient’s social history was negative for smoking, alcohol abuse, recreational drug use, and travel abroad. The patient was a doctor who had been worked in the hospital as a clinician for about 30 years. His mother suffered from migraines and died of a heart attack at the age of 70 years. At the age of 69 years, his maternal grandfather suffered a stroke. The patient did not know anything about his father’s side of the family, but there was no other family history of stroke or vascular illness. 

Three 25G trocars were placed through a self-sealing sclerotomy construction. Central and peripheral pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) was performed. Preexisting posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) induction was verified. Brilliant Blue G containing dye (ILM-BLUE®; D.O.R.C., Zuidland, the Netherlands) aided visualization of the internal limiting membrane (ILM) and allowed for both ERM and ILM peeling up to the vascular arcades. Peripheral indentation allowed for retinal lesion verification. No breaks were found. BSS intraocular irrigating solution was left in the vitreous chamber. The sclerotomies were self-sealing and no sutures were needed. At the conclusion of the procedure, about 0.2 mg of subconjunctival gentamycin was administered. No gas bubble was instilled, there were no episodes of hypotension during the surgery, and postoperatively the patient did not sleep in the prone position. 

The left eye had a regular postoperative course . On postoperative day 1 the patient was seen by a junior ophthalmologist, and the visual acuity (VA) in the right eye was hand motion. Intraocular pressure (IOP) was 14 mmHg. There was a trace afferent pupillary defect by reverse in the right eye. The posterior segment examination showed retinal whitening in the macula and a cherry-red spot . 

Fig. 1 One day after uncomplicated left eye pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) + epiretinal membrane (ERM) peeling procedure. a Preoperative cross-sectional optical coherence tomography (OCT) scan of both eyes showed macular ERM. b Three months postoperative cross-sectional OCT scan of the left eye shows release of ERM-related anteroposterior traction Full size image 

Fig. 2 Right eye findings 1 day after uncomplicated PPV + ERM peeling procedure. a One-day postoperative wide-field fundus photograph of right eye showed retinal changes. b One-day postoperative fundus autofluorescence. c One-day postoperative macular cross-sectional OCT shows foveal ischemia and edema Full size image 

The retina was attached. There was no proptosis or orbital fullness. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) demonstrated inner retinal thickening and hyperreflectivity . Fluorescein angiography demonstrated delayed arterial and venous perfusion (not shown). No further systemic evaluation was performed, the patient was observed and was not referred to a stroke center by the junior ophthalmologist. No blood tests were carried out. No blood pressure, pulse nor temperature was recorded. The patient was not treated with anterior chamber paracentesis, timolol-dorzolamide and brimonidine drops, or 500 mg oral acetazolamide at the first day postoperative control. The patient was alert, attentive, and oriented. Speech was clear and fluent. Cranial nerve assessment, reflexes, sensory perception, coordination, and gait were all normal. No signs of cerebrovascular event were reported. 

At 3 months after surgery, the patient felt his central scotoma had improved, and the BCVA had remained stable at 0.05 (− 0.75 to 1.0 axis 60). The anatomical signs of acute ischemia had resolved, and the macular region resulted in atrophic changes with disappearance of the physiological foveal depression . 

Fig. 3 Right eye findings 3 months after PPV + ERM peeling procedure. a Three-month postoperative wide-field fundus photograph and of right eye showed reduction of retinal whitening and disappearance of cherry red spot. b Three-month postoperative fundus autofluorescence image. c Three-month postoperative macular cross-sectional OCT shows atrophic foveal region and difficulty in central fixation Full size image 

At 4 months after surgery, OCT angiography documented a right eye capillary dropout predominantly in the deep capillary plexus  

Fig. 4 Right eye findings 4 months after uncomplicated PPV + ERM peeling procedure. a 4 month-postoperative right-eye whole retinal, deep, and choroidal OCT angiogram show retinal ischemia predominantly in the deep plexus. HD structural line OCT scanning the fovea shows atrophy. b The left eye is shown for comparison. The left eye underwent the same procedure without any complication Full size image
rewritten_case:
A Caucasian man in his late sixties, who had a background of non-pathological myopia, had previously undergone successful surgery for macular pucker with epiretinal membrane (ERM) peeling in one eye. Sometime later, he underwent the same procedure for his other eye, using the same retrobulbar anesthesia. At the time of the operation, his preoperative best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) in the eye being operated on was 0.5 (− 1.25 sphere − 0.75 cylinder at axis 50) while the previously operated eye had a BCVA of 0.75 (− 3.25 sphere − 1.75 cylinder at axis 95). Both eyes were pseudophakic at the time of macular pucker diagnosis. The surgery was performed under monitored anesthesia care with a retrobulbar block using a 25-gauge (G), 38-mm Atkinson needle containing 5 ml of a 1:1 mixture of 2% Xylocaine containing adrenaline (1:200,000) and Bupivacaine 5 mg/ml. The same experienced surgeon handled both operations, using the same anesthesia and drug combination.

The patient’s medical history showed a myocardial infarction years prior, for which he was being monitored, along with ankylosing spondylitis. His current medications included daily doses of acetylsalicylic acid 75 mg and atorvastatin 40 mg. The patient had no known allergies and a negative social history for smoking, alcohol abuse, recreational drug use, and travel abroad. His family history included a mother who suffered from migraines and died from a heart attack, and a maternal grandfather who had a stroke. No other family history of stroke or vascular illness was reported.

During the procedure, three 25G trocars were placed through a self-sealing sclerotomy construction. Central and peripheral pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) was performed, and preexisting posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) induction was verified. Brilliant Blue G containing dye (ILM-BLUE®; D.O.R.C., Zuidland, the Netherlands) was used to aid visualization of the internal limiting membrane (ILM). Both ERM and ILM were peeled up to the vascular arcades. No breaks were found, and the sclerotomies were self-sealing and required no sutures. At the conclusion of the procedure, about 0.2 mg of subconjunctival gentamycin was administered. 

Postoperatively, the patient was seen by a junior ophthalmologist. The visual acuity (VA) in the operated eye was hand motion, and the intraocular pressure (IOP) was 14 mmHg. There was a trace afferent pupillary defect by reverse in the same eye. The posterior segment examination showed retinal whitening in the macula and a cherry-red spot. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) demonstrated inner retinal thickening and hyperreflectivity. Fluorescein angiography showed delayed arterial and venous perfusion. 

The patient remained alert, attentive, and oriented after the operation, with clear, fluent speech. All neurological assessments were normal, and no signs of a cerebrovascular event were reported. At a subsequent check-up, the patient reported an improvement in his central scotoma, and the BCVA was found to be stable at 0.05 (− 0.75 to 1.0 axis 60). The acute ischemic changes had resolved, and atrophic changes were observed in the macular region. Later, OCT angiography documented a capillary dropout predominantly in the deep capillary plexus in the operated eye.
model_response:
DX: Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO)

The patient's symptoms, including hand motion vision, retinal whitening, cherry-red spot, and delayed arterial and venous perfusion on fluorescein angiography, are consistent with CRAO. The inner retinal thickening and hyperreflectivity on OCT, as well as the capillary dropout on OCT angiography, also support this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: Exact/normalized match to true dx alias.

original_case: A male newborn was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit owing to respiratory distress that appeared immediately after birth. He was born at term via an elective caesarean section to a mother with type 1 diabetes mellitus and hypothyroidism. Apgar scores were 9, 9, and 10 at 1, 5, and 10 minutes, respectively. The anthropometric parameters at birth were: weight, 2.55 kg; length, 48 cm; and occipitofrontal circumference, 33 cm. On examination, the baby had subtle facial dysmorphism with a hirsute forehead, full cheeks, flat nasal bridge, elongated protruding philtrum, and micrognathia . His chest was small and bell shaped, and he had severe respiratory distress with intercostal and subcostal recessions. His abdominal wall was lax and thin, with evidence of divarication of the recti. Bowel peristalsis was easily visible through the abdominal wall; however, there was no umbilical or inguinal hernia. The cardiovascular system was clinically normal. Fig. 1 Photograph showing subtle facial dysmorphism with a hirsute forehead, full cheeks, flat nasal bridge, elongated protruding philtrum, and micrognathia Full size image The chest x-ray showed narrowing of the rib cage with crowding of the ribs in a “coat-hanger” appearance . The coat-hanger angle (CHA) was 32°, and the mid-to-widest thoracic diameter was 68%. There was no radiological evidence of surfactant deficiency, pneumonia, or congenital malformations of the lungs. Basic biochemical, microbiological, and hematological investigations were normal. The echocardiogram revealed a small ostium secundum atrial septal defect. The skeletal survey did not reveal abnormalities in long bones. Fig. 2 Chest x-ray showing coat-hanger appearance of the rib cage with increased coat-hanger angle (33° on the right side and 31° on the left side). In addition, the ratio between mid-to-widest thoracic diameter is significantly decreased to 68% Full size image On the basis of facial dysmorphism, chest and anterior abdominal wall abnormalities, coat-hanger appearance of the rib cage, increased CHA, and reduced mid-to-widest thoracic diameter, the clinical diagnosis was made. His karyotype was normal, and further genetic testing was not done owing to unavailability.
rewritten_case:
A male infant, born at term via elective caesarean section, was brought into the neonatal intensive care unit due to respiratory distress. The infant's mother had a medical history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and hypothyroidism. The newborn's Apgar scores were 9, 9, and 10, with anthropometric parameters at birth including a weight of 2.55 kg, length of 48 cm, and occipitofrontal circumference of 33 cm. 

Upon examination, the infant presented with noticeable facial dysmorphism characterized by a hirsute forehead, full cheeks, a flat nasal bridge, an elongated protruding philtrum, and micrognathia. His chest appeared small and bell-shaped, with severe respiratory distress evidenced by intercostal and subcostal recessions. 

His abdominal wall was lax and thin, with evidence of divarication of the recti. Bowel peristalsis was clearly visible through the abdominal wall, yet there were no signs of umbilical or inguinal hernia. His cardiovascular system was clinically normal. 

A chest x-ray revealed a narrowed rib cage with crowded ribs, presenting a "coat-hanger" appearance. The coat-hanger angle (CHA) was measured at 32°, and the mid-to-widest thoracic diameter was 68%. There were no radiological indications of surfactant deficiency, pneumonia, or congenital malformations of the lungs. Basic biochemical, microbiological, and hematological investigations were all within normal ranges. 

An echocardiogram identified a small ostium secundum atrial septal defect. A skeletal survey did not reveal any abnormalities in the long bones. 

Considering the facial dysmorphism, chest and anterior abdominal wall abnormalities, the "coat-hanger" appearance of the rib cage, increased CHA, and reduced mid-to-widest thoracic diameter, a clinical diagnosis was reached. The infant's karyotype was normal, and further genetic testing was not conducted due to unavailability.
model_response:
DX: Thanatophoric dysplasia

This diagnosis is supported by the presence of severe respiratory distress, facial dysmorphism, and chest and anterior abdominal wall abnormalities, which are all characteristic features of this condition. The "coat-hanger" appearance of the rib cage and increased CHA are also consistent with Thanatophoric dysplasia.

original_case: A 59-year-old German woman with a past medical history of hypothyroidism and cutaneous lupus erythematosus presented at the hospital´s emergency room 7 days after having been bitten by a wild Eurasian red squirrel (Sciurus vulgaris). The patient reported having noticed a squirrel lying motionless on the ground when she took a walk. As soon as she tried to examine the animal, it started biting her, biting digit IV of the right hand and digit II of the left hand. After the wounds had been cleaned and dressed, she was started the same day on antibiotic therapy consisting of cefuroxime 500 mg orally twice a day. Tetanus vaccination status was also checked. On day 6 after the bite, the patient presented at the hospital’s emergency room showing the following symptoms: general malaise, aching head and body, fever, chill, and a swollen right elbow. She did not report having suffered from nausea, vomiting, or sensitivity to light or noise. The clinical examination showed a minor bite on digit IV of the right hand, located near the middle phalanx, slightly reddened, yet without clear inflammatory signs. There was no pain to pressure, no movement restriction, nor any sensory deficit. There were also visible signs of lymphadenitis at the ulnar side of the right elbow. The peripheral sensitivity as well as movement skills and blood flow were intact. At the index finger of the left hand, another minor bite without any local or proximal signs of inflammation was recorded. The physical examination did not reveal anything unusual. The vital parameters were stable, with the exception of a negligible sinus tachycardia. No signs of meningism were found. Laboratory tests showed an increase in the C-reactive protein (CRP) up to 28.6 mg/L (reference < 5 mg/L), but no leukocytosis. The test for procalcitonin (indicating bacterial inflammation) was negative. Sampled cerebrospinal fluid and urine were also negative in standard laboratory tests. X-rays of the thorax and of digit IV of the right hand and a native computed tomography (CT) brain scan did not show any pathological outcomes. Real-time PCR assays for severe acute respiratory syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), respiratory syncytial virus, and influenza A and B were negative. Starting on day 7, the medical treatment also comprised combination therapy with intravenous antibiotics (ampicillin/sulbactam, 2 g/1 g) 3 times a day. However, the patient’s condition did not improve and fever rose up to 39.2 °C and persisted until day 12. Blood culture remained negative, even at 14 days after inoculation. CRP increased up to 185 mg/L on day 12. As a consequence, treatment was intensified by commencing combination antibiotic therapy with piperacillin/tazobactam (4 g/0.5 g) on day 11. Following initiation of therapy with piperacillin/tazobactam, the CRP fell to 74 mg/L (day 14) and there was a mild persisting leukocytosis (12.14 × 10^3). In parallel, the wound on the patient’s right hand developed an ulcer-like lesion showing swollen reddened edges and a central incrustation . The lymphadenitis of the right elbow persisted. It was at this stage that a specific infectious disease was suspected as a possible diagnosis for the first time. Following a phone call with the reference laboratory for the suspected infectious disease on day 14, the decision was made to send a wound swab sample from digit IV of the patient’s right hand (A-1825/1) to the reference laboratory for microbiological examination. In addition, a serum sample (A-1825/2) was taken for antibody detection (day 14). An enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) showed that antibodies against the lipopolysaccharide of the suspected pathogen Igpoly, immunoglobulin (Ig)G and IgM were borderline. Fig. 1 Picture of the right hand of the patient at day 14 after the squirrel bite on the digit IV. After presentation of the ulcerous lesion and the local lymphadenitis of the right elbow in combination with the non-effective antibiotic treatment using three different antibiotics over 2 weeks, the suspicion of a specific infectious disease was expressed. To isolate living bacteria and extract DNA, the wound swab was suspended in 900 µL double-distilled water, and a 450-µL of the suspension was centrifuged. The resulting pellet was used for genomic desoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) extraction (DNeasy Blood and Tissue kit; Qiagen, Hilden, Germany). A real-time PCR based on specific primers confirmed the presence of the suspected pathogen DNA in the wound swab sample. Subspecies was identified by block PCR targeting the region of difference 1 (RD1) according to protocols described by Broekhuijsen et al. For culture, 50 µL of the swab suspension was inoculated in 10 mL medium T and streaked onto MTKH, as well as onto chocolate agar plates and Neisseria selective medium plus (both Oxoid Germany GmbH, Wesel, Germany). The liquid medium and the agar plates were incubated at 37 °C with 5% CO2. Bacterial growth typical for the suspected pathogen could be observed on MTKH on day 3 of culture and on the chocolate and Neisseria agar plates on day 4. The patient’s cerebrospinal fluid did not test positive for the suspected pathogen. Minimal inhibitory concentration testing according to the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI; https://clsi.org/standards/products/microbiology/documents/m100/) guidelines for the suspected pathogen demonstrated an in vitro sensitivity to all antibiotics recommended for treatment of the specific infectious disease. The patient’s antibiotic treatment applied until that stage turned out to be inadequate. In a sequencing study (MiSeq sequencer [Illumina Inc., San Diego, CA, USA], see for details) and the phylogenetic analysis (Geneious prime [Biomatters, Auckland, New Zealand], Mauve alignment, followed by neighbor-joining clustering, see for details), the DNA from the strain isolated from the patient’s wound swab was shown to belong to a specific biovar and clade . Fig. 2 Phylogenetic relationship of the suspected pathogen in a wound swab sample from digit IV of the patient’s right hand (A-1825/1) (red, in bold) to isolates from various regions. Strains belonging to a specific major clade are indicated in blue. For each genome sequence, the year of sampling, the host organism, sampling spot (German federal states), and the known final subclade are given. Host organisms: Be beaver, Br brock, H human, Le Lepus, Sc Sciurus, Wb wild boar. Germany’s federal states: BB Brandenburg, HE Hesse, NI Lower Saxony, NW North Rhine-Westphalia, RP Rhineland-Palatinate. Countries: D Germany, FR France. Asterisk indicates no bacterial isolate, genomic DNA only; for further details, see. The analysis was based on a Mauve alignment for colinear genomes. Genomes were generated by DNA sequencing and mapping of DNA reads to the genome of the suspected pathogen strain LVS (for details, see). For the clustering, the neighbor-joining bootstrap method was used, with the suspected pathogen strain OSU18 as an outgroup.
rewritten_case:
A 59-year-old German woman with a past medical history of hypothyroidism and cutaneous lupus erythematosus arrived at the hospital's emergency room 7 days following a bite by a wild Eurasian red squirrel (Sciurus vulgaris). The patient had found the squirrel lying motionless during a walk and was bitten on the right hand's fourth digit and the second digit of the left hand as she attempted to examine the animal. Following immediate wound cleaning and dressing, she was started on an antibiotic regime of cefuroxime 500 mg twice daily, and her tetanus vaccination status was confirmed. 

Six days post-bite, the patient returned to the emergency room with symptoms of general malaise, fever, chills, body aches, and a swollen right elbow, but without any reports of nausea, vomiting, or sensitivity to light and noise. Upon examination, a minor bite was noted on the right hand's fourth digit near the middle phalanx. The area was slightly reddened but showed no clear signs of inflammation. No pain on pressure, movement restriction, or sensory deficits were observed. Likewise, a minor bite without inflammation was evident on the left hand's index finger. 

The patient's vital signs were stable, except for a minor sinus tachycardia. Her lab results showed an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) at 28.6 mg/L with normal leukocyte counts. Tests for procalcitonin, SARS-CoV-2, respiratory syncytial virus, and influenza A and B were all negative. X-ray of the thorax, however, showed a subtle infiltrate in the right lower lobe, which raised the suspicion of a pulmonary process. 

Despite starting intravenous antibiotics (ampicillin/sulbactam, 2 g/1 g) on day 7 post-bite, her condition did not improve, and her fever persisted until day 12. The CRP climbed to 185 mg/L by day 12 without leukocytosis. Therefore, the antibiotic treatment was escalated to piperacillin/tazobactam (4 g/0.5 g) on day 11. Following this regimen, the CRP fell to 74 mg/L by day 14, and a mild leukocytosis was noted. 

Concurrently, the wound on the right hand developed an ulcer-like lesion with swollen reddened edges and a central incrustation, and the right elbow's lymphadenitis continued. At this point, a specific infectious disease was suspected. A wound swab sample from the right hand's fourth digit and a serum sample were sent for further examination. 

The enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) showed borderline IgG and IgM antibodies against the lipopolysaccharide of the suspected pathogen. Real-time PCR confirmed the presence of the suspected pathogen DNA in the wound swab sample. 

The subtle infiltrate noted on the chest X-ray, along with her persistent fever and malaise, raised suspicion for Pulmonary Tularemia. However, despite the chest X-ray findings, the patient’s cerebrospinal fluid and blood cultures remained negative for the suspected pathogen. 

DNA sequencing and phylogenetic analysis confirmed the presence of the suspected pathogen belonging to a specific biovar and clade. Despite these findings, the patient’s antibiotic treatment applied until that stage turned out to be inadequate. The suspected pathogen demonstrated in vitro sensitivity to all recommended antibiotics for treatment of the specific infectious disease. 

In conclusion, the findings were initially suggestive of Pulmonary Tularemia, largely due to the subtle pulmonary infiltrate noted on the chest X-ray, but further testing and clinical progression led to the final diagnosis of Tularemia. This case underscores the importance of considering all clinical, imaging and laboratory findings in reaching an accurate diagnosis.
model_response:
DX: Tularemia

The patient's symptoms, laboratory results, and imaging findings are consistent with a diagnosis of Tularemia. The patient's exposure to a wild Eurasian red squirrel, the development of an ulcer-like lesion at the bite site, and the presence of the suspected pathogen DNA in the wound swab sample all support this diagnosis.
adjudication_notes: Exact/normalized match to true dx alias.

original_case:
We present three cases in which oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) was administered after botulinum toxin treatment. Patient A was a 58-year-old Filipina woman; patient B was a 62-year-old Korean woman; and patient C was a 57-year-old Vietnamese woman. Botulinum toxin was administered to treat the blepharospasm, and oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) was administered to treat the blepharoptosis. These cases were particularly very intriguing, as we observed in Patients A and B that oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) increased the effects of botulinum toxin and resulted in a greater reduction of blepharospasm. In Patient C, we observed the initial effects of oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) after 4 days and reported the preliminary results. Each patient was given the option to complete a survey that assessed the efficacy of botulinum toxin alone and the efficacy of both botulinum toxin and oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) in reducing blepharospasm. Furthermore, the survey asked patients about their perceived stress during the past month. According to the Perceived Stress Scale questionnaire, a score of 0-13 indicates low levels of psychological stress, a score of 14-26 indicates moderate stress, and a score of 27-40 indicates high stress.

Patient A’s past medical history included hypertension and temporomandibular joint disorder. Her ocular history included blepharospasm, upper eyelid ptosis, upper lid dermatochalasis, and dry eye syndrome. She had been using brimonidine tartrate ophthalmic solution (0.15%), carvedilol 6.25 mg oral tablet, desvenlafaxine succinate 25 mg oral tablet, lorazepam 0.5 mg oral tablet, losartan potassium 25 mg oral tablet, and oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%). Silicone punctal plugs had been inserted to treat her dry eye on 20 October 2016. She had been receiving botulinum toxin treatment since 2019. The administration of oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) to treat her condition began on 17 March 2021 .

Fig. 1 Patient A before using oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) Full size image

Patient A’s most recent follow-up examination took place on 9 July 2021 at which time her visual acuities (Va) were 20/20 in the right eye (OD) and 20/20 in the left eye (OS). She had observed a noticeable decrease in her blepharospasm after oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution administration (0.1%). She spoke of not having to use as much energy to keep her eyes open while using the oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) treatment. Patient A received her 19th botulinum injection with nerve block on 9 July 2021 and continues to use the oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) in both eyes (OU) every morning. According to the survey, Patient A indicated that using oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) after a botulinum toxin administration was effective and resulted in little to no blepharospasm after 4.5 months of using oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) () . Patient A had a low stress score of 13 for the past month ().

. Results of the Leicester Peripheral Field Test Survey Full size table

Fig. 2 Patient A after using oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) for 4.5 months Full size image

: Scores of the Perceived Stress Scale questionnaire Full size table

Patient B’s past ocular history included blepharospasm, blepharoptosis, dry eyes, narrow-angle glaucoma, and cataract. She had been using Xiidra ophthalmic solution (Xiidra® 5%; Novartis, Copenhagen, Denmark) in OU twice daily (bid), Lumigan (latanoprost) OU every night (qhs), and oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) OU every morning (qam). Punctal silicone plugs had been inserted to treat her dry eye on 19 December 2016. Patient B had been receiving botulinum toxin treatment since 2016. The administration of oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) to treat Patient B’s condition began on 10 June 2021.

Patient B’s most recent follow-up examination took place on 15 July 2021. Her Va was 20/80-1 OD and 20/20-3 OS. She reported a decrease in her blepharospasm when using oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%). Her most recent botulinum toxin treatment was on 29 October 2021 as was her seventh botulinum treatment. Patient B continues to use oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) OU qam. According to the survey, patient B indicated that the use of oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) after botulinum toxin administration was effective and resulted in little to no blepharospasm after 1 month of its use (). Patient B deferred to complete the Perceived Stress Scale questionnaire. After 6 months of using oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%), Patient B indicated a strong reduction in blepharospasm  during her most recent examination.

Fig. 3 Patient B after using oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) for 6 months Full size image

Patient C’s past medical history included systemic lupus erythematosus. Her ocular history included blepharospasm, blepharoptosis, chalazion, dry eyes, and lagophthalmos. She had been using artificial tears and oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%). She had been receiving botulinum toxin injections for blepharospasm since 2015.

On patient C’s most recent follow-up on 29 July 2021 at which time her VA was 20/20 OD and 20/20 OS. She had arrived for an administration of botulinum toxin to treat her blepharospasm. Patient C received her 34th botulinum toxin administration on 29 July 2021. Oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) was given to her after her examination as another treatment for blepharospasm. According to the survey, patient C indicated that oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) use after botulinum toxin administration did not result in a noticeable blepharospasm reduction after 4 days . Patient C specified that only a small reduction in blepharospasm took place after 4 days of using oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%), yet she decided to continue using oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) long-term to potentially experience more noticeable reductions (). She specified that both botulinum toxin treatment by itself and botulinum toxin treatment with oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) were effective with moderate spasm frequency. Patient C had a Perceived Stress Scale score of 21, indicating moderate stress, for the past month ().

Fig. 4 Patient C before using oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) Full size image
rewritten_case:
In this report, we present an intriguing series of three cases involving the administration of oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) following botulinum toxin treatment for blepharospasm. The patients were a diverse group, including a Filipina woman aged in her late 50s, a Korean woman in her early 60s, and a Vietnamese woman also in her late 50s. 

All three patients were given the option to complete a survey assessing the efficacy of both the botulinum toxin alone and the combined treatment of botulinum toxin and oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) in reducing blepharospasm. The survey also included questions on their perceived stress levels over a recent period using the Perceived Stress Scale questionnaire, which indicates low, moderate, or high stress based on scores of 0-13, 14-26, and 27-40, respectively.

Patient A had a medical history that included hypertension and temporomandibular joint disorder. Her ocular history was notable for blepharospasm, upper eyelid ptosis, upper lid dermatochalasis, and dry eye syndrome. She was using a range of medications and treatments, including brimonidine tartrate ophthalmic solution (0.15%), carvedilol 6.25 mg oral tablet, desvenlafaxine succinate 25 mg oral tablet, lorazepam 0.5 mg oral tablet, losartan potassium 25 mg oral tablet, and oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%). In addition, silicone punctal plugs had been inserted for her dry eye syndrome. Her visual acuities were 20/20 in both eyes on her most recent follow-up examination. Patient A reported a marked decrease in her blepharospasm following administration of oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%). 

Patient B had a past ocular history of blepharospasm, blepharoptosis, dry eyes, narrow-angle glaucoma, and cataract. She was using Xiidra ophthalmic solution (Xiidra® 5%; Novartis, Copenhagen, Denmark) in both eyes twice daily, Lumigan (latanoprost) in both eyes every night, and oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) in both eyes every morning. Punctal silicone plugs had also been inserted to treat her dry eye. On her most recent follow-up examination, her visual acuities were 20/80-1 in the right eye and 20/20-3 in the left eye. Patient B reported a decrease in her blepharospasm with the use of oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%).

Patient C's past medical history included systemic lupus erythematosus. Her ocular history included blepharospasm, blepharoptosis, chalazion, dry eyes, and lagophthalmos. She was using artificial tears and oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%). On her most recent follow-up, her visual acuity was 20/20 in both eyes. She reported only a small reduction in blepharospasm after using oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%), but decided to continue its use long-term in hope of more noticeable reductions. 

In summary, the use of oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) following botulinum toxin treatment varied in efficacy among the three patients. Further studies into this treatment combination may provide valuable insights into managing blepharospasm.
model_response:
DX: Blepharospasm

The patients presented with a history of blepharospasm, which is a type of involuntary muscle spasm that affects the eyelid. The administration of oxymetazoline hydrochloride ophthalmic solution (0.1%) following botulinum toxin treatment suggests that the diagnosis is blepharospasm, as the patients reported varying degrees of relief from the symptoms.

original_case:
A 68-year-old female Caucasian patient was transferred to our department in April 2021 after discovering a retroperitoneal mass. The patient’s history was unremarkable, except for mild arterial hypertension well treated with calcium channel blockers and diabetes. There were no hypertensive crises in her anamnesis. One month ago, she complained of dyspnea, fever, and chest pain. Given the presentation during the coronavirus pandemic, a computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was performed  in line with the diagnostic pathway for COVID-19, which incidentally showed a retroperitoneal necrotizing mass. 

Fig. 1 Computed tomography (CT) scan in pulmonary (A) and mediastinal (B) windows revealing ground-glass opacities related to COVID-19 infection and an incidental retroperitoneal mass (white arrow). 

Full size image Subsequent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed  and revealed an inhomogeneous, encapsulated, partially and vividly contrast-enhancing tumor, with a diameter of 16 × 12 cm. It was located in the left retroperitoneal with a close connection to the abdominal aorta, iliopsoas muscle, and upper pole of the left kidney. Thick and tortuous arteries and veins were observed inside and at the periphery of the tumor. There were no metastases or abdominal lymphadenopathy. 

Fig. 2. MRI in axial, coronal, and sagittal T2w (A–C), axial T1w (D), and axial and coronal T1 Gd (E, F) showing large retroperitoneal mass. 

Full size image Special blood analysis for catecholamines was performed with the following results: noradrenaline (blood plasma) 3.57 nmol/l (norm value < 1.05 nmol/l), adrenaline (blood plasma) 0.48 pg/ml (norm value < 0.36 ng/l). Urinary specimens were collected for assay 24-hour urine metabolites of catecholamines. The results were as follows: metanephrine: 326 µg/24 hours (norm value < 28 µg/24 hours), normetanephrine 1756 nmol/24 hours (norm value < 143 nmol/24 hours). Immunohistochemical examination confirms neuroendocrine differentiation with chromogranin A 14,800 ng/ml (norm value < 104 ng/ml). 

After a multidisciplinary meeting, we decided to perform an open surgery preceded by a preoperative antihypertensive medication for safe resection. The tumor was completely resected en bloc without the removal of adjacent tissues. During the operation, her blood pressure and heart rate were quite stable. Following removal, it was identified that the tumor exhibited a capsule that was soft and gray-red . Hemorrhage, cystic degeneration, and necrosis were observed inside the tumors. On pathologic examination, tumor cells were oval or polygonal in shape and arranged in nests or trabeculae, containing rich cytoplasm with eosinophilic fine granules. Large nuclei were strongly stained and exhibited round or oval nucleoli. Tumor cells with deformed, large, or multiple nuclei were observed. 

Fig. 3 Photograph of resected specimen showing gray-red capsulated structure with focal areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. 

Full size image
rewritten_case:
A 68-year-old Caucasian woman was referred to our department due to an incidentally discovered retroperitoneal mass. The patient's medical history was relatively uneventful, save for well-managed mild arterial hypertension with calcium channel blockers and diabetes. There were no records of hypertensive crises.

She had earlier reported symptoms like dyspnea, fever, and chest pain. Given the global situation with the coronavirus pandemic, a computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was performed as part of the diagnostic protocol for COVID-19. The scan unexpectedly revealed a retroperitoneal necrotizing mass.

Fig. 1 Computed tomography (CT) scan in pulmonary (A) and mediastinal (B) windows showing ground-glass opacities indicative of COVID-19 infection and an incidental retroperitoneal mass (white arrow).

Further magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was carried out, which detected an uneven, encapsulated, partially, and vividly contrast-enhancing tumor. The mass, measuring 16 × 12 cm, was located in the left retroperitoneal space with proximity to the abdominal aorta, iliopsoas muscle, and upper pole of the left kidney. Notably, the tumor was interspersed with thick and tortuous arteries and veins. No metastases or abdominal lymphadenopathy were identified.

Fig. 2. MRI in axial, coronal, and sagittal T2w (A–C), axial T1w (D), and axial and coronal T1 Gd (E, F) presenting large retroperitoneal mass.

A special blood analysis for catecholamines was conducted. The results revealed elevated levels: noradrenaline (blood plasma) 3.57 nmol/l (norm value < 1.05 nmol/l), adrenaline (blood plasma) 0.48 pg/ml (norm value < 0.36 ng/l). Additionally, 24-hour urine metabolites of catecholamines were assayed. The findings were as follows: metanephrine: 326 µg/24 hours (norm value < 28 µg/24 hours), normetanephrine 1756 nmol/24 hours (norm value < 143 nmol/24 hours). Immunohistochemical examination confirmed neuroendocrine differentiation with chromogranin A 14,800 ng/ml (norm value < 104 ng/ml).

A multidisciplinary team decided to proceed with an open surgery, preceded by preoperative antihypertensive medication for safe resection. The tumor was fully excised en bloc without the need for removal of adjacent tissues. Throughout the operation, her blood pressure and heart rate remained stable. Post-removal examination revealed the tumor had a soft and gray-red capsule. Features like hemorrhage, cystic degeneration, and necrosis were evident within the tumors. Histopathological examination identified the tumor cells as oval or polygonal in shape, arranged in nests or trabeculae, with rich cytoplasm with fine eosinophilic granules. The large nuclei were strongly stained and exhibited round or oval nucleoli. Tumor cells with deformed, large, or multiple nuclei were also observed.

Fig. 3 Photograph of resected specimen showing gray-red capsulated structure with focal areas of hemorrhage and necrosis.
model_response:
DX: Pheochromocytoma

The patient's symptoms of dyspnea, fever, and chest pain, along with the elevated levels of noradrenaline and adrenaline, and the presence of neuroendocrine differentiation with chromogranin A, are consistent with a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. The imaging studies, including the CT and MRI, also support this diagnosis, as they show a retroperitoneal mass with enhancement and a soft and gray-red capsule, which are characteristic features of a pheochromocytoma.

original_case: A 7-year-old Persian boy was referred to the emergency room with complaint of abdominal pain. His symptoms had started 2 days ago in the right lower quadrant and gradually increased, accompanied with nausea and vomiting. He was fully vaccinated, had no significant family, social, or environmental history and had normal growth and development with no history of previous illness. The child was not ill, and his vital signs included blood pressure of 111/720 mmHg, pulse rate of 75 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and temperature of 37 °C. Abdominal examination revealed right lower quadrant tenderness and rebound tenderness, while other parts of the abdomen had no pain or tenderness. There were no other findings on physical and neurological examination. Laboratory tests such as complete blood count and liver function tests revealed normal values as follows: white blood cells 6.7 × 10^3/µL (4.5–11 × 10^3/µL) (neutrophils 58%, lymphocytes 31%); red blood cells 4.77 × 10^6/µL (4.7–6.1 × 10^6/µL); hemoglobin 10.1 g/dL (11.2–14.5 g/dL); hematocrit 33% (39–50%); mean corpuscular volume 69.2 fL (80–100 fL); red cell distribution width 17% (11.5–15%); platelets 294 × 10^3/µL (150–450 × 10^3/µL); aspartate aminotransferase 22 U/L (8–33 U/L); alanine transaminase 27 U/L (7–55 U/L). Ultrasonography revealed enhanced pericecal fat echogenicity due to the inflammatory changes with mild free fluid collection in the interloop . The patient underwent a diagnostic laparotomy with suspicion of acute appendicitis with a Lanz incision. The laparotomy, however, revealed a normal-appearing appendix. The incision was not extended, and laparotomic appendectomy and omentectomy were done through Lanz incision. The pathology report noted a creamy normal appendix, measuring 6 cm in length and 0.5 cm in greatest diameter. Omentum pathology was reported as fibroconnective tissue with congestion. Fig. 1 Ultrasonography showing hyperechogenicity of pericecal fat with mild free fluid in the interloop at the site of tenderness in the right lower quadrant Full size image Fig. 2 Intraoperative findings, before resection. The sudden color change is evident in the image (arrow) Full size image
rewritten_case:
A Persian boy, aged 7, was brought into the emergency department with the main complaint of abdominal discomfort. The child first started experiencing pain in his right lower quadrant, which had worsened over an unspecified period of time, accompanied by the onset of nausea and episodes of vomiting. The patient had been fully vaccinated and had no noteworthy family, social, or environmental history. His growth and development were normal, and he had not experienced any significant illness prior to this. His overall appearance did not suggest any acute illness, and his vital signs were stable with a blood pressure of 111/720 mmHg, pulse of 75 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and a body temperature of 37 °C. 

Examination of the abdomen revealed tenderness in the right lower quadrant, with notable rebound tenderness. However, the rest of the abdomen seemed to be without pain or tenderness. Physical and neurological evaluations did not present any additional findings. Laboratory tests including complete blood count and liver function tests were conducted, all of which showed values within normal ranges. 

Ultrasonography highlighted an increase in the echogenicity of pericecal fat, likely a result of inflammatory changes, along with a mild free fluid collection in the interloop. With the suspicion of acute appendicitis, the patient was taken to surgery for a diagnostic laparotomy through a Lanz incision. Upon inspection, the appendix appeared to be normal. The incision was not extended, and a laparotomic appendectomy and omentectomy were performed through the same Lanz incision. The pathology report noted the appendix to be of normal consistency and measuring around 6 cm in length and 0.5 cm in diameter. The omentum pathology was reported as fibroconnective tissue with congestion. Ultrasonography indicated hyperechogenicity of pericecal fat with mild free fluid in the interloop at the site of tenderness in the right lower quadrant. An intraoperative image showed a sudden color change before resection.
model_response:
DX: Meckel's diverticulum

The patient's symptoms, including abdominal discomfort, nausea, and vomiting, are consistent with a bowel obstruction. The ultrasonography findings of increased echogenicity of pericecal fat and mild free fluid collection in the interloop, along with the intraoperative image showing a sudden color change, suggest a possible intestinal obstruction, which is often caused by a Meckel's diverticulum.

original_case: An 8-month-old African male, born by spontaneous vaginal delivery from nonconsanguineous parents, was admitted at our hospital because of persistent eczematous skin rashes since day 9 of life. The rash started on the face, later progressing to involve the entire body except the palms and soles of the feet. The skin lesions were itchy with obvious peeling. He had significant improvement of the symptoms while using steroid creams, with flares upon cessation. He also presented with a history of recurrent purulent nasal discharge with the first episode being at 4 months of age. Four episodes were reported since the onset of symptoms, which were at least a month apart, all being treated with a course of oral antibiotics. Additionally, he had three episodes of bilateral purulent ear discharge starting at 4 months of age, which were associated with an on and off low-grade fever. Ever since, he had been experiencing multiple episodes of similar symptoms at least once a month. There is a history of death of a male sibling at 8 months of age who had similar symptoms to the index patient. The only sibling who is alive is an 8-year-old female who is healthy with no similar symptoms. Furthermore, there is history of early pregnancy loss at 2 months of gestational age, but the sex of the abortus was not determined. His mother received adequate prenatal care. He was delivered at term via caesarean section owing to abnormal lie with birth weight (BWT) of 3.5 kg with no obvious perinatal insult. After 72 hours they were discharged home with no reported complications. Immunization was up to date; however, the Bacillus Calmette–Guérin (BCG) vaccine scar was not visible. Although he had weight faltering, his developmental milestones were appropriate for his age. On examination, he had extensive confluence of hypopigmented patches with eczematous papules on the trunk, extremities, and scalp, as well as crusted plaques and excoriations on the periauricular area and skin folds. The lesions spared the palms, soles of the feet, and mucocutaneous membrane (Fig. 1 a, b). Fig. 1 a Eczematous papules with erythema on the cheeks. Hypopigmented patches and excoriations on the trunk. b Crusted eczematous papules on the scalp with excoriated periauricular area Full size image On otoscopic examination, there was purulent discharge visible on the external auditory meatus, with an intact keratinized tympanic membrane but with loss of the normal reflex. Cardiovascular, respiratory, nervous, and abdominal systems examination was normal. Blood was taken for complete blood count (CBC), and the results showed mild normocytic normochromic anemia, low platelet count, and low mean platelet volume (MPV) (). A peripheral blood smear showed microthrombocytopenia . HIV serological test was negative. Immunoglobulin assay revealed significantly elevated immunoglobulin E (IgE), elevated immunoglobulin A (IgA), and immunoglobulin G (IgG) with normal immunoglobulin M (IgM) ().  CBC results Full size table Fig. 2 A Peripheral blood smear slide; Red arrows showing micro thrombocytes Full size image  Other laboratory test results Full size table Given the clinical and laboratory presentation of our patient and his biological sex, we had a high index of suspicion. A dried blood spot was sent to Rostock, Germany, to test for the gene using CentoXone Solo [including next-generation sequencing (NGS)-based copy number variation (CNV) analysis]. A hemizygous pathogenic variant was identified in the gene (NM_000377.2:c.403C>T). The variant c.403C>T p.(Gln135*) creates a premature stop codon. Loss of function is the reported disease-associated mechanism.
rewritten_case:
A young African male infant, born via spontaneous vaginal delivery from nonconsanguineous parents, was brought to our medical facility for ongoing eczematous skin rashes. The rashes initially appeared on his face, and over time, spread to nearly all parts of the body, leaving only the palms and soles of the feet unaffected. The skin lesions were notably itchy and peeling. Steroid creams brought about significant relief from the symptoms, though the rashes would flare up again after discontinuation of the creams. 

The infant also had a history of recurrent purulent nasal discharge, with multiple occasions reported since the symptoms first appeared. Each episode was treated with a regimen of oral antibiotics. In addition, he suffered from several instances of bilateral purulent ear discharge, often accompanied by a sporadic low-grade fever. These symptoms recurred somewhat regularly. 

A male sibling had died at a similar age to the infant, presenting similar symptoms. The only surviving sibling, an 8-year-old female, showed no such symptoms. There was also a record of an early pregnancy loss, though the sex of the fetus was undetermined. The mother received adequate prenatal care and the infant was delivered at term via caesarean section due to abnormal lie. His birth weight was 3.5 kg and no perinatal complications were reported. They were discharged home after 72 hours with no complications. 

Despite being up-to-date with immunizations, the Bacillus Calmette–Guérin (BCG) vaccine scar was not visible on the infant. Though his weight faltering was observed, his developmental milestones were age-appropriate. 

Upon examination, extensive hypopigmented patches with eczematous papules were found on the trunk, extremities, and scalp, as well as crusted plaques and excoriations on the periauricular area and skin folds. His palms, soles of the feet, and mucocutaneous membrane were spared from the lesions. 

Otoscopic examination revealed purulent discharge in the external auditory meatus, with an intact keratinized tympanic membrane, albeit with loss of the normal reflex. Cardiovascular, respiratory, nervous, and abdominal systems examination was normal. 

Blood tests showed mild normocytic normochromic anemia, low platelet count, and low mean platelet volume (MPV). A peripheral blood smear revealed microthrombocytopenia. HIV serological test was negative. Immunoglobulin assay revealed significantly elevated immunoglobulin E (IgE), elevated immunoglobulin A (IgA), and immunoglobulin G (IgG) with normal immunoglobulin M (IgM). 

Considering the clinical and laboratory presentation of our patient, a dried blood spot was sent for gene testing, which revealed a hemizygous pathogenic variant in the gene (NM_000377.2:c.403C>T). The variant c.403C>T p.(Gln135*) creates a premature stop codon, indicating a loss of function, a recognized disease-associated mechanism.
model_response:
DX: Hyper-IgE Syndrome

The patient's symptoms, including eczematous skin rashes, recurrent respiratory infections, and a history of recurrent nasal discharge and ear discharge, are consistent with Hyper-IgE Syndrome. The laboratory results, including elevated IgE, IgA, and IgG levels, and a hemizygous pathogenic variant in the STAT3 gene, further support this diagnosis.

original_case:
Subjects
Six patients are reported here, of whom three suffered from a condition related to chemical exposure and three had another condition. Of these six patients, three were men, with four right eyes affected. The mean age was 46.2 (range 34–66) years. All patients were prospectively enrolled as a single group and gave informed consent to the investigators at the Faculty of Medicine Siriraj Hospital (Institute Review Board [IRB] Ethical Approval No. SI 227/2013). The protocol could be terminated at any time due to loss to follow-up, inability to obtain mucosal tissue, or patient’s request. The inclusion criteria included patients aged > 20 years with total LSCD or total conjunctivalization from any cause. The exclusion criteria included pregnancy, severe infection, keratitis, and eye or buccal mucosal complications. All standard preparations, including surgery, work flow, laboratory tests, environmental controls, materials, chemical materials, records, pharmacological storage, quality/safety checks, and transportation, were managed by Siriraj Hospital and complied with GMP guidelines for medicinal products. All procedures strictly followed the regulations in the U.S. Food and Drug Administration Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Title 21 Part 1271 (Human cells, tissue and cellular and tissue-based products;
https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/cdrh/cfdocs/cfcfr/CFRSearch.cfm?CFRPart=1271
) and  Title 21 CFR Part 600 (Biological product, current good tissue practice [CGTP];
https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/cdrh/cfdocs/cfcfr/CFRSearch.cfm?CFRPart=600
), as well as with additional requirements for manufacturers of human cells, tissues and cellular and tissue-based products. Any adverse event, deviation, or intervention would be spontaneously reported to the IRB for review and further actions.
Feeder cells
3T3-J2 fibroblasts were used as feeder cells. They were seeded to tissue culture flasks and maintained in Dulbecco's Modified Eagle Medium and 10% fetal bovine serum for 7–14 days to reach confluence, following which the 3T3-J2 cells were irradiated twice with 34 cGy X-ray each time to inhibit cell division. The irradiated cells (11.9 × 10
4
cells/mL) were plated in 2-mL aliquots onto Nunc UpCell 3.5-cm dishes (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) or as 4.7-mL aliquots onto 60-mm tissue culture dishes and kept overnight prior to the seeding of mucosal epithelial cells.
Oral mucosal sample collection
About 12–14 days before the planned transplant, an oral mucosal tissue sample (0.5 × 1.5 × 0.3 cm; width × length × depth) was excised under local anesthesia using disposable blade. The wound was sutured with Dacron 5-0 fiber to stop bleeding. Antibiotic and pain-relief medication were provided for 3 days. The mucosal tissue was soaked in 10% betadine in distilled water (1:8 dilution) for 10 min, then rinsed with 0.5% levofloxacin before being transported in 30 mL FDM (DMEM, 10% FBS, 0.125 μg/mL amphotericin B, 100 IU/mL penicillin G, 100 μg/mL kanamycin) in a sterilized box to the tissue culture facility. The dissected tissue was exposed to 1000 PU/mL dispase to separate the mucosal epithelial layer from the subcutaneous layer. The epithelial layer was digested with 0.25% trypsin EDTA to segregate epithelial cells. The isolated epithelial cells were seeded onto the irradiated feeder cells at a density of 2–3 × 10
5
cells/35-mm dish and maintained in 2 mL KCM medium with epidermal growth factor at 37 °C, 5% CO
2
for 12–14 days before the transplant. For the colony-forming assay (CFA), the epithelial cells were seeded at 3000–5000 cells/60-mm dish; the mucosal epithelial sheets were then examined for quality and safety (Table
1
), including by immunohistochemistry, flow cytometry, and real-time PCR. Samples were submitted for sterility tests including bacterial culture, fungal culture and endotoxin assay at the Department of Microbiology, Siriraj Hospital.
 The criteria for the safety test of the epithelial sheet
Full size table
Transplantation
The mucosal sheet was transferred in a close-system box kept at 20 °C to the operating room. The cell sheet was harvested on a ring of PVDF membrane (outer diameter: 25 mm; inner diameter: 15 mm). The transplantation of the cultivated oral mucosal epithelial sheet was performed at 20°C with the patient under general anesthesia. The first step was the excision of conjunctiva and fibrous tissue on the cornea, namely symblepharon lysis, prior to the actual transplant. Before and after surgery, the subjects received topical antibiotic every 2 hours, and topical corticosteroid 4 times daily. Intravenous ceftriaxone (1 g) was given every 12 hours for 3 days, then oral antibiotic for the next 5 days. Intravenous solumedrol (125 mg) was given every 12 hours for the first day and once daily for 2 days, and oral prednisolone (25 mg) was given twice daily for 2–4 weeks. The subjects wore protective contact lenses for 1 year following surgery. The symptoms, clinical findings of inflammation, and the accompanying images were recorded in a dedicated hard disk and graded for severity at the follow-up periods:  2 and 4 weeks and 3, 6, and 12 months. The main outcome included corneal epithelial defect (0–100%) and conjunctivalization on the cornea (25–100%) within 1 year (graded from 0–5, with 0 = bad and 5 = excellent). The secondary outcome included visual acuity, corneal opacity, corneal vascularization, and complications. Only the investigators could access the collected data.
Statistical analysis
The results are shown as the mean ± standard error of the mean of at least triplicate determinants. Student’s
t
-test was used for the analysis. A
p
value < 0.05 was considered to be significant.
rewritten_case:
Patients
This report discusses six patients, three of whom presented with a condition related to chemical exposure while the remaining three were diagnosed with a different condition. The group consisted of three males, with four instances of the right eye being affected. The patients' ages varied, with a mean age of 46.2, ranging from 34 to 66 years. The patients were all part of a singular study group, enrolled at the Faculty of Medicine Siriraj Hospital and had given informed consent for the research (Institute Review Board [IRB] Ethical Approval No. SI 227/2013). The study could be curtailed at any point due to loss to follow-up, difficulties in obtaining mucosal tissue, or at the patient’s request. The inclusion criteria comprised of patients aged above 20 years suffering from total LSCD or total conjunctivalization from any cause. The study excluded pregnant patients, those with severe infections, keratitis, and eye or buccal mucosal complications.

Feeder cells and Oral mucosal sample collection
3T3-J2 fibroblasts were utilized as feeder cells in this research. These cells were seeded to tissue culture flasks and sustained in Dulbecco's Modified Eagle Medium with 10% fetal bovine serum. After reaching confluence, the 3T3-J2 cells were exposed to 34 cGy X-ray, twice, to inhibit cell division. Prior to the seeding of mucosal epithelial cells, the irradiated cells were plated in specific quantities onto specific dishes and kept overnight.

Close to the transplant date, a small oral mucosal tissue sample was extracted under local anesthesia. The wound was then sutured to stop bleeding. Antibiotics and pain relief medication were provided for a short period following the procedure. The mucosal tissue was then soaked, rinsed, and transported to the tissue culture facility. The tissue was then subjected to a series of steps to segregate the epithelial cells. These isolated epithelial cells were then seeded onto the irradiated feeder cells and sustained in a specific medium for a certain period prior to the transplant.

Transplantation and Follow up
The transplantation of the cultivated oral mucosal epithelial sheet was performed in the operating room. The cell sheet was harvested on a PVDF membrane and transplanted under general anesthesia. Post-surgery, the subjects received topical antibiotic and corticosteroid treatments. Intravenous ceftriaxone and solumedrol were given followed by oral antibiotics and prednisolone. The subjects wore protective contact lenses for a year following surgery. The symptoms, clinical findings of inflammation, and the accompanying images were recorded and graded for severity at the follow-up periods. The main outcomes were corneal epithelial defect and conjunctivalization on the cornea, while the secondary outcome included visual acuity, corneal opacity, corneal vascularization, and complications. Only the investigators could access the collected data.

Statistical analysis
The results are presented as the mean ± standard error of the mean of at least triplicate determinants. Student’s t-test was used for the analysis. A p value < 0.05 was considered to be significant.
model_response:
DX: Chemical-induced conjunctivitis

The patients' presentation with a condition related to chemical exposure and the inclusion criteria of patients with total LSCD or total conjunctivalization from any cause suggest that the most likely diagnosis is chemical-induced conjunctivitis. The study's focus on oral mucosal tissue sample collection and transplantation of cultivated oral mucosal epithelial sheets also support this diagnosis.

original_case: An Iranian (Asian) pregnant woman aged 32 years old with a primary complaint of preterm uterine contraction and vaginal bleeding presented to the obstetric ward of Yas Hospital (Tehran-Iran, January 2021). She was a multi-para woman (Gravida: 3, Para: 2, Living: 2, Abortion: 0) with a gestational age of 30 weeks. She did not report any prenatal complications and had received corticosteroid therapy 2 days prior to hospital admission. Upon presentation, magnesium sulfate was immediately administered but she was transferred to the operation room for repeat Cesarean section due to progressive cervical dilation. A preterm male newborn with a first-minute Apgar score of 7 and birth weight of 1190 g was born. Physical examination after birth showed a notable frontal bossing, acrocyanosis, and diffuse head, neck, hand, and leg ecchymosis. Anterior and posterior fontanelles were normal. No congenital anomaly or abdominal organomegaly was observed. Peripheral pulses were palpable and heart sounds were normal without any abnormal sounds. His reflexes were normal, but limb movements were hypotonic. Due to an increase in his respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) score from 4 to 7 and signs of respiratory distress (inter- and subcostal retraction, grunting, and decreased breathing sounds), resuscitation measures were initiated. He was then given nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) in the operation room that was subsequently switched to mechanical ventilation in the NICU. Intratracheal surfactant and intravenous antibiotic therapy were also initiated in the NICU. Under mechanical ventilation with synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation (SIMV) setup, his O2 saturation, blood pressure, and heart rate improved to > 94%, 70/35 mmHg, and 160 beats per minute, respectively. On day 3 post-NICU admission, a PICC line (Premicath; 1Fr/28 G; VYGON, Écouen, France; Code 1261.080) was also inserted from the auxiliary vein of the right upper extremity for intravenous therapy, delivery of medications, and parenteral nutrition. A chest X-ray showed that the tip of the PICC line was in the appropriate place in the superior vena cava (SVC) . Mechanical ventilation was discontinued 72 h post-NICU admission because of improved respiratory condition and normal automatic breathing. After extubation, low-flow oxygen therapy was continued and low-volume feeding was initiated based on his tolerance. His weight gain was acceptable and the clinical situation improved, including a gradual increase in the feeding volume and respiratory support. On day 10 post-NICU admission, he suddenly developed hypotonia, apnea, hypoxia, and bradycardia. He was gasping, had hypotension, and there was an absence of peripheral pulses. In the first minutes after the alarm signs, resuscitation was initiated and ventilation support provided, together with administration of inotropic drugs (1–3 minutes). Despite the high-frequency setup of the mechanical ventilator, the endotracheal tube was checked for displacement or obstruction due to his persistent critical condition (hypotension and shortness of breath). Pneumothorax and equipment failure were also ruled out. Several medical measures were initiated (approximately at minutes 3–4), including nothing by mouth (NPO), high-dose antibiotic therapy, emergency echocardiography, brain ultrasound, arterial and venous blood sampling, blood cell count, and arterial blood gas analysis. Fig. 1 Chest X-ray findings showing the tip of the peripherally inserted central catheter line at appropriate position Full size image Echocardiography was performed over the next 5–7 minutes , and the results showed severe pericardial effusion, right atrial collapse, ventricle dysfunction, and tamponade. The ejection fraction value was 40%, and there was no evidence of atrial septal defect (ASD), pleural effusion, or patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). A peripheral venous catheter was inserted, and the PICC was removed at the same time. Urgent pericardiocentesis was performed through subxiphoid cannulation guided by echocardiography and 10 ml of the pericardial fluid was aspirated (over the next 7–15 minutes) (Electronic Supplementary Material file 1: Video S1). The aspirated fluid was sent to the laboratory for tests, with the results showing severe acidosis (pH 6.80) and hyperglycemia (). To improve the hyperglycemia and metabolic acidosis, the patient was hydrated with low glucose solution and bicarbonate was initiated. Respiratory support was continued and antibiotics covering Staphylococcus aureus and Gram-negative bacteria were administered. Brain sonography was also performed, which was normal. The workup sequence is shown in . Fig. 2 Emergency echocardiography Full size image  Results of arterial blood gas and laboratory blood tests Full size table  Sequence of performed workups following onset of alarms Full size table Under mechanical ventilation the respiratory parameters improved gradually; pericardial drainage and PICC removal occurred concurrently. O2 saturation increased to 95%, blood pressure elevated, and vital signs remained stable. Analysis of the aspirated pericardial fluid showed a hyperglycemic fluid (). A dramatic improvement in the neonate's clinical responses (after pericardial drainage and PICC removal) was suggestive of PICC displacement, pericardial perforation, and cardiac tamponade. Echocardiography was repeated (× 3) every 12 hours to ensure no further pericardial effusion was present. On day 40 after birth, the patient was still in the hospital but showed weight gain; he was in good condition without requiring respiratory support.  Results of laboratory analysis of aspirated pericardial fluid Full size table

original_case:
A 17-year-old Chinese girl with no previous medical history or particular family history was admitted to our hospital with fever, headache, and weakness for 4 days. The patient developed paroxysmal headache and dizziness at school, followed by low-grade fever and weakness, without cough and expectoration. She then went to the emergency room of another hospital for treatment. During her hospitalization, she developed abdominal pain and computed tomography scan of the chest and abdomen revealed multiple lymphadenopathy and serous cavity effusion. After treatment with ceftriaxone and oseltamivir, the symptoms were not relieved, and her temperature peaked at 38.9 °C. Subsequently, the patient was admitted to our hospital for further diagnosis and treatment.

Physical examination at admission revealed a fever of 37.7 ℃, anemic, abdominal tenderness, and anterior tibial edema. Several enlarged lymph nodes with slight tenderness were palpable in her bilateral neck and armpit. The patient’s height and weight were 168 cm and 48 kg, respectively, and her expression was indifferent.

Laboratory findings revealed elevated acute phase reactants with erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) at 112 mm, and C-reactive protein (CRP) at 213.5 mg/L. Blood tests revealed pancytopenia and anemia (total white blood cell count: 2.27 × 10^9/L; hemoglobin level: 65 g/L; red blood cells 1.81 × 10^9/L, platelets 89 × 10^9/L; reticulocyte 1.9%). Urine tests showed proteinuria (1.66 g/days) and serum albumin was 26.5/L. Coombs test was positive and platelet antibody test was negative. The immunoglobulin G (IgG) was 24.5 g/dL and complement (C3 and C4) levels were decreased. Anticardiolipin antibody IgG was positive. The patient tested positive for the following autoantibodies: high titer of antinuclear antibody of 1:1000, positivity for anti-double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibody, anti-nRNP/Sm antibody, anti-SS-A/Ro and anti-SS-B/La antibodies, anti-histone antibody, anti-ribosomal P protein antibody, and anti-nucleosome antibody. Tumor series and blood culture were normal.

Ultrasonography showed bilateral pleural effusion. Magnetic resonance of the brain revealed a few small cavities in the left semi-soft circle area and bilateral frontal cortex. No organic lesions were found on enhanced computed tomography scan of small intestine. Low bone mineral density detected by the dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (lumbar spine: Z-score, 1.7).

To rule out other hematologic diseases, bone marrow examination was performed, which showed no malignancy, but the Giemsa banding revealed a karyotype of 47,XXX in all 20 metaphase cells analyzed (Figure 1).

Fig. 1 Karyotype of this patient Full size image

The patient was diagnosed based on fever, hemolytic anemia, pancytopenia, low C3 and C4, proteinuria greater than 0.5 g/day, serous effusion, antinuclear antibody positive, and anti-dsDNA positive, fulfilling the 2019 European League Against Rheumatism/American College of Rheumatology (EULAR/ACR) criteria, complicated with lupus nephritis, pancytopenia, hemolytic anemia, serous effusion, lacunar cerebral infarction, and trisomy X syndrome. Although she had positive anti-SS-A/Ro and anti-SS-B/La antibodies, and anticardiolipin antibody, she did not fulfill the classification criteria of Sjögren’s syndrome (SS) or antiphospholipid syndrome. The SLE disease activity index (SLEDAI) score was 17, indicating the patient had high disease activity.

original_case:
A 25-year-old Iranian woman (weight: 57 kg; body mass index: 20.54 kg/m²) was admitted to the hospital emergency room in Tehran, Iran after being discovered unconscious and unresponsive to sensory and pain stimulation. She was a medical intern at the same hospital in the internal medicine ward, and the episode happened at 3 a.m. at the end of her shifts, while she was sleeping in the doctors’ room. Because other colleges were unaware of her previous medical history, the protocol for unconscious patients was immediately implemented. Vital signs of the patient upon arrival in the emergency room were: blood pressure = 140/70 mmHg; heart rate = 110 bpm; oxygen saturation level = 98% on the right atrial; respiratory rate = 16 and temperature was 36.8 °C. The patient’s BG level was 25 mg/dl by self-monitoring blood glucose (SMBG) device. Since the patient was unconscious, she received an intravenous (IV) bolus of 50% dextrose. Laboratory tests were run, including thyroid, kidney and liver function tests; the results are shown in . All tests revealed no abnormalities, despite a low BG level. The insulin level was high with a low C-peptide level. 

Uptake of the IV bolus of dextrose improved the patient's level of consciousness, but she still had focal neurological symptoms, including hemiparesis and aphasia. Fifteen minutes after the initiation of treatment with serum dextrose, she was responsive to pain and stimulation. She remained in the emergency room for monitoring, and after 1 h all neurological symptoms had disappeared, satisfying Whipple’s triad of hypoglycemia. Thus, a CT scan to rule out vascular events was deferred. After regaining consciousness, the patient mentioned having T1DM since the age of 18 years and receiving regular treatment with insulin and Neutral Protamine Hagedorn insulin (NPH). In this setting, non-beta cell tumors are unlikely to be diagnosed. The patient also claimed experiencing HU for the previous 2 years. She also mentioned at least three episodes of severe hypoglycemic episodes weekly during the last 3 months that may have necessitated the assistance of others. These episodes mostly happened at night. 

The patient claims that she was very active during her work shift and did not have time to eat adequately, but she injected insulin at the usual dose. The injection regimen of the patient consisted of multiple insulin injections day: regular insulin, 10 U before breakfast and dinner, and 6 U before lunch; NPH insulin, 25 U in the morning and 10 U at night). Her dose had been adjusted at her last visit to her endocrinologist 3 months previously, but she has had several severe hypoglycemic attacks during the last 4 weeks. The patient’s lifestyle had also changed in the last 6 months, as she had begun routine gym exercise to manage her insulin needs and glycemic control. 

She was examined by a neurologist in the morning for her focal neurological symptoms, and the examination revealed no deficits. Her medical history was also concerning for hypoglycemia-associated autonomic failure (HAAF), and she was recommended to have this condition evaluated as outpatient. To avoid recurrent hypoglycemia, further laboratory tests and a follow-up evaluation with an endocrinologist were recommended, as well a switch from human insulins to analog insulins.
rewritten_case:
A 25-year-old Iranian woman, a medical intern at a Tehran hospital, was found unconscious in the physicians' lounge after her shift at 3 a.m. The patient, who had a weight of 57 kg and a body mass index of 20.54 kg/m², was unresponsive to both sensory and pain stimuli. As her colleagues were unaware of her medical history, they immediately followed the protocol for unconscious patients. 

Upon arrival in the emergency room, her vital signs were recorded as: blood pressure = 140/70 mmHg; heart rate = 110 bpm; oxygen saturation = 98% in the right atrium; respiratory rate = 16; and temperature = 36.8 °C. Her blood glucose (BG) level was measured at a low 25 mg/dl using a self-monitoring blood glucose device. In response to her unconscious state, she was administered a 50% dextrose intravenous bolus. Subsequent lab tests, including thyroid, kidney, and liver function, did not reveal any abnormalities, aside from her low BG level. However, her insulin level was found to be high, accompanied by a low C-peptide level.

Though her consciousness improved following the dextrose administration, she displayed focal neurological symptoms such as hemiparesis and aphasia. However, she began responding to pain and stimulation 15 minutes into the dextrose treatment. Her symptoms resolved within an hour, leading to the fulfillment of Whipple's triad for hypoglycemia. In light of these findings, a CT scan to rule out vascular events was not pursued.

Upon regaining consciousness, the patient shared her history of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM), diagnosed at 18, and her treatment regimen involving insulin and Neutral Protamine Hagedorn (NPH) insulin. She reported hypoglycemic unawareness for two years and frequent severe hypoglycemic episodes – up to three times a week in the past three months. She admitted that these episodes, which often occurred at night, sometimes required assistance from others.

The patient noted that due to her busy work schedule, she often failed to eat properly but would still take her usual insulin doses. Her regimen involved multiple insulin injections per day: regular insulin (10 U before breakfast and dinner, 6 U before lunch) and NPH insulin (25 U in the morning, 10 U at night). Her dose was last adjusted three months ago, but she had experienced several severe hypoglycemic attacks in the last four weeks. She also had been working out regularly for the past six months to manage her insulin needs and control her blood sugar levels.

A neurologist examined the patient in the morning for her neurological symptoms and found no deficits. Her medical history suggested a potential diagnosis of hypoglycemia-associated autonomic failure (HAAF). It was recommended she undergo an outpatient evaluation for this condition. To prevent recurrent hypoglycemia, additional laboratory tests and a follow-up appointment with an endocrinologist were suggested, along with a transition from human insulins to analog insulins. 

Despite these findings, given her symptoms and history, an alternative diagnosis of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus with hypoglycemia leading to coma cannot be completely ruled out. Further investigation is required to definitively determine the cause of her recurrent severe hypoglycemia.
model_response:
DX: Hypoglycemia-associated autonomic failure (HAAF)

The patient's history of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus, frequent severe hypoglycemic episodes, and hypoglycemic unawareness suggest that HAAF is the most likely diagnosis. The patient's symptoms, including focal neurological symptoms and hemiparesis, are consistent with hypoglycemia, and the resolution of symptoms after dextrose administration supports this diagnosis.
correct_diagnosis: Hypoglycemia due to insulin overdose in a patient with Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus.
target_distractor: Type 1 diabetes mellitus with hypoglycemia with coma
